PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1990-91[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 5) 1990-91APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 May, on motion by Mr Willis:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the honourable member for Macquarie, I remind the House that it has been agreed that there should be a general debate on this Bill and Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having taken a few moments to recover from that overwhelming reception, it gives me great pleasure to be able to speak this morning on Appropriation Bill (No. 5), which is for the appropriation of moneys to meet essential and unavoidable expenditures additional to the appropriations made for 1990-91 under Appropriation Acts Nos 1, 2 and 3 and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Act.

SPEECH.PARA: When one mentions `unavoidable expenditures' and additionals to the appropriations, one could perhaps spend the whole debate wondering why it was necessary and why they are unavoidable. A number of other speakers have, of course, taken that approach.

Today I wish to speak on the additional gross estimate of $278.2m that is being sought by the Defence portfolio in Appropriation Bill (No. 4). The total Defence outlays are estimated to increase by a net figure of $181m, when account is taken of all transactions contributing to the Defence function, including offsets provided from increased revenues and a reduction in the provision of contingent salary and related increases.

Let us look at the main objectives of our defence forces in relation to the additional estimated funds that are required under this Bill. I am talking in terms of the general aims and objects of each of our defence forces, irrespective of these particular appropriations but in terms of the Budget overall.

One of the prime objectives of our naval defence force is to provide a maritime force capable of conducting effective maritime operations in the pursuit of Australia's interests, using Regular and Reserve forces and expanding, or having the capacity to expand, in a timely manner against a warning of more substantial conflict. That statement is one of the prime concerns of past reports-the Dibb report, the White Paper and so on. We on this side of the House have become increasingly aware, in particular, of the Government's lack of attention on that point: of having the capacity to expand in a timely manner against warning of more substantial conflict.

The prime objective of our Army defence force is to provide land forces capable of conducting effective land operations in the pursuit of Australia's security interests, using both Regular and Reserve forces, and being able to expand in a timely manner against warning of more substantial conflicts and the resolution of high risk terrorist incidents in support of all our civil authorities.

I did hear a definition recently that an army is a body of men gathered together to correct the mistakes of politicians. I sincerely hope that in the light of the budgetary cuts and the points that are being emphasised in this debate, and with the seemingly rapid deterioration in terms of Government policy with regard to the defence forces, such a thing will never become reality in this country.

An army subprogram of individual training for both regulars and reservists is also to be developed. There is the need for the Government to provide more funding for the cadet organisations throughout this country. I know that the reintroduction of national service, of which a lot of people in this country would be very much in favour, is beyond the resources of the Government and the country at the moment; but certainly it is within the power of the Government to give more support to the cadet organisations around the country. In my own electorate there is a flourishing cadet corps at Katoomba, where, believe it or not, there is a long waiting list of young people wanting to become members of that cadet corps. It has recently been provided by the New South Wales Government with a very good venue in which to conduct its training.

The corps had to look for an alternative venue because in the Federal Government's selling-off program, the ideal set-up at Katoomba-the drill hall that was owned by the Defence Department-was sold off by the Federal Government as part of its revenue collecting exercise to help balance the budget. I would like to commend Mr Ollie Hume, one of the driving forces behind the cadet corps in Katoomba, for the work he has done. It will be of tremendous assistance in promoting a good, healthy group of young people in that part of Australia. There are very good flourishing cadet corps in many other parts of this nation. I do commend to the Government the provision of more support and funding to that very worthy cause.

The prime objective of the air Defence Force is to provide an Air Force that is capable of strategic and tactical operations as an independent, joint and combined force, including the supply of maritime and land operations in the pursuit of Australia's defence and internal security. Further development is necessary to meet higher levels of conflict should Australia's strategic circumstances deteriorate over the longer term. This is also high on the Air Force agenda.

Having regard to Australia's extensive northern coastline, its significant maritime interests and its relatively small manpower force, we need a strategy of defence in much greater depth. This dictates the need to operate in the sea and air approaches to this country. Air capabilities are vital in this regard. The Royal Australian Air Force also has an important role to play in conducting maritime surveillance patrols in our areas of interest, protecting shipping, offshore territories and resources, providing air lifts and offensive air support to the other services, contributing to cooperative activities with countries in our region, and providing assistance to civilians in times of crisis and natural disasters.

In my electorate there is the very large RAAF transport base at Richmond. Every time there is a crisis in terms of floods, drought and so on, such as the floods at Nyngan and in other parts of Australia, a substantial part is played by the men and women at the base and their aircraft in alleviating the tremendous problems that confront people in those crises. I commend the commanders and the personnel at the Richmond base for the excellent way they perform their duties and for their willingness to spend long hours, as they do, in carrying them out without overtime. No members of the regular Defence Force are paid overtime. There is time off in lieu, but they are prepared quite willingly to spend a great number of hours working in those areas of need that confront us from time to time. That objective is one of the very fine objectives that are achieved by the Defence Force.

The prime objectives of our defence forces that I have just outlined will be impossible to achieve in the light of the current problems that confront us with regard to our present defence capabilities. Our peacetime defence forces need to be kept at a high level of readiness if we are to have a credible deterrent. Our forces that went to the Gulf had to learn many of their warfare skills along the way-if that can be believed. Equipment was fitted onto the ships in a great rush, and the technicians and operators of the new equipment were fundamentally self-taught.

This parallels with the experience of our soldiers at the beginning of World War II, who stuffed cigarette papers into their bandoliers and who had to train with pieces of wood because of the shortage of rifles and ammunition. I sincerely hope that such situations and circumstances will not be the case today should we in this country be confronted with aggression.

We should reflect on the lessons learned from our previous wars, and remember that one of these lessons has to be the importance of maintaining a well-equipped and well-trained Defence Force so that we may deter any aggressor and allow our country to remain at peace. This is the desire throughout this country. No matter where one goes, when one talks to ordinary Australian people it is apparent that they are very concerned about the reports in the media-which are, in many instances, true-about the lack of confidence that is felt generally with regard to the capabilities and the effectiveness of our defence forces at the moment.

One major concern is the strength in numbers of our defence forces. The strength of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) continues to fall. It is now at its lowest level since 1979. It is expected that proposed drastic changes in Force structure will slash these figures dramatically. The crucial test will be whether the new strength and structure will leave the ADF with the capacity to carry out its role in the defence of Australia. The low level of strength at the moment has left many key units and formations seriously depleted. Is it any wonder that we are seeing large amounts of money being appropriated at this time in addition to those which were already budgeted for?

The Government now faces a fundamental problem in dealing with the legacy left by the former Minister for Defence, the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley). I point out that I do not consider it to be his fault, as I think that he really fought hard in Cabinet for money to fund many of the projects which were dear to his heart, but he failed. He did achieve quite a lot, but not enough. The predicament of meeting the defence budget, particularly at a time of economic stringency and given the very large commitments to capital expenditure which have grown year by year since 1983, is indeed a cause for great concern.

There is nothing to gain by honourable members on the other side getting up and saying, `What did you do?' and, `What were your achievements when you were in power?'. We are talking about the situation that confronts us now and the needs that are occurring now. The mobility of armed forces throughout the world is quite different, and the needs are quite different in terms of the responses that need to be made. We need to look at these situations with regard to what we can do now. That is a very important point. We ought not to get bogged down in debates about who did what, who did not do what and so on. The finger can be pointed at both sides in terms of deficiencies in this regard. We need to really concentrate on the current situation.

Despite the fall in wastage rates, to which I referred earlier and which was an inevitable result of the current recession-one notices that when we get a downturn in the economy, the separation rate within the armed forces decreases as a natural result-the numbers leaving the forces remain comparatively high. Even with the euphoria generated by the Gulf commitment, speculation concerning further cuts has left morale very low, and I mean low. I do not want anybody to get up and say that morale is not low, because it is low.

In the past two weeks I have spoken with and been in the company of dozens of men from all the defence forces. For example, I attended the El Alamein Firepower Day; while I did not go around and solicit from people whether their morale was high or not-which I never do-it is not hard to pick up very quickly that morale is low. Even at Anzac Day services, at which many of the regular forces personnel were present, expressions about the decline of morale in the defence forces were made. This morale problem is real and we ought not deny it; we ought to be doing things to build morale up rather than just seemingly turning a blind eye to it.

The Australian Defence Association recently expressed its concern at reports in the media about proposals regarding substantial cuts to the regular defence forces. The reports include: a cut overall of 10,000 regular personnel, or 14 per cent of the total force; the reduction of the Army's combat strength of two of its six infantry battalions; and the closure of bases such as the Richmond RAAF base and the Australian Air Command at Glenbrook. All these rumours are floating around and appearing in newspapers; usually such rumours are a very clear indication of the Government's intentions. I know the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) will make a statement on 6 June; it will be very interesting to hear what he has to say on that occasion. I hope the plans will not take into account the serious cuts in expenditure, such as the closing of the important base at Richmond and the efficient administrative centre at Glenbrook.

The Association accepts, and indeed has highlighted for some years, that there is a substantial degree of manpower misuse in the ADF. No-one is denying that; there will have to be a rationalisation. However, at the same time key units are seriously under strength. Proposals to cut regular defence manpower by a raw figure of 10,000 do not make much sense at all. At the same time the combat elements of the force, especially the Army, are already 18 per cent below authorised strength according to a reply to a question on notice by the Minister for Defence in March this year.

Australia's commitment to the Middle East war, while admirable in rhetorical terms, was approximately one-tenth of what a country of Australia's population and wealth might have been expected to contribute. While it was essentially symbolic, and will attract equally symbolic rewards, the fact remains that the basic level of manning and training left the Government with almost no option but to limit the commitment to two warships and a supply ship. It may have been possible to contribute some combat aircraft, but no credible ground forces could have been provided in less than six months. That is almost hard to believe.

In this context it is worth pointing out that a fundamental measure of defence capability is sustainability. In manpower and equipment terms this means that a defence force must provide an inventory of equipment and personnel roughly three times larger than it needs to maintain in combat. This allows for replacements, resting and repair. We do not enjoy that situation in this country. I would like to quote from a speech made by the United States Ambassador, Mel Sembler, at the National Press Club in Canberra in April 1991:

I think that the Gulf War has taught us several important lessons-and two of them definitely relate to security in the Pacific. The first lesson tells all our friends and allies in the region that we keep our commitments.
We must say `thank you' to the United States for that. The speech continues:

We can be counted on. The second shows that concerned nations can stay together in a common cause to support the rule of law against an outlaw like Saddam Hussein. This gives credence to our emerging Pacific security concept of ``co-operative vigilance.''

Under this concept we see a growing partnership where all parties provide adequate contributions to common defence needs and show a credible degree of self-sufficiency. It is a call for greater intra-regional responsibility sharing.

There are very serious doubts about our degree of self-sufficiency and our ability to defend this country in a time of crisis. Only a little over a month ago the Chief of the Air Staff, Air Marshal Funnell, stated that the Air Force was losing its technological edge and that we did not know what was going on in the vital air-sea gap to the north. The Gulf war has confirmed warnings made last year by Australia's chief defence men that the ending of the Cold War could lead to instability and uncertainty in our region. The Cold War strategy of superpower patronage had restrained many would-be troublemakers like Saddam Hussein. They warned the Government in a direct and indirect way that this situation had to be dealt with in a very strong way in terms of a greater commitment by the Government to our defence forces generally.

Finally, I mention that on El Alamein Day last week I had the great honour and privilege of being only one of two members of parliament, despite the fact that 40 were invited, to attend that firepower day. Again, this is cause for a great deal of demoralisation in the forces.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, I want to address the level of foreign investment in Australia. It is a topic which is raised with me from time to time by many branch members of the Australian Labor Party. Many of them have fears about the level of foreign investment in Australia and those fears often become more particular: they worry about the level of Japanese investment in Australia. I will cite some figures which indicate the level of foreign ownership, control and investment in Australia and also try to delve into the whole question of Australian sovereignty and capital accumulation. The figures I will cite are from the Foreign Investment Review Board report of 1989-90 which was tabled only in the last couple of days.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a great deal of irrational fear about the level of foreign investment in Australia, but there is also a rational argument about the degree of control which Australians do or do not have over their own industry. It seems to me that there are a couple of questions to be focused on. There is the question of whether Australia has a sufficiently wide spread of trading partners. For instance, do we trade too heavily with a single entity such as Japan? Should we not attempt to spread that trade more widely?

I noted in the speech by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to the Japan Chamber of Commerce in Tokyo on 20 September 1990 that he said that the two-way exchange of goods between Australia and Japan last year was worth $23 billion. He also illustrated the nature of the exchange-that Australia had been a supplier of essential commodities, mainly coal, iron ore, aluminium and liquefied natural gas, and that increasingly we are becoming a provider of quality foodstuffs. In exchange for this, the Japanese, characteristically of course, as manufacturers, have supplied a diversity of sophisticated goods, mainly motor vehicles, manufacturing and telecommunications equipment, electrical goods and computers.

So there is that question of whether our trade is too narrowly based and therefore we become dependent upon another nation because of the narrowness of the trade. The other question concerns that often more spectacular form of foreign investment-the degree of ownership by foreigners of Australian companies. I must admit that, particularly in Queensland and in some sensitive regional areas such as the Gold Coast and Cairns, there has been a degree of hysteria about the degree of foreign ownership, particularly Japanese ownership on the Gold Coast and in the Cairns region.

Some governments from time to time have chosen to use that anti-foreign investment, anti-Japanese investment card; and they do so to their own detriment, in my view. In improving the living standards of Australians, the name of the game is capital accumulation. If Australians cannot accumulate sufficient capital of their own, they must seek to borrow that capital from others or they must seek investors who will buy part of our industry to help us develop that industry. The only alternative is to choke off investment and development. At the end of the day, having sought Australian investment in any number of industries, if investment is not there, if we have not accumulated sufficient capital of our own, we must seek that capital from others who have, for whatever reason, been able to accumulate it.

I might say to those of the far left of the political spectrum that there is a Marxist definition of capital as `dead labour'. In other words, capital is nothing more than the fruits of the generations of workers' labour that has gone on beforehand. It is not easily accumulated and it has to be marshalled very well and very intelligently if it is to be built upon. Some of my branch members and any number of Queenslanders have to take this broader view that Australians do have choices, but that some of those choices are not easy ones. If we do not have sufficient Australian capital by which to develop our own industries, then we ought to seek foreign investment.

It seems to me that there are clear figures in the Foreign Investment Review Board's report that indicate that, on the one hand, the spread of investment in Australia has not narrowed in the last number of years and, on the other hand, the degree of foreign ownership in various industries has not increased. I want to cite those figures.

The report shows the level of foreign investment in Australia by country from 1984-85 to 1988-89 in billion dollars. The second largest investor in 1984-85 was the United Kingdom at $26 billion; in 1988-89 the UK was the largest investor at $47 billion. Next ranked in 1988-89 was the United States (US); it invested nearly $47 billion. In 1984-85, it was the largest investor in Australia, at nearly $27 billion. Third ranked is Japan, which in 1984-85 invested $16 billion and in 1988-89 invested $33 billion.

The rankings of our sources of foreign capital-that is, the UK, US and Japan-have remained reasonably stable over that period of five years from 1984 to 1989. Our key supplying nations for capital are still the UK and the US, and they are likely to remain so for some time. The level of Japanese investment certainly has picked up, but, as I say, I do not find any reason to worry about that.

Let us go to a further set of statistics on foreign ownership and control in Australia. These are at table 3.6 in the Foreign Investment Review Board report of 1989-90. Foreign ownership is cited by industry sector, by per cent, for selected years. For instance, in 1972-73 the total foreign ownership in mining was 49.5 per cent, with, by definition, Australian ownership of 50.5 per cent.

The increase in the level of investment in mining during that time was phenomenal, and the degree of Australian ownership in mining increased. In 1984-85 the Australian ownership percentage was 55.3, while total foreign ownership was 44.7. In that decade and a half of growth in one of our key sectors-that is, the mining industry-Australian ownership lifted from 50.5 per cent to 55.3 per cent.

In mineral processing the situation was somewhat reversed. In 1972-73 the total foreign ownership level was 39.7 per cent and Australian ownership 60.3 per cent, but by 1981-82 the degree of foreign ownership was 46.3 per cent and Australian ownership was 53.7 per cent. So in that sense of comparing Australian ownership with foreign ownership we have slipped. To give a further illustration, in 1972-73 the total level of foreign ownership in manufacturing was 31.2 per cent and Australian ownership was 68.8 per cent, and by 1986-87 total foreign ownership was 30.9 per cent and Australian ownership was 69.1 per cent.

These figures tend to indicate that there has been a stability in the proportions of Australian and foreign ownership, at least in those three key sectors. There are a whole series of other sectors in the statistics which generally indicate the same sorts of movements-either some improvement in the proportion of Australian ownership or a stability in the level of Australian ownership in Australian industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has happened in the last five years?

—I do not have those figures in this report. If the honourable member would like to bring them to the chamber and quote them, he might do so. I guess the statistics illustrate some of the fears that honourable members opposite as well as some of the members in Australian Labor Party branches have about foreign ownership per se. What is the problem? If we cannot accumulate the capital, and we want to continue to develop Australian industry, we will need foreign ownership. The only question is: under what circumstances do we use it? Do we allow foreigners to take up ownership-equity-of our Australian industry, or do we simply continue to borrow the money? We did go through a binge, a phase of borrowing, and now we are in a situation in which much of the private sector is beholden to foreign capital inasmuch as we have to repay a lot of those loans. We do not at this stage have the productive capacity to repay easily. I am sure that as we come out of the recession we will have that capacity. We should not confuse a short term recession with this broader question that I am illustrating of the level of foreign ownership in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Tourism has been a particularly sore point amongst Queenslanders. In the Gold Coast and Cairns areas in particular we can see the degree, level and importance of Japanese ownership. It seems to me that at times the Queensland Government has prodded along to some degree that fear of Japanese ownership and investment. There is a joint study now by the Queensland Government and the Commonwealth Government into the question of foreign ownership in tourism.

Already we have some figures that suggest that amongst the five-star accommodation sector of the tourist industry there is about 49 per cent foreign ownership. If we measure the total amount of accommodation available in the tourist industry, we find that the level of foreign ownership is running at less than 20 per cent. The most spectacular and obvious level of the market is 49 per cent foreign owned, but the entire Australian tourist industry, so far as we can measure it in terms of beds available, is only 20 per cent owned by foreigners. Again, we should put the figures in perspective.

I know that from time to time the Queensland Government has reacted to the sensitivities of Queenslanders, especially about Japanese investment, but the Queensland Government needs to remember that it cannot want and ask for foreign investment-especially Japanese investment-and, at the same time, play on the worst prejudices of some Queenslanders. It can play the game straight and say, `We need that investment', and perhaps monitor where the investments are made; but it cannot play a dual game and say, `Well, we're not too keen on Japanese investment' when on the Gold Coast and then, in front of the Japanese Chamber of Commerce, open the doors and say, `We love you, we want your money'.

It is that sort of doublespeak which worries me considerably, because the Commonwealth Government has never played that double game. We have consistently argued the case for the need for foreign investment, and consistently sought to defend that case even in the worst circumstances amongst the most prejudiced of Australians, and we will continue to do that.

It seems to me that there was an opportunity, certainly in Queensland on the Gold Coast, where not only Japan but also any number of other nations were interested in the concept of the multifunction polis (MFP) which was, in a sense, to be a science city. It was clear from the Australian studies of the multifunction polis that the Gold Coast would be the key and prime location. I must say that I was very disappointed indeed that the Queensland Government, for whatever public reasons it gave, did not wish the MFP to go ahead on the Gold Coast. It did not wish it to go ahead on the Gold Coast for the very basic reason that it was scared of the anti-Japanese reaction. It seems to me that we do not play politics like that in Australia in 1991.

Queenslanders were sick to death of being treated as children under the Bjelke-Petersen regime. The new Labor Government in Queensland is bound to treat Queenslanders as intelligent adults, and it should never play to those base prejudices of some people who reside on the Gold Coast who would prefer the wealth that comes with foreign investment, but who do not want that foreign capital to come from a particular source.

I do not think that I have wrongly interpreted what occurred over the decision on the MFP. I have investigated it fairly carefully and it seems to me that a very fresh, young and perhaps immature State Government was, if you like, forced to make a decision that it might not necessarily make a couple of years down the track when it feels more relaxed, more settled, more in control and more able to sell the tough proposition. The tough proposition is that, if other Australians have undertaken a study which suggests that a multifunction polis should be located on the Gold Coast, then we actually go ahead and support that proposition despite some very loud objections from a very base section of the Australian electorate.

In conclusion, I say to my branch members and other supporters of the Australian Labor Party that I am very pleased that a number of the questions they asked me about foreign investments are now couched in far saner terms than they once were 10 and perhaps 15 years ago; that Australians now realise that, as part of our integration with the international community, we will draw in a great deal of foreign capital; and that the only question is how quickly and how well we can repay our debts when we borrow, and how quickly and how well we can learn from our partners who might invest with us.

The Australian Prime Minister has now said a number of times to the Japanese that we do now wish to spread the nature of Japanese investment particularly throughout Australian industry. We realise that much of their investment is centred in real estate and tourism. I can understand that. But for me that is a means of opening their eyes to Australian industry. It does not mean that that is all they want to do in Australia. But the Japanese are learning about Australian industry, and it is our job to teach them a little more about how well Australian industry operates and how they may assist us.
I again refer to a section from the Prime Minister's speech of September 1990 when he said:
It is time for you-
the Japanese-

to be more creative in your approach to investment in Australia and to joint ventures with us. Together we could become productive partners in increasing the value-added component of Australian exports and expanding our export-oriented manufactures and services.

I think the Prime Minister is right. We do want more from our relationship with the Japanese and other foreign investments, but we do not want to turn off the tap. We should never give in to those people who, based on prejudice, would seek to ruin Australian industry because they do not happen to like the source of our foreign investment and they do not happen to like what they perceive to be a loss of control by Australians over our industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some parts of the speech just made by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) interested me. There is no doubt that we do need to get more from our foreign relations. One thing I will say, though, is that this Government has been very lax in trying to seek reciprocity in access. When one looks at difficulties with countries like Japan, one needs to remember that we seem to approach most of our foreign relations in more of a subservient role than I believe is appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: I think a great deal could be done, for example, to secure access for our manufactured exports into the Japanese market, to secure the same rights of selling and owning property and operating in that market as they enjoy here. It is no use accepting the Japanese response unless of course there is that access. The reality is that there are all sorts of hedges and restraints, as all of us know. The first thing we have to do in looking at our relations with Japan-and in general terms I agree with the honourable member-is that we need to be far more aggressive in our approach.

One of my concerns on the wider subject which I wish to address is that there seems to be among some people the view that the world owes us a living. I think the world is becoming an extraordinarily difficult marketplace, wherever one looks. There is no doubt that the downturn in the economy, the recession that we are suffering here, is not unique. We do need to remember that an analysis of the economic pattern in Australia, as distinct from the circumstances in 1981, 1982 and 1983 about which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and others seek to berate us so often, shows that in this instance we have led the world into the recession. It is not the product of our following, it is not a product of our being able to maintain proper economic approaches towards management; it has been a matter of the world in this instance actually going into recession after Australia.

Yesterday we heard the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer trying to talk up the economy. We should remember that we cannot talk up the economy if the international environment in which we operate is on the downturn. It is this attitude to so many subjects which concerns me.

Before I address the core of my concern this morning, I wish to commend the honourable member for Macquarie (Mr Webster). Sadly we have very few debates on defence issues in this place. I am most concerned at what I see as the result of the force structure review which is to be announced by the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) in the other place early next month.

There are three aspects of it. Firstly, the geopolitical situation, not just on an economic basis but on a political basis, is changing. The world in which we live is far more fragile than it has been, in my view, almost since the end of confrontation. I think that is probably the most appropriate time to refer to, although the problems in Vietnam, and of course Korea, were after the Malaysian confrontation period. We need to understand what is happening in Bougainville. The Honiara accord seems to be at an end. We have enormous problems with predicting the outcome of events in the Pacific countries. We certainly have residual difficulties in knowing where the Philippines is heading.

All this is happening at a time when the Americans, as a result of the changed world geopolitical situation, are saying that they can reduce their military strength. Indeed, I thought it quite ridiculous for the Prime Minister to take the initiative he did on the North West Cape. There is no doubt that that facility is of tremendous use to Australia, but it has been a backup facility to the Americans. For the Prime Minister to say that we are automatically going to take it over puts a defence expense on the Australian Government at a time when those funds need to be looked at within the allocation of funds here.

The geopolitical situation is changing. There has been no real reappraisal of the White Paper produced by the Government in 1987, and that 1987 White Paper has never been funded by this Government-either by the previous Minister for Defence or by the present Minister for Defence. The Government, for all that it pretends to have developed self-sufficiency of our Defence Force, knows that that is not so. We are not self-sufficient; we are less self-sufficient. Anyone looking at our commitment in the Gulf would realise that to be true; indeed, the very nature of our commitment was that we could only operate as part of an American force. For us to believe that we are now more self-sufficient is wrong, and yet that is the direction that all of us accept we should take.

So we have to look at funding and the application of funds. I am not too sure whether a great deal more could be done in revamping the management structures within the Australian Defence Force. The Government has done nothing about that. If it is going to look at the Australian Defence Force structure review, it ought to be looking at management and not just pruning bases and cutting back funding of projects such as our F111s, one of the projects that I am told may be at risk. If that were so, it would be dangerous in the extreme.

Whatever the Government does, now that it has committed itself to major construction programs in Australia on the submarines and on the frigates, for all that I have reservation about the original commitments, there must be no reduction in the funding for those programs or it will do irreparable damage to Australia. I commend the honourable member for Macquarie and share many of his concerns.

The main subject of my concern this morning and the reason for my wishing to speak is that I am very worried about the state of Australia. I think that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the shadow Minister for industrial relations, employment and training, has been registering most effectively an alternate industrial relations policy to be pursued. We need to understand that the elements that produce wealth in Australia are extraordinarily under threat.

I opened by referring to my worry about the economic markets in which we sell. I am equally concerned about the climate of production, the costs of production and the way in which the Government seems to ignore the penalties which, in particular I think, flow through the constraints of our industrial relations system.

I raise this matter because my main worry is that the Government is seeking more than ever to pursue the compromises, the so-called consensus approach, which are representative of the accord-not with the community, not with concern about the costs of production or passing on benefits where there is an improvement of productivity across the board, but by simply addressing how to share the spoils between the employers and the employees and allowing for some rise in wage levels to accommodate the accord relationship between the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the Government.

Above all, one element that must be addressed is the facilitation of voluntary unionism. There is no doubt that at the moment the closed shop environment which is listed in so many theatres is impossible. It is not a basis from which we are going to be able to secure a real competitive environment.

Again, let me stress that the world does not owe us a living. The nations that surround us geographically are processing and proceeding in developing their secondary industry at a far greater rate than we are. Their transport systems are more efficient. Day by day we see comparisons in the waterfront handling capacity of Singapore and other Asian ports to those in Australia. We are not going to succeed in reaching their level of productivity by the present compromise negotiated by the Prime Minister in his all night session the other night. Frankly, the result of that was not to achieve the productivity improvements we need on the waterfront, but merely to satisfy some of the differing elements within the Labor movement, within the Australian Labor Party, within the trade union movement, and with a single group of monopoly waterfront employers.

People need to remember that if we are going to look at the waterfront we should be looking at not just improving the conditions of productivity by the employees. As far as I am concerned many of those in the stevedoring industry too need to have their productivity significantly improved and their management improved apart from anything else.

I see no reason why there should not be a greater percentage of handling of individual goods imported and exported by those who are in fact the shippers of those goods. I think the exporters and importers tend to be the element largely neglected in the compromise agreement reached on the waterfront. My concern in the wider economic scene is that the world market is deteriorating, the world economy is in recession, and Australia is changing its ball game far too slowly to compete.

My particular worry is that, in the rural sector of Australia at a time when we are not addressing the infrastructure reforms that we should, we are finding that there is an increasing drought bearing down on much of our productive industry. Before coming to the drought-and I have spoken briefly about industrial relations and macroeconomic reform-let me say that, in my view, the Government has gone entirely the wrong way in trying to secure the competitive advantage we need. At the moment we have not done anywhere near enough to contain Federal Government spending and Federal Government programs. We have not pursued privatisation, even in the legislation introduced in the House yesterday by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley). We are not looking at trying to establish the most effective marketplace; we are trying to reach compromises to satisfy existing vested interests.

We have an enormous number of vested interests in Australia-in the employee field, in the management field and in the education field. My colleague the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp), who is the shadow Minister sitting at the table, knows that there are enormous problems, not in trying to throw aside those vested interests but in trying to determine the most efficient way by which we can establish a more equal playing field for the future.

What I believe we have done in macro-economic reform is really just pursue a far too narrow vision of how we can pursue greater fiscal restraint and improve managerial operations. We have got to address that. But with increasing corporate failures, with the difficulties of the entrepreneurs, and with the general disgrace, which applies not just to those who are presently before royal commissions and the courts but flows right across the board, I am afraid that Australia's industry and its reputation are down the gurgler. In the international perspective we are in the worst position that I can recall, simply because in past days we have had a large number of Australians whose reputations have been high.

What is happening in Australia at the moment is that we have besmirched our reputation, we have besmirched our credibility; and the Government does not seem to understand that all this flows through. When it does, we have to be even more dramatic and more significant in the changes made in economic and government policy and in the overall programs that are pursued-and we are not doing that. We are not responding to the national disgrace that the Brian Burkes are bringing on us at the moment. That is not to say that Brian Burke is necessarily guilty of all the matters that have been alleged, but certainly there is little doubt that the Government's attitude towards Brian Burke as Ambassador for Australia to Ireland and the Holy See is reflected in its approach on so many other issues. Sadly, it is not just in politics; it is in business and it is in corporate affairs, and all that is reflected in the failure of small business and in the failure of the rural sector, which I want to address for a few moments.

I said that all these things are happening before we come to the drought. This morning's Australian Financial Review says that the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics has already assessed the consequence of the increasingly dry conditions around Australia. I notice that the Bureau has produced some preliminary assessments. I can assure the readers of this morning's media that it is not just a 25 per cent reduction in wheat production that is being faced: already 60 per cent of New South Wales is drought declared. Within the southern winter rainfall zone there is increasing concern about the present lateness of autumn rain. In spite of the fact that there was so much rain in about half of Queensland through the summer months, about half of Queensland is moving into drought conditions. It is true that, if we get rain within six weeks, perhaps general circumstances could change.

However, I wanted to refer to the drought because it, like the aspects of micro- and macro-economic operations and like the geopolitical situation we are facing, needs to be viewed against what is happening in particular industries and against the climate which, I see, is not being redressed by present Government policies.

Since this Government was elected there have been a number of fundamental changes which are not being taken into account, when you look at just how profitability in individual sectors-certainly in the rural area-operates. Let me just refer to a few. There is the higher cost of meat inspection charges: it is now 100 per cent. That is a direct cost in killing that goes back to the producers. The abolition of superphosphate subsidies, something that is not in contention on this side of the House, is a cost as far as the producers are concerned. Reduction in wool promotion, the changes in the tax treatment of livestock, natural increases in valuations, the failure to maintain real expenditure on roads, the difficulties there have been in fundamental changes to depreciation allowances-and we all know the cry so many in business put in for changes to investment allowances-the increases in levies and charges, the changes in the incidence of sales tax, and the cost of indirect taxes-all these things bear down on so many of the productive industries. We have the increase in fuel excise and we have the reductions in assistance for those in the education sector, including means testing, cuts in isolated children's programs, and cuts in the assistance provided to university and educational residential systems.

We have the problems in the sugar industry, debated in this House the other week. We have the fundamental cuts to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. When all these are put together, they start to represent a change in the environment within which business is operating. I am particularly speaking at the moment, of course, of the rural sector.

I am not saying that any of those need necessarily have been wrong in isolation, but I am saying that what is happening is that the world environment is changing and the marketplace itself is getting harder, but the Government is not pursuing the correct macro- and micro-economic programs, which is adding to the costs of each of our productive industries in a way that makes life very difficult for them.

People need to understand that there are elements in this that have far more profound implications than perhaps the Government itself has realised. One of the difficulties is Australian asset prices-the degree to which, because of the way in which our markets and industries have operated, the structure of our financial system has been predicated on values given, assets held, and equity in residential property, commercial property and, of course, on government paper. All those elements reflect some sort of security. In national terms we talk about our security being in the overseas reserves we hold. We know how our overseas debt has risen, but it is not just a matter of looking at that.

The difficulty with the present climate in Australia is that the value of all those assets is declining. Part of the problem that I see in the present trend in government management is that nobody has addressed the difficulty of what is going to happen when the residential property, the commercial property, the rural property and the equity are all trending down, so that the assets which back the financial advances to business are no longer there.

In relation to the rural sector, I was talking to the honourable member for Riverina-Darling (Mr Hicks) earlier this week. I do not think there is a more difficult productive area in Australia than the western plains of New South Wales. We heard the other day, in his speech on a matter of public importance, extraordinarily distressing letters about families who were withdrawing their children from school because they cannot afford to give them an education. We are hearing of banks having to foreclose properties.

I was horrified the other day-I had better not identify the school-when the principal of a school said to me how distressed he had been that morning to hear that the head boy at his school had just received a call from his parents saying that the banks had foreclosed on their property and the family was forced to walk out with nothing. That is not an unusual event, but it is a real event-it is happening. As far as I am concerned, it is happening because progressively the worldwide environment within which we are operating is not one within which we are going to find it easy to compete. Our own marketplace is losing its competitive edge and it is losing its asset edge, and that double whammy is creating an impossible circumstance for those who are trying to generate the wealth upon which this country's living standards depend.

Turning from that, let me spend two minutes on the recovery plan that the Minister called for the wool industry. I commend Sir William Vines and his colleagues for the recommendations they have produced. But everything the Government has done, both in its reaction to the Vines Committee and even in its earlier supplementary payments scheme, has failed to address the fundamental problems of the declining value of the assets from which people are going to fund their operations, the difficult world environment in which we operate, and our failure to achieve a truly competitive edge.

The problem is not just the trade union movement. I have suggested that we have to address our macro-economic and micro-economic programs urgently and dramatically; I have suggested that we have to address the challenge of voluntary trade unionism; and I have suggested that the policies that the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) has enunciated must be pursued. But the Government has to realise, with some sensitivity, that it is responsible for the disabilities that arise from what it does.

For example, why the devil could the supplementary payments scheme to which I referred not have been implemented simply by reducing the present levy paid by woolgrowers? That would have got rid of all that administrative burden. If the Government is going to provide $300m, it could have done that by reducing the levy on wools to be sold between now and 30 June. That would have got money straight through to the woolgrowers and got rid of the administrative costs. It would have achieved the same result.

The same thing is happening with the recovery plan for the wool industry. We have a whole lot of nuances in this recovery plan which are going to lead to more bureaucratic intervention and less efficiency. We have to understand that the climate within Australia at the moment is critical; the drought is accentuating that situation. As I mentioned, at the beginning of the 1980s Australia lagged behind the world going into depression, but now Australia is leading it. I am afraid that the Government's programs in approaching these questions are totally wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91, and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91 provide for additional estimates for a wide range of activities not previously budgeted for. They include $32.2m as a contribution to the cost of deployment of Australian naval vessels and personnel to the Persian Gulf task force. As honourable members would be aware, this contribution is only a portion of the total cost of our involvement in that conflict and in its repercussions in terms of reconstruction of property and the restoration and establishment of human rights for the peoples of the region. I have heard estimates of $100,000m, but have no way of ascertaining their accuracy.

SPEECH.PARA: The human and environmental damage arising from the war will undoubtedly cost us all dearly, irrespective of the monetary value of that cost. For instance, the tragedy of the Kurdish refugees as a by-product of the Gulf conflict cannot be ignored, and I am sure is not ignored, by this House. Their plight, both within and without Iraq, is impossible to ignore. The assistance of the international community is essential to help resolve their difficulties. However, it can be claimed that their difficulties have been exacerbated by the conflict. Whilst their situation was not at all satisfactory before the war, thousands of Kurds were killed during the bombing and many more died in Iraq as a consequence of the attempts to overthrow Saddam Hussein after his defeat in Kuwait. Even more died while fleeing to Iran or Turkey. Mention has been made in this place of the difficulties encountered by them in the mountains-the cold and hunger, and the sickness. I know that most Australians' hearts would have been torn by the sight of these people on television.

The plight of the Kurds is a tragedy of immense proportions which will not easily or quickly be resolved. In the meantime, continuation of aid is imperative, and I support absolutely the Government's commitment in this regard. These appropriation Bills provide for the financial support of $1m specifically for the Kurds and $5m for humanitarian aid in total. The announcement in recent days of the dispatch of more Australian Defence Force personnel to assist with medical, dental and water purification needs of Kurdish refugees from the war and postwar retaliations is an indication of the continuing nature of the problem.

That is not to say that Australia should ignore calls for such aid or that the Government should be miserly in its response. I think the Government has responded ably and adequately to this need and will continue to do so as other needs arise. Our involvement in the conflict demands our continuing contribution to the resettlement and reconstruction which will follow. I simply make the point that the costs of war are many and varied, and any realistic assessment of them cannot be confined to the money amounts associated with the commitment of personnel, equipment, provisions and arms. The cost in human terms is overwhelming, even in a short war, as the Gulf war has been termed. Mercifully, it was one in which no Australian lives were lost.

It is also appropriate in the context of this debate to mention the relative merits of deficit budgeting and surplus budgeting by government as a means of influencing macroeconomic outcomes. In recent years in this country and elsewhere in the world there has been a great deal of emphasis on the importance of obtaining and maintaining a surplus in order to assist-particularly in our case-current account imbalances. The floating of the dollar exposed the Australian economy to greater scrutiny at an international level and, as a consequence, what we do in Australia affects our currency level which in turn affects our ability to export products and to reduce our current account.

A recession demands some adjustment to the surplus Budget policy, as government has an important role to play in kick-starting the economy again at a time when business is reluctant, if not afraid, to commit its resources to the types of expansion which are essential to achieve recovery in the shorter term rather than the longer term. The importance of getting the economy going quickly rather than slowly is obviously needed in human as well as capital terms. People who lose jobs are unable to get jobs again for quite a long time.

The psychology of the community is absolutely crucial to this process of recovery. People require positive action on the part of government to encourage them to take advantage of those opportunities which present themselves. I think in the context of business this is important because it is not as if there are no opportunities available. With interest rates dropping and with businesses becoming available, some people are in the fortunate position of having capital to expend, but quite obviously and understandably they are reluctant to do so in the absence of other fairly firm action on the part of government. That shows the importance of the March industry statement, because it has helped people to understand the Government's thrust in these areas.

As the first sector of the economy to be affected by the recession, the housing and building industries are also the first to feel the effects of the recovery. Accordingly, public expenditure in the housing sector is an important element of the Government's approach to stimulation of the economy through assistance to industry on a broad front. At the meeting of housing and planning Ministers some weeks ago, the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) offered to bring forward Commonwealth-State housing agreement funds for the next financial year. Not surprisingly under the circumstances, the States accepted this offer by the Federal Government, and a total of $842m will be made available to them in two parcels, one from 1 July and the second from 1 October, to allow building of housing to commence considerably earlier than would otherwise have been the case. I think this sort of flexibility on the part of the Commonwealth is crucial to the recovery of the State economies and the economy of Australia as a whole.

With housing it is essential to remember also that the benefits are not just an improvement in our employment prospects or an improvement in our economic prospects; they include also the provision of an important infrastructure resource in the form of houses for Australians. The housing that we are talking about is housing for low income earners, those who are most in need in our society at all times, especially in a recession.

Employment stimulation across the industrial spectrum should take place in the months ahead. The industry statement contained a number of valuable measures which were designed to halt the loss of employment and to ensure the retention of apprentices during the course of the downturn. I make mention here, as I have elsewhere, and as many other honourable members have done, of the step to assist employers to retain people in jobs when their firm has been affected by the downturn. That will be by way of the payment of unemployment benefits so that people can be retained in jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very important, too.

—It is very important, I thank the honourable member for Throsby. I think it is crucial because people in those circumstances who have lost their jobs are often unskilled and they would have to undergo quite intensive training in order to regain a job. Through this scheme they are able to obtain that training on the job, whilst staying in a job where they know the people and, hopefully, where the employer understands their capacity.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe job creation schemes and community employment projects have an important role to play. These sorts of schemes have come into some question in recent times because of the upsurge in the economy when there was no obvious need for them to continue. I think that where these can be conducted in conjunction with approved training schemes, local government or other forums in the economy, they should be encouraged so that skilling and reskilling of the unemployed can go hand in hand with the experience and esteem of having a job. Of course, if we can associate such employment with training, we are actually ensuring that when the economy does pick up people will be in a position to use their skills to fill the needs in the economy for those skills.

When the Labor Government was in office in New Zealand I led a delegation to that country, along with some of my colleagues in this House and from the other place. It was quite obvious that, although the New Zealand Government was making a lot of decisions to do with rationalising and deregulating its economy, it did not appear that these measures were being taken in conjunction with positive employment programs.

That, together with the low infrastructure or manufacturing base of New Zealand, had a large impact on the number of people who became jobless as a consequence of the changes occurring in their economy. This was at a time when the economy of New Zealand was considerably more robust than it is at present. The demonstrations which are occurring in New Zealand at the moment have a number of underlying causes which include social welfare cuts, the extreme controversy concerning industrial relations and, of course, joblessness.

In the context of industrial relations controversy, I was interested in the views expressed by the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) about voluntary unionism. We cannot simply say that we should have voluntary unionism in Australia and expect that to mean that everything in the garden will be rosy-that all employers will be happy and that all employees will choose not to be members of unions. Union membership in Australia is largely voluntary. The Opposition continually raises the percentages in this area and says that the majority of people are not members of unions. That being the case, it is very difficult to sustain an argument which says that we have compulsory unionism in this country.

Unions in Australia have achieved considerable gains for their members over time. These gains have been distributed to the wider work force via the central mechanism of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Let us make no mistake: abolition of the centralised wage determination system will not advantage the powerful unions or their members-they do not need that system to achieve their wage rises. Discussion of enterprise bargaining should always be seen in the context that those in a powerful position in the economy whose skills are required will always be able to make demands on employers and have those demands met because the economy, at whatever rate it is working, will need their skills. They are masters in determining their capacity to bargain on those skills-that is their job, after all.

The people who would be most detrimentally affected by a change in the arbitration system would be those who are not members of unions or who are not members of strong or militant unions-that is, ordinary working Australians. Another group which would be detrimentally affected by a substantial change in this area would be small business. Small business people do not have the capacity to withstand union claims, or even employee claims if those claims were to be based on the withdrawal of labour.

If the arbitration system is abolished, increases will not flow on to ordinary people. As a consequence, those ordinary workers who may not be members of unions now will seek union membership because the unions will be needed in order to give them protection in the workplace. It is a simple scenario which I think people overlook-especially in the Australian context where the centralised wage system has, in fact, given people a great deal of protection, ensured a flow-on of wage increases and reduced the amount of militancy in the community.

I think that small business will also suffer because there will be no certainty in wage outcomes. That is one of the things that the Commission and the accord, through the Government and union negotiations, have ensured for Australian business-particularly for those smaller businesses which are not in a position to pay more than the award wage and which do not have the capacity to become involved in independent discussions or enterprise bargaining. They simply rely on knowing that there will be a regular wage required and that there will be fairly regular increases to that wage as the case may be.

The lack of certainty in wage outcomes would affect those people probably more than it would affect the larger companies, which can pass on their costs more easily to the public or remove their costs from profit for which small business does not always have a great margin. When I say `small business', of course, I mean those businesses which are operating at the margin, of which there are a large number in Australia and they employ a great many people.

Whilst being a strong supporter of unions, I think that greater militancy in the work force would flow from a radical change in the present industrial relations and arbitration arrangements. Confrontation would affect small business in another way, also, in that there would be a reduction in the cooperation which is very much needed in order to run a small business-that is, the cooperation between the employer and employees. Employees would see themselves as having to fight their employer in order to get gains in wages, or see themselves as being disillusioned or disadvantaged if the employer refused what they considered to be a reasonable request for an increase in wages.

To a large degree this would ruin the camaraderie which does exist between employers and employees in many small workplaces where, in fact, there is very little distinction in a managerial sense, and the manager often gets his hands dirty-it is not unlike the farms, really. Those things have to be looked at. I think that farms would also be affected in that way because the workers would feel that they had been disadvantaged by the existing system.

In the context of small business, I also wish to mention the fact that the Minister for Small Business and Customs (Mr Beddall) visited Perth recently and was the guest-not at my invitation, but at the invitation of the Morley and Districts Business Association-at a breakfast in Bayswater. Of course, breakfast is about the only meal of the day for which small business people can actually get away in order to talk about policy and other issues. The Minister was very well received and it was obvious from the discussion at that breakfast that the Beddall report Small Business in Australia-Challenges, Problems and Opportunities, which was brought down in this House in January 1990 by the Minister, was very well-received and had been well read by the participants at the breakfast.

The report had the support of these small business people in terms of its major thrust and also in terms of most of its recommendations. The support for the implementation of these recommendations was, therefore, very strong from small business people that I spoke to elsewhere and at that forum. The Minister was able to assure people that these recommendations are being implemented in a continuing fashion.

The links with schools and training establishments was another point which was raised at that meeting. Many of these small business people find that the employees they get from the schools need to have a little more specific training in order to make them most useful to small business.

That is not to say that young people leaving school are unable to take up the challenges provided in small business, but I think some of them will either be able to establish their own small businesses or will be able to make a more productive contribution to small business quickly if they receive some training at the school level. It is obvious from the discussions we had that some schools in the area have actually undertaken small business courses so that older students who may be contemplating a career in that area are able to skill themselves as much as possible before leaving school. That also means they will be able to come to grips with budgeting, accounts and those sorts of areas where they can be of value to an employer. With the current wage structure, it is important that young people leaving school have as many skills as possible in order to encourage their employment.

It was interesting that most students referred to in the discussions were from lower socio-economic backgrounds; their background was seen in a positive light by some people as these kids were actually very much aware of what had to be done and how one had to survive. They were those cluey kids who are able to cope in an employment situation. I thought that was very encouraging because in this place we often hear that many people from lower socioeconomic backgrounds-particularly children-lack skills that would enable them to get on in our society.

The links with schools are obviously helping the small business community and the students. I also think these students will not have to repeat the lessons they learned in the latter years of their schooling should they choose to go on to a training institution and follow through their own natural inclination perhaps to become small business people themselves. In discussion about our economy it is crucial to consider always the plight of unemployed people, and as a consequence my thoughts are never far from ways to assist them to obtain skills, and I think the Government is in the same mode.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been quite entertained by the contributions made by some Government members during the course of debate this morning. I cannot help but mention one or two things. I was quite astounded to hear the contribution made by the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) and his spirited-and I use that word loosely-defence of the Government's foreign investment policy. I hope he is listening because he was wrong on just about every count. Contrary to what he suggested, Australians are concerned about the selling off of the family silver, the selling off of the farm, the selling off of all our best real estate and industries and so on. Why is that happening? The defence of that by the honourable member for Petrie was pathetic when we really look at why this selling off is happening. It is because of, and simply is another example of, the failure of this Government to take action to foster the kinds of foreign investments we need in this country. The fact that we have such appallingly low levels of savings in this country is also a direct product of the economic mismanagement this country has experienced over the past eight years.

SPEECH.PARA: In my view the position of the honourable member for Petrie on foreign investment is totally indefensible. It is even interesting that it should come from someone in the Australian Labor Party. He acknowledges that many honourable members on his side of the House would completely disagree with him; I would like to think there will be a number on our side. We do have choices in this matter: this is our country and Australia belongs to Australians. We are standing by while this Government, acting in desperation, is attempting to sell off this country. The Government has no right and no mandate to do that. I believe most Australians are concerned. Speaking specifically for my electorate, which I guess bears the brunt of this, people on the Gold Coast recognise the benefits it has for them, but the great majority of my constituents nevertheless have expressed concern to me about the direction foreign investment has taken under this Government. They are concerned about it and I am articulating that concern on their behalf.

I want to make it clear to the honourable member for Petrie that most Australians-perhaps not him-are genuinely concerned about the direction foreign investment has taken under this Government. It is a laissez-faire policy, where everything goes-`Open the doors; we need everything we can get to try to balance the books'. Despite those policies the Government has still failed to balance the books and we now see an enormous net debt of $130 billion. That debt is almost totally beyond our capacity to repay within the foreseeable future. It could be 50 or 100 years before we pay back that debt, if ever we do so, and in the meantime we are saddled with an interest bill that will shortly become totally unmanageable. In fact, at the present rate we could find ourselves with a net foreign debt of some $200 billion by the year 2000. It is an enormous problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is your Party's policy on foreign investment? Tell us your Party's policy.

—I will tell the honourable member for Bowman the policy of the Liberal Party of Australia at another time. Let me put it in this context for the honourable member: the Liberal Party will be more responsible when fostering the sort of foreign investment needed in this country and in its industries to ensure Australia has the opportunity to repay that debt.

SPEECH.PARA: That contribution was another desperate attempt to salvage some credibility for a Government which is totally discredited in the eyes of the vast majority of the Australian people at this time. I notice that the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) is staying in the House for the time being, and I will refer to her contribution shortly. I cannot help but mention, because this is a wide-ranging debate-and I want to speak specifically to some matters raised in Appropriation Bill (No. 4), Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2)-that it is unbelievable that the Government should even contemplate putting the Treasurer (Mr Keating) up as Prime Minister. That is an example of the absolute desperation which exists on the other side of the House. Here we have a Treasurer who has a 6 per cent popularity rating.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a good day.

—Yes, as the honourable member for Lowe said, 6 per cent on a good day, yet the Government wants to put him up as Prime Minister. The people of Australia will not wear him as Treasurer; I cannot see how they will wear him as Prime Minister. However, that is how desperate the Government is to salvage just a little credibility. It almost adds a new dimension to the word `desperation'.

SPEECH.PARA: I listened to the honourable member for Cowan talking about kick-starting the economy. I would remind the honourable member that it will take considerably more than a good kick to get this economy going, after what will have been 10 years of mismanagement by the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, rubbish!
—Warren, you cannot even get to a dog show on time in a VIP jet. If that is a example of efficiency, I do not know what he is able to contribute--
—Order! The honourable member for McPherson must use the honourable member's electorate, not his name.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy Speaker. If the 12 March statement to which the honourable member for Cowan alluded is an example of a kick, I would be amazed if it were anything other than a bit of a flick pass. It is State of Origin day, so perhaps the analogy is appropriate-it was a flick pass and did nothing to address the real problems actually facing Australia. In a way it was a sick joke, which has already failed. I note that the debate on the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has been taken off the daily program. We have not heard anything more about it; it has faded into oblivion. I suppose one could say that it has been consigned to the scrap heap of prime ministerial rhetoric.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of honourable members in this House have referred to the recent waterfront deal in this debate. It really was the coup de grace for the 12 March industry statement given by the Prime Minister. That statement was supposed to give direction and leadership to this country. I suppose in a way the waterfront deal is the icing on the cake. If ever we were to need evidence of the inability of this Prime Minister to provide the real leadership this country needs in devastating times, the 12 March statement was an example of inability to give leadership. The waterfront deal, which was done last week with the mates who feature predominantly in this place each day, is further, final and conclusive evidence of the Prime Minister's total inability to come to grips with the problems facing this country. The Prime Minister is unable to deliver leadership when this country is crying out desperately for that sort of leadership.

Having made those comments-as I say, somewhat motivated by having listened to contributions from Government members who, almost out of desperation, were attempting to salvage some credibility-let me turn to the Appropriation Bills that we are dealing with today. I take honourable members back for a moment to the Budget that was presented last year by the Treasurer. This was not the one that would bring home the bacon. It did not get that billing, but nevertheless it was to produce an $8 billion surplus. On Budget night and on a number of occasions subsequently, we heard what a terrific job the world's greatest Treasurer-I remind the House that that was a mantle that he inherited from the Treasurer of Mexico-was doing. He was to bring down this Budget with an $8 billion surplus. What do we find as we deal with these Appropriation Bills? On the Treasurer's own admission most of that surplus has dissipated to the point where we could very well see a deficit occur, simply because of the Government's mismanagement. I refer to the enormous addition to unemployment benefit costs and the companies that are failing every day around the country and are unable to pay tax. That is another indictment.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was the last Howard surplus? When was the last surplus under a coalition government?

—The circumstances were different. If the honourable member for the Northern Territory wants to debate that issue, he can make a contribution. Is this not embarrassing for Government members? If I were sitting where they are, I would feel the same way. I understand how they feel. After the next election when they are sitting on the opposition side and we are sitting on the government side, we could take great delight in reminding them-although, in a sense, I hope we do not do what they have done-day after day of the ineptitude with which they have run the country since 1983. On almost every measure we find ineptitude or an inability to manage properly.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget that was presented last year predicted an unemployment rate of 7.25 per cent. What is the figure across the country now? The unemployment rate is approaching 10 per cent. I do not believe that that figure tells even half the story. It may well be that in real terms the unemployment rate is actually very much higher than that.

Of real concern, of course, is the fact that we have within that unemployment pool an enormous number of young people. In my electorate, 25 per cent of people between the ages of 15 and 19 cannot get a job. That figure, of course, is based on an Australian Bureau of Statistics sampling. We are not allowed to have the Commonwealth Employment Service figures. The Treasurer will not release those figures because, I imagine, they would be a devastating indictment on this Government's policies.

I cannot get any data or information from the Commonwealth Employment Service for my electorate. I have been told it is not available; it is not to be released. Why is that so? I can only assume that the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures which show youth unemployment at 25 per cent are vastly understated. I challenge the Government to tell us today what the true unemployment figure in this country is. I suggest that it certainly will be higher than the approximate figure at the moment of 10 per cent.

Even those unemployment figures tell only half the story.
