We can think about the hardship that has been suffered by people whose businesses have gone broke, who have been forced onto unemployment benefits for the first time in their lives, who are having marital hardship and breakup because of the enormous stress that this Government has created for them. I remind the Government again that on the Treasurer's own admission this is the recession that we had to have, and it has created all of this hardship.

I find it astonishing to hear the Treasurer almost boasting about inflation. He has found one measure on which to hang his hat, that is, a falling inflation rate. I put it to honourable members that in this recession, which is the worst recession we have had since the 1930s-and I suspect that in some respects it is worse than the recession at that time in terms of falling asset values and other measures; the whole asset base of this country will be completely decimated by the time we come out of this recession-we should not only be seeing, in these terms, falling inflation, but we could well expect to see deflation when things are as they are.

I do not think the Treasurer can take any comfort whatsoever from lower inflation figures. In fact, I suggest that they are only a temporary aberration and that it will be very difficult to keep the lid on inflation once we manage to turn this economy around. That is a job which those on the other side will not have to do. The job will be left to us. We will have to pick up the pieces. We will turn things around. We will spend plenty of time in this place over the next couple of years talking about how we will do that. We have the policies, and we will have the policies in place to turn this country around and get Australia moving again. But anything is possible in the meantime.

The Bills that we are debating-and I return to the topic that we are debating today-appropriate an additional $1 billion from Consolidated Revenue. I understand that this is expected to be partly offset by savings of $270m odd on expenditure authorised by the previous Appropriation Acts. I am interested in looking at Appropriation Bill (No. 4) which in part seeks an additional $28.7m for the Government's student financial assistance scheme, which is called Austudy. The Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) in his second reading speech said that this additional funding was necessary because it reflected the increasing number of recipients in the latter half of 1990, together with an anticipated increase during the first half of 1991.

Austudy is a scheme which costs the Government $1.1 billion per annum. We are being asked now to appropriate additional funds to this scheme yet, if ever we needed evidence of gross mismanagement and gross inefficiency, we have only to look at the Department of Employment, Education and Training-administered, I remind the House, by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins).

I recently took part in a study that was carried out by the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, of which I am a member, into the effectiveness of Austudy, the Government's student financial assistance scheme. During our investigations we found that this scheme was being managed very badly. We were asked to consider an Auditor-General's report into Austudy which contained 124 recommendations covering most aspects of Austudy administration since the inception of the scheme in 1987. That was the starting point.

The greatest concern that we had ultimately about the scheme, having interviewed a wide cross-section of the Australian community, was that there were no indicators as to the effectiveness of the program. The program effectively had no clear statement of objectives, and there had not been a proper assessment carried out of its effectiveness in any case. I suppose that if a program does not have objectives, it is pretty hard ultimately to judge whether the program has been effective.

Here we have over $1 billion of expenditure going into a program without any indication of whether it was being effective in meeting its objectives. The Committee, of course, recommended firstly that the Government should as a matter of urgency develop clear policy objectives for student financial assistance.

If we look at the Minister's portfolio, not only do we find Austudy, but we find one Dawkins disaster after another. The poor administration of Austudy is only the tip of the iceberg. I could go on for hours, given the time. For example, there are the forced amalgamations that continue to damage diversity and opportunity in higher education and the Government's inability to meet the demand for tertiary places.

The Minister is too clever by half, in a way. He decided that the Government would encourage kids to stay at school and he stands up here and tells us about the great job the Government has done in improving retention rates-and it has improved retention rates; nobody can quite say why, but let us assume that there is some reason for that. All those kids having stayed at school, they now want to go to university when they leave school. What do we find? There are no university places for them. One would have thought that that was pretty simple, but we find that over 20,000 qualified students in Australia are missing out on university places.

In my own State of Queensland the situation is endemic. Even the Premier, Wayne Goss, says that he is fed up with the Minister and does not want to have anything to do with him. The Gold Coast University College of Griffith University has facilities for about 700 students and we have about 2,000 students attending the college. But the piece de resistance of the administration of the Department is, of course, the training guarantee levy, the regulatory solution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sciacca The Hon C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that I should say something in passing about some of the comments, and sometimes rubbish, that the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford) has just been telling us about in this House. I was just reminded by the honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil) that everything is being done by this Government to look at the question of extending Austudy in remote areas and rural areas. It is quite incorrect for the honourable member for McPherson to criticise the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). I think the Minister's achievements in this area are very well known.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very interested when the honourable member for McPherson was complaining about the so-called sale of our property and so forth to overseas companies. I remember-he may not, because he was not here in this House at that time-his former leader, and I think that was the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) at that time, wanting to completely abolish the Foreign Investment Review Board. That is one of the major curbs that we have on the sale to people from overseas of assets owned by the Australian public and by Australians. It was those opposite who wanted to abolish the Foreign Investment Review Board. I do not know what their policy is now, of course, because it changes so often-simply to suit the times and depending on opinion polls. But I do not want to waste my time speaking on matters raised by the honourable member for McPherson.

I support the Appropriation Bill (No. 4), the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2). In particular, I wish to look at an area where the Government has found it necessary to seek additional provisions beyond the appropriations made for 1991 under the Appropriation Acts Nos 1, 2 and 3. This area is the health area. In the time that I have, I would like to talk about a growing area of health care that I feel deserves to be mentioned in this place. I refer to diversional therapy.

Diversional therapy is a relatively new form of health care that has developed in our health system over the past couple of decades. If we wanted to go back further, we could trace the beginnings of diversional therapy, even though under another name, back to the days of World War II, when Miss Leila Bloore recognised the need for more than medical rehabilitation for soldiers returning from the war and provided them with diversional activities.

The Diversional Therapy Association in its formal sense was established in Sydney in 1976. The Diversional Therapy Association of Queensland, my home State, being somewhat parochial, is of more interest to me. That was officially inaugurated on 12 October 1985. By October 1990, the membership in Queensland had grown to some 260-plus members. Diversional therapy groups in Queensland have been established in Cairns; Townsville; Caloundra; the Redlands district, which is in my electorate of Bowman; the Gold Coast; Toowoomba; Warwick; Ipswich; Maryborough; Gympie; Redcliffe; and Chermside.

What is diversional therapy? `Diversional' means to deflect and divert negative thoughts, actions and attitudes to positive feelings of well-being. It sounds simple, and in many ways it is. But it is also very effective. Diversional therapy provides leisure and recreational activities which are designed to enhance the psychological, spiritual, social and physical well-being of individuals within community settings and health care facilities. The diversional therapist motivates people through activities toward a fuller, more purposeful life.

Diversional therapists deal with a wide range of client types. Amongst them are: physically able and mentally able; physically able, but with a degree of dementia; physically disabled and mentally alert; physically and mentally disabled; frail aged; psycho-geriatric; those with Alzheimer's disease; intellectually disabled; those with visual or hearing loss; terminally ill; and, basically, all types of medical ailments.

Essentially, diversional therapy is client centred and recognises that leisure and recreational experiences are the right of all individuals and should be positive and valuable, ensuring opportunities for clients to pursue existing interests, acquire new skills and participate in their choice of activities. A wide variety of experience is appropriate to their interests and needs. Diversional therapy recognises the need to divert people away from illness, diverting them away from being institutionalised and diverting them away from confusion. A great deal of diversional therapy is conducted with our senior citizens.

But why such an emphasis on senior citizens? Why do they need stimulation? They certainly seemed stimulated enough when I was recently trying to explain the new deeming provisions to them! The answer, I guess, is easy to see when we stand back a little-stand back and stand still. Standing still is something we find very hard to do these days. We are always on the go. Constant change has become part of our daily lives.

But let us stand back a moment and see how much adjusting our senior citizens have had to do during their lifetime. It can best be demonstrated through reading a passage from a book I recently launched in Brisbane with my very good friend Haydn Sargent, a very popular talkback announcer in Brisbane. It was at a diversional therapy seminar and the book, co-authored by Wendy Butler and Margaret Stephens, was called Never Too Old to Learn. The passage went something like this:

Senior citizens of today are the children of the First World War and the Great Depression of the 1930s. They were here before penicillin, polio shots, antibiotics, heart transplants and replacement parts, before frozen food, plastic, nylon, dacron, radar, fluorescent lights, credit cards, ball point pens and thongs.

They listened to the wireless, not the radio. They played records on the gramophone, not discs on the stereo. TV and video were things undreamed of. For them `time sharing' meant togetherness and not spending one week of the year at Great Keppel. Computers were unimagined; hardware was something you bought if you wanted to fix the fence and software was a word yet to be invented.

They came before pantihose and drip dry clothes, before sinkerators and dishwashers, freezers and electric blankets. They lived before men wore long hair and earrings in their left ear and before women wore trousers and earrings in their nose; not to mention the shaved heads, the unwashed look, clothes bought with designer rips and tears, haircuts that once would have led to law suits and inventions that would have left Mandrake speechless. In those days the girls wore Peter Pan collars, hats and gloves and the men raised their hats to the ladies.

They lived without DDT, EEGs, vitamin pills, disposable nappies. They didn't walk in fear of stepping on a dirty hypodermic during their family day at the beach. They weren't decaffeinated or polyunsaturated and they did not watch their cholesterol. Macdonald was the vowel-singing old bloke who owned a farm and not a chain of burger joints. Fast food was what you ate during Lent; passive smoking was havin' a fag lyin' down; grass you mowed not smoked; coke you drank not sniffed and pot was something you cooked in.

In short, things are certainly not what they used to be. It is no wonder that so many of our senior citizens now feel somewhat dislocated. Peggy Skehan, a diversional therapist at the Brisbane seminar, said this to me the other day:

Imagine being old, frail, lost in a wilderness of uncertainty, not knowing what is going to happen next. If in a days work I can break through and get a smile from such a client . . . then that is the most precious moment of the day. Our main aim in our work is to give quality of life to those in their declining years; rather than simply sustaining life.

The main thing for staff to understand is the importance of doing things with residents instead of doing things for them. Diversional therapists are used more and more in the following places: nursing homes, hostels, retirement villages, day care and respite care centres, community centres, hospitals, rehabilitation and psychiatric units, special children's services, services offered by the Royal Blind Society, and multiple sclerosis, Red Cross and intellectually handicapped associations.

In Queensland the headquarters of the Diversional Therapists Association is based at Carindale, which is very close to my electorate. The Executive Director is Shirley Dredge, the President is Nina Grey, and the Secretary is Patricia Price. Unfortunately, there is still limited training in a professionally recognised capacity for diversional therapists. Nina and Shirley told me that the Cumberland College of Health Scientists at Lidcombe, New South Wales, is the only institution in Australia that runs a full time two-year associate diploma course. This situation can surely be improved.

In Queensland the Diversional Therapy Association offers a basic introduction course through the Ithaca technical and further education college, which consists of 18 hours of theory plus eight hours of practical training. This is augmented substantially via a whole swag of workshops and seminars right throughout the year, plus 10 newsletters each year.

I am interested in this area of diversional therapy because I feel that in the long term this approach to health care could contribute to a general reduction in overall health costs. There is no doubt that people with a positive self-image rely less on traditional forms of medication to help them through the day in their declining years than people who have developed a negative outlook on the hand that has been dealt to them in the card game of life.

Being from an ethnic background, I come from a culture where family is very important. I mentioned that in my maiden speech many years ago. If all else fails, we can rely on our family. I am not talking about immediate family; I am talking about extended family, no matter how remote the relationship. It makes me sad today to see situations where young people often seem to take little long term interest in the future welfare of their parents. It makes me just as sad to see an increasing number of parents apparently taking little long term interest in their children.

Times are indeed changing. The fabric of our society is changing. That cultural glue that once bound us together with the instinctive drive to protect our own has now somewhat been diluted, perhaps even contaminated. As a society, we seem to have embarked on a lifestyle course that has eroded our feeling of collective responsibility and built into our psyche the modern-day imperative of looking after No. 1. I think that is very sad. I am sure you would agree with me, Mr Deputy Speaker.

I was equally saddened when I read a report recently that my own cultural group, the Italians, have fallen victim to the decade of greed and the modern concept of individuality at any cost. Italian divorce rates have increased by over 200 per cent in past years. No-one, it seems, is now safe. In many ways-some small, some large-we are all suffering from various forms of cultural dislocation. This has probably hit the aged community with more impact than any other section of our community. Therefore, I believe that there is a need, more than ever before, for forms of diversional therapy to put as much positiveness back in life as is possible. It is too easy to be cynical, and in the long term being cynical is never constructive.

The Diversional Therapy Association makes it quite clear that it is only part of the overall health care team. Its work complements the excellent work done by others in the field. The moneys raised by this Appropriation Bill will help finance this excellent work.

In the remainder of the time that I have, I would like to cover a few other health areas that relate particularly to my own electorate-organisations that I know something about in detail, organisations that I believe deserve to be given some credit for the fine work that they do. Not only do they use government funds and funds from other sources to do excellent work, but also their organisations are very cost efficient. In these days, when the welfare dollar is very limited, it then needs to be targeted and that is obviously a very good thing.

In a previous speech delivered to this House on 9 April I mentioned the fine work of an organisation known as BABI, Bayside Adolescent Boarding Inc., whose work in the area of homeless youth drew Brian Burdekin, the Human Rights Commissioner, to make the comment that BABI should be used as a national model when it came to dealing with the growing problem of youth homelessness.

Owing to my limited time in that speech I failed to mention the people involved in BABI who are carrying on the good fight against this modern social disease. I wish to take a moment to place acknowledgment of their fine work on the public record. Alan Prisley is the dynamic coordinator of BABI and Claude Huddy, a personal friend of mine and a Commonwealth Employment Service manager, is president of the management committee. Vice-President of the management committee is Pat Jefferies and the secretary is Zillah Bunn, the well-respected and long-serving senior mistress of the Wynnum High School, also in my electorate. The treasurer is Andy McIntyre, with other committee members being June Harrison, Kath McLean, Alan Prisley, David Rolls and Maureen Cooper.

BABI has three hard-working and compassionate social workers in the person of Mary Guenthroth, Beverley Griffiths and Louise Herrod. Robyn Pattison doubles as both a youth worker and office worker and complements the team effort that is central to the BABI spirit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I appreciate that we do have a wide-ranging debate, but this has no relevance at all to the Bill under discussion. I really think it is out of order.
—I accept the point raised by the honourable member, but the debate has been very wide ranging indeed. I feel that the honourable member for Bowman is in order.

—I thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I know that you are interested in these sorts of things. I am very sorry that the honourable member for Lowe takes such an attitude. I understand that he is the health spokesman for the Opposition. If he listens to this, he might learn something.

SPEECH.PARA: All these people deserve to be recognised for their work in this area and I am proud to be able to mention their names in this place. Without organisations such as BABI the Government's work in the health and community services area would fall short of what is demanded by society close to tearing at its seams.

Other groups in my electorate that do excellent work in the health and community area are BIN and WIN. BIN is the Bayside Interagency Network and WIN is the Wynnum Information Centre. The Bayside Interagency Network evolved out of community need during the mid-1980s. The organisation was formed to encourage all community groups in the bayside district to work together for the benefit of the area. It is now a subcommittee of the Wynnum-Manly and district committee on the ageing and BIN is made up of service clubs, government and community organisations. On last count, there were some 50 groups within the bayside area involved in BIN.

Meetings of BIN are always extremely well attended and there is a general feeling within the local community that BIN is a major success story. BIN's existence has made life easier for every group in the area. It has provided coordination among groups, which has reduced duplication of services, while at the same time enhancing limited resources by ready referal from one group to another when dealing with related matters.

BIN has produced a bayside resource manual which is an extremely valuable document. It contains information and contact numbers on all emergency services, Aboriginal services, advocacy services, aged services and information on accommodation, alcohol, drugs and gambling. It also contains information on bereavement, child-care, churches, counselling and disabled persons services. Education, employment, health care, home care, hospitals and essential services are covered. Legal assistance, migrant services, mental health, prisoner services and self-help therapy groups are listed in detail. Information on senior citizens, social and community groups, veterinary services, welfare assistance, women's groups and youth services conclude a resource document that has proved to be of immense value to people who live in my electorate. With these sorts of services there is a great saving to government and to government departments because there is so much volunteer work being done. Surely that has something to do with appropriation debates, although indirectly.

BIN is not restricting itself to a coordinating role alone. Moves are under way to establish a crisis shelter for 10- to 17-year-olds who are in desperate need for overnight accommodation. There are many other ideas in the melting pot which can do nothing but benefit the bayside area of my electorate.

The executive of BIN needs to be congratulated on its fine work. Cathy Bavage from Wynnum family day care is a hard-working chairperson. David Jones from community corrections is the treasurer and Julie Christensen, my own electorate secretary, is the secretary of BIN. Other members of the committee are: Marie Lynham from the Department of Family Services; Pam Loynes from my own Department, the Department of Social Security; Marie Stokes, whose wonderful work I have placed on record previously in this place; Theo Gard, who has done magnificent work with the disadvantaged youth at the pioneer centre; and last but not least, Clive Ayre, minister of the local Uniting Church.

I have already stated that the Bayside Interagency Network is a subcommittee of the Wynnum-Manly and district committee on the ageing, but there is another organisation within BIN that is quickly growing in importance and finding its place within the growing web of support systems that do such a wonderful job in my electorate. In 1988 BIN conducted a survey to ascertain the developing needs of the bayside community. One of the identifying needs was that an information centre, or citizens advice bureau, be opened in the district to allow access of information to residents. The information centre was trialled on a one day a week basis at the Church of England hall, but it soon became obvious, through demand, that the service needed to be extended and be available on a daily basis.

To this end the committee, which is now officially known as the Wynnum Information Centre Committee, approached the Brisbane City Council for the use of one of the shops in the civic centre in Wynnum central. This was recently approved by the council, a council which, I might add, Mr Deputy Speaker-and you would know about this-has had dramatic changes of fortune over the past weeks. People power it seems is alive and well at least in the State of Queensland, even though our place on the wheel of political fortune always seems to be at odds with what is happening in the rest of Australia.

One thing is for sure-over recent years Queenslanders have become very discerning in many ways and quite shrewd in developing ways of getting the funding dollar to stretch as far as possible. What BIN and the Wynnum Information Centre are doing is smart. The people who serve on both committees are intelligent and very committed to making life a little easier for those who find themselves at any kind of disadvantage due to the changing lifestyles of modern society.

The Wynnum Information Centre, which has a working committee comprising several of the BIN executive plus Dianne Bagnall and Pat Lewis representing the community, will provide information on a wide range of services in the bayside area. This will include sporting activities, places of interest, business services, community services, welfare agencies and entertainment venues. The Wynnum Information Centre requires only a few thousand dollars recurrent funding to cover day-to-day expenses. Most of that is raised through public donations, but the amount of good to the community that this money buys is way beyond a few thousand dollars.

I am proud of the way that both these organisations operate within my electorate. They do a marvellous job and do not simply wait around for government grants before they try to rectify problems encountered in the community. As members of the community they know that they have a responsibility to that community. These people do not sit in their armchairs complaining about how tough life is. They are out there doing something, helping people, supporting people and generally contributing towards the destiny of the area in which they live.

I am proud of the work that these people do in my electorate. They rarely seek the limelight. They are quiet achievers who meet obstacles every day in pursuit of their beliefs. But they do not give up; they persevere. I place on record in this place that the bayside community in my electorate would be a much worse place to live in if it were not for people like them.

I conclude by saying that in the health and community services area, this Government has an unequalled reputation. There is no doubt that we do care. But we need not only a government that cares, but also people in the communities themselves that care, and the organisations that I have mentioned in this debate are fine examples of that caring. Unlike those opposite, we place prime importance on the social, mental and physical health of all Australians. The problems faced in health are always challenging. We strive to overcome them. We strive to make life better, even in small ways, for as many people as we can who have chosen to live in this great country. We have to think positively and not be dragged down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the February 1991 Business Council of Australia summit on `Our Competitive Future', Professor Michael Porter of the Harvard Business School said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the capacity to innovate and improve over long periods of time in ways that are valued in foreign markets that determines competitiveness.

Honourable members will be aware that it is no longer good enough for any sector in Australia to set its standards of performance internally. Rather, we must endeavour to achieve international best practice in our work, our rates of taxation and our overall environment for business to operate in.

To this end, a brief examination of the relationship between Australia and our fifth largest trading partner, Taiwan, could give a lead and a guide as to the way in which Australia should change its policy direction in the next two decades. Australia and Taiwan have populations of 17 1/2 million and 20 million people respectively, but Taiwan's population density per square kilometre is 100 times greater. Therefore, pressure is placed on the landmass and environment in Taiwan to a degree unknown in Australia.

Our Asian neighbour has made great progress over the past 40 years. From an agriculturally based economy in 1950, it has developed to become a major exporter of technologically sophisticated electronics and plastics as well as textiles and footwear. The growth in exports of personal computers over the past few years provides a good example of how the Taiwanese have raised their productivity and their technical efficiency.

The balance of trade between our two nations is difficult to assess because of the widely differing methods of calculation, but it appears that Australia accounts for about 3 per cent of Taiwan's imports and 2 per cent of Taiwan's exports. Australia's growth rate in the two-way trade of 17 per cent per annum, however, is not enough for us to keep pace with other nations trading with Taiwan. At the present time, unfortunately, we are only of marginal importance in this part of East Asia, at least when compared to Japan and the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are teaching us a lot.

—Yes they are, as the honourable member for Lyne says. Nevertheless, it is possible to open the window of opportunity. Our goal is to increase the proportion of our trade with the four tigers-Taiwan, South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong. These rapidly developing industrialised countries are creating the wealth and capacity to trade with Australia, which is mutually beneficial to both parties. Australia is rich in natural resources, and the four tigers have big populations with an increasing consumer potential which has a capacity to pay for Australian products which are predominantly agricultural and mineral.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government claims to place great store on our economic performance. Yet Australia has severe structural problems including a centralised wage fixing system, a transport infrastructure that performs at levels below that of other nations and high unemployment, at 9.2 per cent of the work force. Inflation in Australia, whilst declining from the 6.2 per cent as forecast by the Treasurer (Mr Keating), is still high by Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development standards.

By contrast Taiwan has managed to contain inflation below 3 per cent for much of the 1980s. Although inflation has since risen to almost 6 per cent, the Taiwanese gross domestic product increased by 5.5 per cent in 1990. In 1990-91 Australia's growth in gross domestic product is forecast at a mere 1.9 per cent-a very interesting comparison compared to Taiwan's tremendous progress. All this is from a country which started out with few resources 40 years ago.

The persistent surpluses gathered each year in Taiwan have facilitated structural change and the more efficient use of resources. This is largely due to the Taiwanese Government encouraging the private sector to continually innovate and export. It recognises that economic growth will achieve an increase in living standards.

By contrast the Australian Government has been forced continually to revise downwards its original prediction of a $8 billion surplus in 1990-91 because of `the recession we had to have', which has reduced the revenue and increased expenditure, especially for those unfortunate unemployed Australians who have had to bear the brunt of the Treasurer's high interest rate policy. The Opposition believes that the experiences of Taiwan over the past few years could become an example of economic progress for Australia to emulate.

Taiwan has fostered a climate in which people know that it is absolutely essential to foster an export culture. Its people vigorously pursue goals of international competitiveness, specialisation, efficiency and economies of scale to bring about the creation of greater national wealth which, in turn, improves individual standards of living in Taiwan.

Of course, Taiwan is not alone in this. The other three tigers of the region-Singapore, South Korea and Hong Kong-have a similar reputation. Taiwan's people recognise that they must be world class in every area of endeavour. Barriers to some of their exports, such as clothing and footwear, have been overcome by sheer persistence. Their exporters have followed a quality first policy.

There is, understandably, much concern in the Australian community about the levels of protection afforded by other nations to their producers. Taiwan continues to protect its agricultural commodities, but the level of protection is about to be reduced from 26 per cent to 18 per cent.

Dr Ross Garnaut's report clearly indicated that the freeing up of world trade would be in every nation's interest in making more goods and services available at lower costs, thereby increasing standards of living in the world. Since 1947 the average tariff on manufactured goods throughout the world has fallen from 40 per cent to about 5 per cent in 1990. As a result of trade liberalisation, the volume of world trade has expanded over that period by an incredible 500 per cent.

It is worthy of note that the economies which have grown the slowest through the 1980s, such as those of Latin America and Africa, believe in high levels of protection. Australia's average level of protection remains at about 12 per cent. This compares unfavourably with Japan's average level of tariff protection of 2.4 per cent. The United States of America is 3.5 per cent, with Germany being only 1.3 per cent. It is worth noting that there is virtually no protection in Hong Kong and Singapore. These countries have achieved rapid rates of economic growth because of their positive attitudes towards exports and by competing on world markets in terms of quality and price.

Economic growth is further encouraged in Taiwan by keeping taxation rates relatively low. Income tax on average weekly earnings is typically around 8 per cent for the single worker in Taiwan as against 22 per cent in Australia. Of course, a value added tax of 5 per cent is also struck in Taiwan but other taxes are broadly similar to Australia, being levied at three levels of government, such as ours. The lower tax rates in Taiwan provide an incentive to work.

Taiwan's broadly based consumption tax encourages national savings. This is demonstrated by one in four Taiwanese investing directly in their own share market. Only one in 10 Australians invest directly in the Australian share market-a very invidious comparison between the two nations' attitude towards investment and their capacity to make this investment. Not only are taxation rates lower for individuals, company tax rates are also less onerous, with the highest rate in Taiwan being about 25 per cent. Tax holidays of up to five years for productive enterprises are also granted. This concession covers a wide spectrum of industries, from agricultural to transportation. These tax rates give an incentive for companies to invest in Taiwan, which encourages its growth and makes it more internationally competitive.

The Taiwanese have managed to foster a work ethic which has resulted in rapid growth in the gross national product to about $US7,990 per capita in the year to December 1990. This has facilitated improvements in education, health and transport.

As with all economies, there are some down sides in Taiwan. In particular, the pressures of a high population and the desire to industrialise have led to the problems of pollution due to emissions from factories. Taiwan cannot afford the problem of acid rain that has caused so many difficulties in Europe. These troubles are now being addressed by the adoption of the `polluter pays' principle. It is worthy of note that the environmental lobby in Australia has opposed this concept even as it steadily finds favour in other countries around the world. I commend to the House the principle of giving the user incentives to minimise pollution.

Under the current Taiwanese six-year plan, $US110 billion is to be spent on public infrastructure projects-principally transportation and electricity generation. This represents a large increase on the levels of spending in this area over recent years. Taiwan's spending will be targeted to increase national wealth producing capacity.

In the Australian of 1 May, the Labor left wing made a plea for increased public spending in areas such as public housing. The difference between Australia and Taiwan is that Australia has a net foreign debt of $130 billion. More housing being created in Australia will not make it more competitive on an international basis. The Taiwanese know that they must live within their means. It is not for nothing that they have built up the world's second highest foreign exchange reserves of $A90 billion.

In another place, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) takes pride in the Australian Government's relations with other countries. In a speech to the Hong Kong Foreign Correspondents Club on 22 April 1991, the Minister said:
We have been conducting an energetic, independent foreign policy in the region . . . built around, but not confined to, some high profile initiatives like Asia Pacific economic co-operation.

Yet it was the Opposition, for instance, that proposed well in advance of the Government's recent announcement that the Far East Trading Co. be granted permission to call itself the Taipei Trade and Cultural Office. This name change more truly reflected the role of this organisation in fostering links between our two nations.

The Opposition has also long called for the commencement of direct air links between Taiwan and Australia. I am pleased to see that progress is finally being made in this area. It must, however, be of concern that Canada has a start of a number of months over Australia as direct flights between Taipei and Vancouver commenced in January. Of course, Canada beating us to the gun is nothing new. A possible area of export revenue for Australia to Taiwan is uranium sales, with nuclear power supplying just under half of Taiwan's electricity requirements. Canada recognises that, with appropriate safeguards in place, the export of uranium is desirable and has therefore secured 30 per cent of the world market despite having only 10 per cent of known world reserves.

The Australian Government, beholden to a deeply-held but outdated creed, as yet has been unable to abandon its three-mines policy. Australia has 30 per cent of the world reserves, yet only 10 per cent of the sales-a remarkable comparison with the Canadian situation.

Indeed, the Industry Commission in its recent report, Mining and Minerals Processing in Australia, has recommended that the three-mines uranium policy be abandoned. I note that the Australian Labor Party annual conference will be having a look at that. We will be interested to see the debates that take place between the left wing and some of the more rational members of the Government in trying to come to grips with the remarkable situation of the Government's three-mines policy. The Commission believes that the Government's intervention in the uranium industry should be limited to ensuring adequate safeguards with respect to the mining, processing, transporting and use of uranium.

The Opposition believes that the intention of the Taiwan Power Co. to spend $10m on a feasibility study into a joint coalmining venture in the Hunter Valley is to be applauded. Our comparative advantage lies in industries such as mining and agriculture, although that is not to discourage downstream processing in Australia which will add export dollars. The Opposition is nevertheless concerned that Taiwan and Australia have such little apparent interest in investing in each other's economies. The latest available figures indicate that the Taiwanese investment in Australia stands at $150m, with Australian investment in Taiwan being $133m. Even if the Taiwan Power Co. project proceeds, investment by Taiwan in Australia will be only about $400m.

The Opposition believes that the property and business sectors would benefit from an increase in these levels and that the growing internationalisation of economies means that we will find it much harder to stand alone. The Taiwanese, in liberating monetary controls and reducing protection have shown that they recognise this. We do, however, need to take a leaf out of their book and not only support, within reason, foreign investment, but also develop an export culture. Our share of output going to exports needs to rise further.

The reason that the Opposition has so strongly argued the case for micro-economic reform in Australia is that, unless our ports, land transport systems and industrial relations practices are modified, we shall indeed be overtaken by Taiwan in terms of gross domestic product per capita by the year 2,000, as predicted by the head of economics at Singapore University.

As an optimist, I believe Australians can rise to the challenge, but we need the Government to show the lead. The Hewson government will address these issues and provide the leadership and example to reinvigorate Australia. The Hewson government will change Australian attitudes to reverse Australia's decline to a Third World country.

The example of Taiwan is one worthy of study. Only with radical changes to industrial relations, micro-economic reform as it affects Australian industry, and the introduction of a broadly based consumption tax will Australia begin to compete with our Asian neighbours, such as Taiwan.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriations that I wish to speak to today concern the Department of Employment, Education and Training. In particular, I refer to the further $12.9m for trade training and the additional $28.7m for Austudy, which reflect an increase in the number of students in our higher education institutions and also the higher retention rates in our secondary schools.

SPEECH.PARA: If we are to be really fair dinkum about our whole education system and about getting value from those appropriations, and indeed all appropriations for education, employment and training, we need to be begin at the beginning. A sensible person driving a car along a road when the oil light comes on will stop at the nearest garage and top up. Sensible people do not wait until the engine seizes up. Why? It is pretty simple-it is cheaper. It is using one's commonsense because it is more effective to apply preventative measures.

The nation's approach to the investment in human capital-a rather cold term, but referring to investment in education-should be no different. In the March industry statement, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made several fundamental statements concerning our education system and he announced the good schools strategy, the foundation block for all further education success. The Prime Minister made three fundamental comments, which I will quote. The first comment reads:
If we get the basics right in these critical years we need not set limits on our prospects.
Secondly, he states:

Quite simply, unless we give our young people the motivation and the opportunity to bring out the best in themselves through education, we shall never be able to bring out the best in ourselves as a nation.
And we will never become a tiger anywhere, let alone Asia. Lastly, he says:
The foundation of a clever country is its education system.

The Hawke Labor Government's cooperative efforts with the States and Territories in school education over the past four years has focused upon curriculum, quality of teaching, duplication and resource issues-a synthesis, rather than an analytical approach. The good schools strategy moves the search for excellence and best practice in our schools into the actual schools themselves. It is the first time any government in this nation has focused education into the big picture, better described as `good schooling' rather than `good schools'.

In the Times Educational Supplement in April 1986, the findings of a major British four-year longitudinal education study on good schooling was published. Its findings are most pertinent to Australia. The study found that more than any other factor, the single most powerful determinant of a person's future success was the quality of schooling received by children between the ages of seven and 11. It found that the quality of schooling was far more important than a child's race, religion, gender, or ethnic or socio-economic background.

The good schools strategy announced on 12 March allocated a sum of $10.5m over the next three years to involve people at the chalkface-school principals, parents, teachers and the local community-in identifying what constitutes a good school. Unfortunately, I did not read anywhere any reference to the most important group of all-the children themselves, some six or seven million of them in our total population of 17 million. The strategy, agreed to in principle by State and Territory education Ministers, will be all about identifying best practice, organisation and structure in the nation's 10,000 schools.

The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) has indicated that those Australians directly involved in school education are best placed to identify best practice. I could not agree more. The Minister has also acknowledged that there are many factors that contribute to making a school outstanding, from the dedication of principals and teachers to the way a school is organised, to the involvement of school councils.

As part of the good schools strategy, once best practice has been identified its application will be promoted in other schools across the nation. The primary goal-and let us remember that word primary-is to improve the quality of education in all schools by identifying excellence in individual school communities.

As part of the strategy, the Government intends to use international Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development research and experience. But if we are to be truly internationally competitive, we will need to assume international leadership and establish our schools as the world's best. As such, we need to have the confidence to develop our own uniquely Australian way.

The basic foundation in our education system is our primary school, a basic fact ignored by many educational bureaucrats in this country. Without doubt, that is where the good schooling strategy should begin. Also without doubt, the best teaching practice is in our primary schools. It certainly will not be found in academia, where often the quality of teaching leaves a lot to be desired.

The good schooling strategy should begin where our schools' practices are strongest-in our primary schools. Certainly, higher education, technical and further education and secondary schools have significantly more resources, but that is often where the strength stops. I recently asked a school principal to ask the children in her school, first, what they thought a good school was and, secondly, what they would learn in a good school. Basically, the first question I asked was wrong because it was about a good school rather than good schooling. When asked what would happen in a perfect school, the kids said quite interesting things.

The kids said that in a good school they would learn new things that they did not already know. They would not choose the easy things to learn but would try to learn something that they did not know and go over it with a teacher. They wanted to learn new things every day because they felt that the more they learnt, the cleverer they would be. The bright kids would teach the less bright. Teachers would understand kids' problems and would listen to and care about them. The perfect school would have many children in a classroom, with three or four teachers.

I appreciate that some of those comments may, in fact, be what children think adults want to hear, but the major thrust of what they are saying is pretty clear. These kids, aged five to 11, think that education should be a cooperative venture, which should be exciting, inventive and an exploration of alternatives and possibilities. They think that it should affirm high quality relationships between the participants and that education excellence takes place in an environment that stimulates. They think that education requires high teacher morale and that education is more successful when influenced by groups of teachers rather than individuals. Any school that stated its philosophy in those terms would certainly at least have an idea of the direction in which good schooling would go. The direction, we note, is stated by the most important people in the schooling process, the kids themselves.

Taking the lead from those children, what is good schooling? Good schooling operates within the parameters of several frameworks, but I believe it can be described in very simple terms and those simple terms are best formed by asking questions. Why educate? What does one educate? How does one educate? When does one educate? With whom does one educate? For whom does one educate? With what does one educate? How does one measure the success of education, and what does one do then? The translation of those simple questions can accommodate anything and everything that does and should happen in good schooling in just six major considerations. Why? Obviously a set of beliefs, a rationale, a philosophy, a policy. With and for whom? Relationships, personnel. What, how and when? Curriculum, programs, scheduling, methodology. With what? Resources, organisation, procedures. Measure of success? Assessment, reconciliation of educational theory and practice. What then? Evaluation and future planning.

What those children were saying is a pretty sound basis for a primary school or, indeed, any sector of education. Remember what they were saying. They were saying education is a cooperative venture; education is the impact of mind upon mind; education is the exploration of alternatives; and education is a `you and me' relationship. The children quite clearly said that education is a people business and that the quality of the relationships developed between teachers, parents and children largely determine the success or otherwise of good schooling. The kids were also pretty clear that they needed to be influenced by more than just one teacher; in fact, they were suggesting three or four. The kids know that a mix of different teachers will be more successful.

The following is my interpretation, but if I went back to those kids I am pretty confident they would not disagree. Kids know intuitively that groups possessing different people roles will work more successfully than individuals. Kids know intuitively that they will need different kinds of people to guide their education. They need a mix of the roles of ideas, process and task people. This does not mean that one can simply categorise people into one or the other. It means that in certain circumstances and dependent upon motivation, commitment, interest and expertise, people will tend to play more of one role than another. Of course, one role is not intrinsically more important than another.

Good schools will have ideas people who have the ability to recognise, receive and create ideas. Good schools will have process people who possess the ability to devise with others appropriate means to implement ideas. Good schools will have task people who possess the ability to persevere and commit themselves to carrying out the idea and the process.

Ideas people are essential to good schooling. They provide the vision and the direction. When ideas are first mooted, they are not always clearly stated or understood by others. This is often a root cause of conflict and ideas and task people often clash. This place is a splendid example of that. The necessary process and understanding is not always clear to either group. Ideas people have short fuses and they show it. They dream, they love to argue ideas. They do not personalise things. Task people, on the other hand, often personalise those ideas without fully understanding the reasons why.

Process people are essential to good schooling. They provide the means to implement ideas successfully. They restate and rework the idea with others into a more acceptable and understood form without losing the intent of the idea. They need to be extremely sensitive to others and skilled in group dynamics. They are often caring, patient and good listeners. They can get frustrated, but seldom show it. They practise and love to be involved with others. They bridge the often very large gap between the thinking of ideas and task people.

Task people are also essential to good schooling. They implement ideas and processes. They plan, organise, complete and review work. They are achievers and are often impatient. They, too, have a short fuse but they seldom show it. They love to succeed individually.

Good schools will be made up of personnel that have all of those roles, but kids need to be influenced by all three roles, not just one on a year at a time basis, as most of our schools are organised. If the preferred ideas, processes and tasks of individuals can be identified within the school and the differences understood, the school or, indeed, any organisation, even this place, has the potential to capitalise on the skills and talents that are available. If one does not know where one is going and why, with whom one is going and how, one will more than likely end up somewhere else. The pity of all that is that one probably will not realise it.

Good schooling will be judged by many criteria, some pertinent, some not. However, the most important criterion is the quality of educational programs that are offered to students. The kids know that for educational programs to be successful they need the input of groups of teachers. The kids know that no matter how good or popular a teacher is, there are no teachers in the world who possess the skills, talents and interests to cope with a primary school curriculum.

In a primary school, good schooling will often have a `broad fields' approach to curriculum. There may be four, five, six or seven areas. I will give four as an example. I point out the following example just to show how silly, illogical and impossible the expectations placed upon teachers are in the foundation years of our education system. In a broad fields approach to curriculum there would probably be about four major subject areas: language arts, mathematics, environmental studies, and expressive arts. Remember when kids said they would like more than one teacher? In all the 25 years I was involved in education I never saw one teacher who was capable in all four areas. Most teachers had expertise in one area; quite often in two areas; very, very seldom in three areas; but never in four areas. Basically, all our primary schools are organised with one teacher and 30 children, year in, year out. I do not think it is terribly difficult actually to prove that teachers are seldom good at more than two subject areas.

Let us take the most important area-language arts. It includes reading, writing, listening, speaking, handwriting, spelling, poetry, library skills, literature-in other words, all forms of communication. There are two major aspects involved in communication-the processes of transmitting and receiving. Essential transmission skills that give messages are speaking and writing. Essential receiving skills to receive messages are listening and reading. The prime function of a language arts program-literacy-is to give children the skills to relate to others and to understand all the reasons for the messages given or received, be they in a verbal, written or non-verbal form. Obviously, a language arts program would be enhanced by the study of a foreign or community language. We have one million people in this country who are functionally illiterate at an adult level. Something has gone wrong somewhere.

Mathematics in a primary school includes number and space, measurement, problem solving, geometry, logic, graphing, money, and keyboard skills. There are two major aspects of mathematics. They can be loosely described as order and spirit. Order is the knowledge of tables and computational skills in addition, subtraction, division and multiplication, and order assumes some sort of sequence. Unfortunately, in many of our schools that is where mathematics, or more accurately arithmetic, begins and stops. Remember the kids again? They want new stuff, excitement and challenge.

Spirit in mathematics is thinking, logic, curiosity, and problem solving, and spirit does not necessarily assume sequence. Some skills are not necessarily prerequisite to others. Most teachers in primary schools cope with the order, but only a few even recognise the spirit. Some children need order to find the spirit. Some children need spirit to find the order, and some children need differing proportions of both.

In a primary school, the subject of environmental studies includes history, geography, social studies, health, science, Aboriginal studies and religious education. The framework for environmental studies can be seen as a never-ending series of concentric circles, each one adding more understanding of the world in which we all live.

The fourth area, an expressive arts program, includes music, physical education, arts, crafts, drama and dance. Expressive arts is the living interpretation of people's past, contemporary and future life. They are studies of the developing skills of all the active, the seen, the heard, the thought and the felt in our senses. Expressive arts is an area much misunderstood, often undervalued and, broadly speaking, done very badly in the majority of our primary schools. Done well, the expressive arts program actually strengthens academic areas.

The reason that I point out the wide diversity of the primary school curriculum is that there is an assumption in our society from parents, teachers, principals and bureaucrats that the deployment of one teacher and 30 kids on a yearly basis is a pretty sound organisational practice. The allocation of one teacher each year never has and never will cope with the diversity of modern curriculum demands, yet it remains the basic organisational practice in nearly all our primary schools. Why? It has never worked. It does not work. Please do not think I am having a go at primary school teachers because nothing could be further from the truth. They are, by the proverbial country mile, the best teachers in the nation.

If we are really serious about being internationally competitive, they need to be the best teachers in the world and they need to be operative at the beginning of the formal education system-in the primary school. It is impossible for a primary school teacher to implement a total educational program, let alone all the other factors, to fulfil the expectations put on them. No individual primary school teacher can cope with the demands of an educational program that effectively implements for kids language arts, mathematics, environmental studies and expressive arts. When will we all stop kidding ourselves?

In conclusion, I acknowledge that I have only scratched the surface of the good schooling strategy. It has come from the most important group in the education process, the kids themselves. Obviously there are many other areas to be considered by the good schooling strategy, for instance, the quality of teacher training. Who in fact teaches the teachers? I applaud the Government on this initiative. But for this project to be successful, at least the following three factors will need to be taken into account: we should involve the children; we should be talking about good schooling, not just good schools; and we should begin with the nation's best schools, our primary schools, and start from a position of strength, not weakness. The good schooling strategy provides an opportunity for the nation to really test its commitment to long term structural change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —While the Appropriation Bill (No. 4), the Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) cover many areas of government funding, I wish to deal today with funding for road transport infrastructure in tied and untied grants to the States for road maintenance, road upgrading and provision of new national highways and arterial roads. I note in the House that $32m is to be appropriated for payment to the bankrupt State of Victoria in lieu of petroleum royalties. The Hawke-Keating, Keating-Hawke, Keating-Keating Labor Government has an appalling record on road funding.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last decade since the Australian Labor Party came to power, spending on roads throughout this nation, which is so dependent on a good road network, has been effectively cut in real terms by 30 per cent. The people of this nation are fed up with paying increased fuel excise without the corresponding increase in improved condition of the roads they use. In the last coalition Budget of 1982-83, 88 per cent of fuel excise revenue was spent on roads. Today it is a paltry 26.8 per cent. The people of Australia are being ripped off by a government that is taking more and more in fuel excise revenue and spending less and less of that excise on roads for which the revenue is taken. It is not simply a case of user pays; rather, the motorist pays and pays for roads that do not eventuate.

Not only has this Federal Government much to answer for in terms of letting our road transport infrastructure run down, but so also does our State Labor Government in the destitute State of Victoria for both decreased road funding and for using the road funding issue for pork-barrelling during State election campaigns. A major municipality within my electorate of La Trobe is the city of Berwick, which I point out to honourable members is the fastest growing municipality in the State of Victoria. This growth has not just been a natural occurrence; it has been encouraged by State Government planning which has set aside for urban development large tracts of what was rural agricultural land.

Additionally, the State Government has purchased substantial hectares within the city of Berwick confines for development of a combination of low cost public and private housing. The growth, therefore, within the city of Berwick is, to a very large extent, driven by government planning processes and that growth is rapidly turning what was once a sleepy rural community into another largely dormitory suburb to the south-east of the major centre of Melbourne.

In order to put the issues which I intend to raise regarding roads within the city of Berwick, it is important to state clearly that since Berwick became a city in its own right in October 1973 the city administration has been known throughout the State of Victoria-indeed, I would trust, throughout Australia-as an administration of great competence and excellence. Many of the councillors of that city since formation have also been of very high quality and have included many forward thinking individuals.

The scene that I am setting is that of a municipality with excellent administration and good councillors representing a broad section of community interests and concern. Berwick has approached its role in the local community in a very balanced manner, addressing in a modern way the needs of the community for capital infrastructure, for community facilities including sport and roads, and at the same time addressing many of the social needs of the city's rapidly expanding population. Berwick's financial management has been excellent and programs are diverse and are seen to be meeting community needs.

Berwick's founding city engineer, Mr Max Pawsey, showed exceptional foresight and engineering competence. In the very early years of the newly formed city, his efforts towards developing local planning, as well as encouraging initial State Government planning for the growth that he could see would inevitably occur, have been significant factors with respect to the availability of public land within the city to cater for spectacular growth. However, Mr Pawsey's insistence that roads within the city, particularly roads running east-west, would in the future become a tremendous bottleneck was to some extent unheeded. Today we are starting to pay the price. There are only two significant east-west roads through the municipality. They are Heatherton Road, which is a minor road in the northern and less populated area of the municipality, and Princes Highway, which is a major feeder road to the entire south-east of Victoria, including Gippsland and the La Trobe Valley.

Both the Victorian and Federal governments have realised that Princes Highway, as the major artery through the south-east, required major upgrading in order to bypass many small towns which acted to dramatically slow through freight and private transport. Many hundreds of millions of dollars have been spent in bypassing towns such as Berwick Village, Pakenham, Morwell, et cetera.

At the beginning of Highway No. 1 we are producing within the city of Berwick an unbelievable bottleneck to through traffic by not linking the Mulgrave Freeway or south-eastern arterial, whatever honourable members want to call it, with that portion of Princes Highway which bypasses the village of Berwick and then continues down to Gippsland. As Berwick expands, access roads continue to be built to feed on to Princes Highway for both new freight from new industrial development to the south of Princes Highway, as well as private motor vehicles. Increasing traffic is exacerbated through both housing and industrial development. Any person who travels on our roads knows the major impediment to traffic flows caused by traffic lights and the chaos that frequently occurs through start-stop traffic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 101a. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The honourable member for La Trobe will have leave to continue his speech when the debate is resumed.

—Yesterday during Question Time the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) asked whether I would table documents in relation to one question asked by himself and one asked by the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello). I said that I would seek advice. I now table the documents in question.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Like most people in this building, I watched his press conference this morning and his struggle and failure to defend the totally untenable position of his Government in relation to Ambassador Brian Burke. How on earth can he allow Brian Burke to remain as an ambassador for another day?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I had on a number of occasions outlined the reasoning of the Government. I will go through it in the sequence which is relevant. In the first place, of course, what the Leader of the Opposition wanted, screeched for, demanded in every conceivable way, is that on the basis of allegations before Mr Burke had appeared we should stand Mr Burke down. I gave my reasons then and have, on a number of occasions, asked whether the Leader of the Opposition would clarify his position on this matter. He never has.

ANSWER.PARA: I said that, as far as this Government was concerned, it was no principle of this Government that the mere making of allegations was sufficient to stand down a person from public office. I have asked the Leader of the Opposition on a number of occasions to state unequivocally whether that is his position. We are still awaiting the reply from the Leader of the Opposition.

In regard to the events which have succeeded that, I have made it clear in this place-and I made it clear again in the press conference to which the Leader of the Opposition refers-that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans, has at all points in this matter sought and acted upon advice from his Department.

The advice of that Department has been that, while certain actions of the ambassador have been unwise and improper, the advice as of today still stands: nothing at this point has been revealed which would require the ambassador to be stood down. The Minister has acted on that advice and I have supported the Minister in that respect.

May I finally say that on this matter of standards there is an enormous degree of hypocrisy on the part of the parties opposite. It goes to the question of royal commissions. I remind this House that on 12 September 1981 letters patent were issued to Mr Justice Woodward to inquire into the Australian meat industry. Specific areas of inquiry were included in those terms of reference, and I quote:
Whether such allegations were dealt with in a manner that was adequate and effective.

So the Government of the Liberal and National parties set up a royal commission with a specific term of reference as to whether such allegations were dealt with in a manner that was adequate and effective. The royal commissioner presented his report on 17 October 1982, and this is what the royal commissioner found in regard to that specific term of reference which had been laid down by the Government for the royal commissioner to inquire into:
I am bound to record my view that the Minister did not deal with these allegations adequately and effectively.
So there is a specific term of reference: was it dealt with adequately and effectively? There was a specific finding by the royal commissioner that it was not so done.
The Minister tendered his resignation. What was the attitude of honourable members opposite? They attacked the royal commissioner. Indeed, the Prime Minister at the time, Mr Fraser, said:
Some aspects of that report make me very, very angry indeed.
He went on to be critical of the adverse finding concerning Nixon. In Parliament on 21 September he said:
I cannot accept that the one adverse finding against the Minister has been substantiated. I unequivocally reject it.

Here we have Opposition members on this occasion saying in regard to a mere allegation or statement that the man involved should be dismissed, but when they were in government they set up a royal commission to investigate on a particular term of reference, there was a specific finding from the royal commissioner that that term of reference led to the conclusion that the Minister did not meet the standards required, and what did they do? They attacked the royal commissioner and rejected the proposition in the finding from the royal commissioner. So honourable members opposite should not suggest in this place or outside it that they have some standard of propriety which is beyond criticism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for O'Connor!

—That was probably the first time in the history of this Parliament when a government has set up a royal commission to examine the conduct of one of its Ministers on a specific term of reference, when a royal commissioner found against the Minister, and when the government then attacked the royal commission for the finding. So honourable members opposite should not stand up here and suggest that they have some standards of propriety. They have none. In the case under review, what the Minister, Senator Evans, has done is act with total propriety. He has sought at arm's length the advice of his Department and has acted upon it.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. I ask whether he is aware of an editorial in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald which describes the Government's decision to send an Australian Defence Force (ADF) relief team to northern Iraq to assist Kurdish refugees as misconceived generosity. Will our contribution have a marginal effect on the relief effort?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for her question. Her concern with the plight of those less fortunate than us is well known. I did see the editorial and I was somewhat taken aback by it because on Monday Senator Ray and I announced that the Australian Defence Force would be sending a specialist humanitarian aid team to northern Iraq to assist Kurdish refugees in the appalling conditions in which they are now living, and which I think we have all seen on television.

ANSWER.PARA: The team is designed to provide basic medical care, field hygiene and water purification facilities, with the cost of the initial deployment, which is over $3m, being met by the Department of Defence out of its existing resources. The decision to send that team was taken precisely because it will make a significant and material difference and contribution to the alleviation of suffering in the region. The article to which my colleague refers is correct in saying that the relief effort is being improvised daily, but that is why a small team of specially trained personnel will be so effective.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mayo!
—That team will be able to be deployed as required in the area and repositioned as the situation unfolds. It is not restricted to any particular area.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the most basic requirements of the refugees is clean water. There is an acute shortage of facilities to provide clean water, and such facilities are essential if we are going to prevent epidemics, escalating infant mortality and suffering on a tragic scale. The Sydney Morning Herald editorial made no mention of the water purification units, the field shower unit and the preventive medicine components of the team. We are providing that assistance because it is desperately needed. We also have some of the best technology in the world for purifying water in the field. The two water purification teams being sent can each provide 7,500 litres of purified water every hour from a thoroughly contaminated source. The field shower unit can shower 80 personnel an hour using water on a continuous basis.

I am pleased to say that since the decision was made we have been advised by our representatives abroad that the ADF presence has been enthusiastically received as `a considerable enhancement of our ability to provide humanitarian aid'. The composition of the team was described as being extremely good. The point is that our assistance is highly practical, guaranteed to meet the most pressing needs of the refugees and, along with other government initiatives, is precisely targeted. The potential for that aid to go astray is minimal. We needed to act quickly because every delay was being measured in deaths, diseases and human suffering.

I conclude by offering the observations of another newspaper from my home city which I believe much better reflects the standards by which this operation should be judged. The editorial in the Adelaide News of yesterday stated:

The ability to respond swiftly to an emergency, particularly in the provision of basic health and communications, is a test as worthy of an army as any battle and would provide maximum value for the defence tax dollar.
That is a statement with which I heartily concur.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Why did the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade say that he would have sacked Mr Burke had Mr Burke not first resigned if, as the Prime Minister insists and has insisted again today, the Department advised that Mr Burke had done nothing to justify his sacking?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has made his position on this quite clear at all points. There have been two considerations in the mind of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, and they were appropriately in his mind. One is that stream of events which involved allegations against Ambassador Burke. He, as I have done myself, has at all points said, in that respect, that the making of allegations was not something upon which the Ambassador should be displaced from his position. That remains a position of this side of the House. Unfortunately, it is not a position of principle which has been embraced, as it should be, by the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Also, the Minister has indicated throughout that he has had another concern as to whether the circumstances that would develop would be such that, in a physical sense, they would almost prevent Mr Burke from being able to carry out his duties. The Minister made his comments in that respect. I repeat that at all times Senator Evans has made it clear that nothing--

TALK.START.PARA: —That he would have sacked Burke.
—That is not what he said at all.
—He said it.

—The honourable member is misquoting the senator. The fact is that he has made it clear at all points, up to and including today, that nothing has emerged on his consideration of this matter and on the advice of his Department-that the Department's advice remains valid is a point which has been confirmed by my office this morning with the Department-Senator Evans takes the same view as I do in that respect, that in these circumstances the position that has been arrived at should stand: that is, that the Ambassador has, in fact, offered his resignation, that has been accepted and arrangements have been made accordingly. That is the position of Senator Evans and it is also mine.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Would the Minister advise the House of the progress of negotiations on the national benchmark salary for Australian teachers? Is the Minister aware of calls for an increase in teachers' salaries of up to 40 per cent? What would be the fiscal implications of such an increase? Can the Minister advise whether any of the States or Territories have agreed to such an increase?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Port Adelaide for his question and his continuing interest in this important area. I am delighted to advise the House that on 12 April the Ministers for education from the States and the Commonwealth, meeting as the Australian Education Council, agreed to a new benchmark salary for teachers of $38,000, which is the level to which teachers can expect to aspire within the normal promotional scale.

ANSWER.PARA: This represents a number of important developments as far as the teaching profession is concerned.
