In the first instance, it means that for the first time we have a national approach to the remuneration of teachers, and we have a national salary structure regardless of whether teachers work in a particular State or in the government system as opposed to the non-government system.

As well, we have set the scene for the introduction of a totally new provision within the teaching profession of the advanced skilled teacher. This means that the best teachers can aspire to far better salaries than they have become used to in recent times. Indeed, in some States teachers will be able to receive salaries 30 per cent in excess of the maximum salary to which they would have been entitled under the old arrangement. I think this gives long overdue recognition to the important place of teachers within our society and provides an opportunity for recruiting and holding some of our best people within the teaching profession.

It was therefore with some surprise that I noticed on 18 April, just a few days later, that the honourable member for Bennelong had decided to bungle his way into this area, proposing that teachers salaries should be increased across-the-board by 40 per cent according to, in his words, some strict new performance standards. This reveals either a degree of ignorance on the part of the honourable member or a degree of stupidity on his part which really defies imagination.

We have been engaged, for something in excess of a year, in painstakingly negotiating, not just with the States but also with the teachers union, a totally new approach to the remuneration of teachers which has, as I said, seen opportunities for increases of 30 per cent for the best teachers within Australia and at the same time the establishment of a national project on the quality of teaching and learning, which will not only go into questions of such things as teacher education but also go into areas such as the way in which schools work and the work practices within the schools to try to ensure there is a better way to provide for the education of the nation's children.

Of course, within this context the honourable member for Bennelong says there should be an across-the-board increase of 40 per cent. This means either an additional cost to the taxpayer of some $2.5 billion in terms of additional wage bills for education ministries within Australia or, as he would say, it should be paid within the existing budget for schools. In other words, as he said in one of his radio interviews:
You can always afford to pay someone 40 per cent more if they work 40 per cent harder and 40 per cent more effectively.

How on earth can one expect teachers to work 40 per cent harder unless one intends to increase class sizes by 40 per cent? In other words, the honourable member for Bennelong is advocating that in this country class sizes should increase from, say, 30 to something like 42. This is the way in which he intends to do something about improving the moral of the teaching profession and improving the quality of education within the education system. This demonstrates more clearly than ever that once again we have a party in opposition which not only has no education policy, because all we know from the Opposition in relation to government schools is that basically it wants to get out of that area, but also has no wages policy.

The Opposition has no conception of the way in which one can bring about improvements in the wages and salaries of the Australian work force in the context of trying to improve the way in which the job is done. We just have this glib and totally destructive suggestion from the Opposition that if one can force the work force into some changed conduct or behaviour, that is the way one is going to bring about the difficult process of reform. Let us just contrast this with what the Opposition was saying yesterday where in the context of--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker; the Minister is abusing Question Time by taking an inordinate period of time to answer the question. I ask that you direct the Minister to bring his answer to a close.
—The Minister is answering the question. He is within the Standing Orders.
—I invite the House--
—The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.

—and the people of Australia to contrast this approach with what the Opposition was saying yesterday when, in the context of 60 per cent increases in productivity on the wharves, the wage earners should receive nothing in return for a 60 per cent increase in productivity, yet in this case we have this sort of off the top of the head, half baked, ill conceived proposal from the man who would be the alternative Minister for Industrial Relations, proposing that there should be across the board increases for teachers of 40 per cent, totally ignoring the painstaking process that has already occurred with us and with the Teachers Union. It is a proposal which would either cost $2.5 billion extra or would involve increases in class sizes of about 40 per cent, taking average class sizes, say, to over 40 children. This is the kind of Opposition that the country has.
—Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. The Minister should go back to his tax accountant.

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor has adopted the practice of prefacing his points of order with rather rowdy interjections. He should cease doing so. Does the honourable member have a point of order?

—Yes, sir. I draw your attention again to standing order 145 on the question of relevance. I draw your attention to the precedents in this place set by Speaker Snedden which I raised yesterday. The Minister is carefully wasting time in this Parliament so that we cannot go on with the proper questioning of his links with the Burke Government. What we want you to do--

—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will resume his seat and I will rule on his point of order. The Minister is answering the question. The answer he is giving is relevant to the question. The Minister is in order.

—I will conclude on this point: the process of change within Australia, being a federation, relying as it does on cooperation between Federal and State governments, does require a great deal more attention to detail than the kind of headline grabbing approach for which the honourable member for Bennelong has become so renowned. In this area, where we are trying to do something about improving opportunities for all children, and trying to do that in a cooperative framework, it would be far better if he learnt what has been achieved, and what even some of his colleagues in the States, particularly in New South Wales, have been doing to cooperate with this process, rather than continuing with these half baked and ill considered proposals.

—My question, which is addressed to the Prime Minister, relates to the still serving Ambassador to Ireland. As Mr Burke is not currently required to give evidence to the Western Australian Royal Commission into Commercial Activities of Government and Other Matters and he still remains on the Commonwealth payroll, will the Prime Minister support Mr Burke's appearance before Senate Estimates Committee B to enable him to give his version of events surrounding the Dublin Embassy telephone accounts, Mr Burke's trip to Romania, and negotiations leading to the arrangement of an unprecedented ex gratia retirement pay-out of $28,000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would imagine that the question of whether or not Mr Burke appears before Senate Estimates Committee B is a matter for Senate Estimates Committee B and Mr Burke, not for me. But now that the honourable member has mentioned Senate Estimates Committee B, let me take this opportunity to make quite clear the misrepresentation involved in the question put to me by the honourable member for Mayo-as though Senator Evans had made some judgment that Mr Burke should be sacked in terms of impropriety or some such matter. I refer to what Senator Evans said on 1 May before Senate Estimates Committee B. It is quite clear what he is talking about. It appears at page--
—Yes, page B105. Senator Evans said:

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is an unfair question to the officers. I will describe my own state of mind. My own state of mind was that, after the weekend and a combination of circumstances that had developed over the weekend, by that time it was in the best interests of the Department and Australia's national interest abroad that there be a resignation in the decorous way that the resignation was in fact conducted, simply because it was manifestly going to be very difficult in purely physical terms for Mr Burke to devote the time necessary for the job; because the nature of the material that was out on the public record by then was such that it was unquestionably likely to generate a much greater degree of media attention in Dublin than had been the case previously, thus creating some difficulties in terms of that other criterion I mentioned in the Parliament some days earlier; and, generally, because any arrangement that involved an open-ended extension of special leave and so on to enable Mr Burke to stay in Australia to deal with these matters would have created, over time, an unsatisfactory situation in terms of the handling of the job in Dublin.

It is all very well to do it on a two-, three- or four-month basis with the charge d'affaires, but clearly it was important that the situation be resolved in a way that had a greater degree of clarity and certainty about it with a finite timeframe around it. For all those reasons, I formed the judgment by Monday that it was probably appropriate that this course be taken. For that reason, I responded favourably to the judgment the Department made that the resignation should be treated, in effect, similarly in terms of its consequences, as a termination. I think it was a proper judgment to make in those circumstances.
You therefore reached the stage that, if Mr Burke had not resigned, his contract would have been terminated and thus you would have been obliged to pay this sum of money.

I would not want to commit myself wholly to that proposition. I had reached the point at which that would have been an appropriate matter for consideration by the Government in the absence of a resignation.

TALK.START.PARA: —He said he should be sacked. That's what it says.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo has been asked not to interject before and he shall cease interjecting.

—It is a gross misrepresentation of both the statement by, and the state of mind of, Senator Evans. The proposition has been put that he should be sacked as though there was some reason for doing that in terms of illegality or improper conduct. Senator Evans spelt out with the utmost clarity that it was related to that strand of his thinking, to which I referred in my answer: that is, the question of the physical capacity to do the job.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. Has the Minister seen reports of serious health hazards caused by atmospheric pollution in western Sydney? What is the Minister's response to these concerns and what plans does the Minister have to address the need for increased attention to the problems of atmospheric pollution and health?
—Order! If the honourable member for O'Connor interjects again, I will name him.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Banks for his question and recognise in the question his concern for the people in the western suburbs, particularly his electorate. Because of the pollution in western Sydney his concern is shared by many other honourable members on this side of the House. I note also with concern the New South Wales Government's response, so-called, to the concerns that have been expressed by many thousands of people who are suffering as a result of this pollution. Claims have been made by Mr Moore, the New South Wales Minister for the Environment, that the pollution was due to unique seasonal factors. But, worse, Mr Peter Collins, the New South Wales Minister for Health, now claims that there is no link between Sydney's air pollution and asthma. That was clearly expressed in his press conference yesterday when he said:

ANSWER.PARA: The message must go out, that whatever problems may be caused by the pollution, and certainly nobody in Sydney would take any joy from the pollution we've suffered over the last couple of days-whatever those problems, they do not exacerbate asthma. I would have no hesitation as Health Minister to state that publicly . . . asthma is not related to pollution, it's related to other factors.

I do not think many people would really believe that. If Mr Greiner or Mr Collins need any more evidence of why they should take firm action, they should only heed the advice of their own Health Department. The deputy chief health officer of the Health Department of New South Wales, Dr Gavin Frost, said in March that high incidence of photochemical smog worsened chest infections, particularly over winter. He said it was worse for people who had chronic lung diseases such as asthma and bronchitis and as pollution worsened so did the effect on the lungs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you go down to New South Wales?
— Order! The honourable member for Mitchell.

—Only today there are reports of a study from the University of Birmingham where evidence shows a clear link between smog and respiratory diseases. It is not good enough for the New South Wales Government to say that it will do something after the election. The New South Wales Government has known for a long time that air pollution in Sydney's western suburbs is among the worst in Australia. That was clearly indicated in a leaked report from the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in March this year. That report recommended a major reassessment of housing development plans for the west and the south-west of Sydney.

ANSWER.PARA: That CSIRO report also clearly found that the State Pollution Control Commission had severely underestimated pollution levels for years. It is very clear that the real issue here is the inability of the New South Wales Government to address the design and make-up of our cities as well as the pollution levels. It is also now clear that the health status of families is affected by the design of our cities. What is needed is an integrated approach to build better cities. The basis of that approach is better data and better monitoring, particularly of environmental health indicators. In New South Wales we have to look more closely at the planning of housing, transport and employment needs to make this data work.

Mr Carr has demanded a halt to north-west development until the Greiner Government can actually tell the people what is the cost of pollution and what are the effects that it has on health. The New South Wales Government cannot even begin to make that assessment until it deals with the matter of underestimation of pollution control. There are four million people in Sydney who need more than empty promises of a meeting or summit after an election. They want action now.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Why does the Prime Minister refuse to treat Mr Brian Burke on the same terms as he would treat any other ambassador? Why did his Government agree to a request which the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade described as `unusual', `not in accord with traditional practice' and `impacting on the credibility of other ambassadors', when his Government gave approval for Mr Burke to go with Mr Lang Hancock's employee to deal with the late President Ceausescu in Romania? Did Mr Burke disclose to the Prime Minister's Government that he had received $400,000 from Mr Hancock in 1985? Would the Government have considered this material information to know in coming to its decision to allow Mr Burke to leave Ireland and go to Romania?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the second time in Question Time today in which we have had a totally misleading attempt by the Opposition to put in question the integrity of people who have made decisions according to appropriate criteria.
—Answer the question.

—We have just seen it in regard to the honourable member for Mayo. Now we have this selective quotation by the honourable member for Higgins. So that the House and the people of this nation will have the opportunity of understanding exactly what the consideration of the Department was in coming to the decision it did to authorise the visit to Romania by Mr Burke, I will read what it said in its totality, and not in this totally tendentious and misrepresentative way employed by the honourable member for Higgins. This is what it said, and I make no apology for reading it in its totality, because we have had this total misrepresentation by picking out a phrase here and there. I will read the whole of the report. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: The purpose of the document is to seek your decision on the proposal from the Hon. Brian Burke, Ambassador to Ireland and the Holy See, that he continues the involvement in matters relating to Australia's trade with eastern Europe where this is appropriate and desirable.

During his period as Premier of Western Australia Mr Burke gave considerable attention to developing that State's trade links with the countries of Eastern Europe. Mr Burke's close working relationship with Lang Hancock-

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh! Dear, oh dear! It continues:

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Burke's close working relationship with Lang Hancock and the effective working relations he developed with prominent political figures in Eastern Europe (including Romania's President) played an important-

TALK.START.PARA: —Go on, read the name. Read it all.
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.
—I go on:

ANSWER.PARA: We have now had revealed that at the time the President of Romania was President Ceausescu. What a remarkable thing! The report states, and this is what happened:
. . . played an important role in WA's success in developing markets in Romania, Czechoslovakia, Hungary and, potentially, the Soviet Union.
Is that not a terrible thing? This is what he had done-he had played an important role in Western Australia's success in developing markets in all those countries. It goes on:

* It has been essentially as a result of Mr Hancock's efforts that Australian exports to Romania have grown so rapidly in recent years and there are good prospects for substantial sales of iron ore to Czechoslovakia and Hungary as well. The Soviet Union has also been discussing possible involvement in the development and processing of iron ore and manganese deposits in WA.
- Mr Hancock has set up a company together with BHP, the Eastern Pilbara Iron Ore Company Pty Ltd, to service these potential markets.

* As you know, Mr Hancock has an aversion to the involvement of Government (Federal or State) in his business dealings. The fact that Mr Burke was an exception for Mr Hancock in this regard and Mr Burke's own policy of keeping the Federal Government informed of important developments in Western Australia's trade relations with Eastern Europe have been invaluable for this Department.
There is the assessment with regard to what had happened-it was invaluable for this Department. It states:

2. Mr Burke has expressed his interest in maintaining some involvement in Eastern European trade matters. He believes there could be occasions in the future when his past contacts could be helpful in promoting particular projects or commercial deals.

* He stresses that any such involvement would be infrequent (he anticipates travelling to Eastern Europe once or twice each year) and only in response to specific requests from commercial or other interests.

3. We consider that some form of ongoing involvement by Mr Burke in Eastern European trade matters could indeed prove beneficial. His contacts could help provide continued high-level access to decision-makers in those countries and it seems likely that Mr Hancock, in particular, would welcome it.
There is the positive, but what do we get quoted? The next bit, which states:
4. On the negative side, the arrangement would be unusual and not in accord with traditional diplomatic practice.
That is all we have had read. Paragraph 4 continues as follows:

Mr Burke is accredited as Ambassador to Ireland and The Holy See. There are other Australian Ambassadors accredited to Romania, Hungary, Czechoslovakia and the USSR who are responsible for the development of political and commercial relations with their countries of accreditation. Involvement of Mr Burke could impact on their credibility with host Governments. Should Mr Burke be involved, he could not be regarded as Ambassador but ``official of the Australian Government'' with all the implications of such status.
having put the positive, the negative follows-

that because of his past position Mr Burke could make a special contribution to Australia's trade with East Europe and that given the size of the potential trade involved this unusual arrangement would be justified, particularly since any visits to East Europe would be occasional and for very specific purposes.

5. In the interests of sound policy formulation, we would ask Mr Burke to clear with us and the relevant Australian Embassy in advance any proposed travel or other initiative. Any travel would be subject to funds being available and Commonwealth responsibility would be limited to travel by Mr Burke alone.
6. Mr Burke has sought approval to agree to a request from Mr Hancock that he join Mr Hancock in Geneva on 12 September for a meeting with Soviet representatives on various commercial prospects.

Unless you see any reasons against, that Mr Burke be advised that his proposal for his continued involvement in relevant trade matters relating to Eastern Europe and the USSR is acceptable, on the basis of the conditions listed above.
It then has the notation of the Minister as follows:

A difficult and sensitive one. Mr Burke rang me about this today. Agree on the basis proposed, and on the basis that our local reps are not only contacted for advance clearance, but also kept informed of progress of his activities and interests.

Mr Speaker, I suggest you could not have a more blatant example of the dishonesty-there is no other word which adequately describes it-the blatant dishonesty of those people who would get up and read from a balanced report, a balanced recommendation which, with a proper sense of responsibility, says, `Well, there are these arguments against doing it, there are these arguments in favour of doing it and, on balance, in the interests of this country, we agree that it should be done'. Such is the nature, the morality and the standards of those opposite that all they would do is read out the negatives. Their question and their tactics rebound upon them and reveal them for the dishonest bunch of crooks they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. I ask the Prime Minister to withdraw that remark.
—Order! The Prime Minister will withdraw that remark.

—I withdraw. The Opposition is not a dishonest bunch of crooks; I withdraw that remark. I simply say that Opposition members are incapable-and they have shown it twice in Question Time-of behaving with any standards of decency or morality.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. Today's editorial in the Australian claims that the recently launched study Juggling Time on unpaid work in the home is an unwarranted intrusion into Australian family life. Is this report accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fatin The Hon W.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I was disappointed this morning to see the editorial in today's Australian. Far from being an intrusion into couples' private lives, as is stated in the editorial, the Bittman research is consistent with our obligations under the International Labour Organisation (ILO) Convention 156, `Workers With Family Responsibilities'. Honourable members on the other side might groan, but it really is quite significant to a number of people and their lives.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia's ratification of ILO 156 came into effect on 30 March this year. Arising out of this ratification, Australia has a commitment to enable workers with family responsibilities who are employed or who wish to be employed to do so without discrimination and, as far as possible, without conflict with their family responsibilities. The study Juggling Time, which I launched in Sydney on Monday of this week, looks at the relationship between women's paid employment and their unpaid work in the home. One of its most significant findings is that women do 70 per cent of the unpaid work in the home and that, regardless of how many paid hours of work women do, men's contribution in the home remains the same. Also, when a woman marries, her workload increases by 60 per cent.

The editorial also criticises the practice of targeting prenatal classes to stimulate greater discussion and planning about working families sharing responsibilities. The study reveals that a new mother's hours of unpaid work increase by 91 per cent after the birth of her first child-that is, 56 hours per week-while, correspondingly, on average new fathers do not increase their workload at all. If that mother is in the work force, she begins to share that incredible load that comes upon her at that time.

It is particularly important that patterns of sharing are established at the time of the first child. The study is a small part of the Government's community education campaign aimed at encouraging greater opportunities for women and men to combine successfully family and work. In particular, the campaign focuses on the double load women workers with family responsibilities face due to the inequitable division of domestic labour. The education campaign aims for long term change. The Government supports and encourages the recognition of all unpaid work done in the home. We want the community to hear about different models of distribution of unpaid work. It wants to encourage sharing of household responsibilities.

The Government is looking at a wide range of measures to assist workers with family responsibilities. If we do not address the issue of women's double load, such pressures will take their toll by affecting the quality of family life, the health and well-being of women and their employment opportunities and social choices.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to a letter from the honourable member for Kalgoorlie urging voters in the Menzies by-election to vote against the Government's immigration policy. I also refer to recent media appearances by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie supporting the anti-migration candidate in that by-election. In the absence of an Australian Labor Party candidate will the Prime Minister, on behalf of his Government, repudiate this campaign stance by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie? Will the Prime Minister show some leadership, at least at this important policy level, and demand the expulsion of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie from the Labor Caucus?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that the call by the honourable member for Tangney for the expulsion of a member comes strangely from a party which is supposed to extol the principles of allowing some divergence of opinion within a party organisation. May I say-and I say this directly to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie-that I was deeply disappointed when I had brought to my attention within the last couple of days the letter which he sent out on this matter because he is saying that the policy of the Government in regard to immigration is something with which he disagrees. I am disappointed in that because I believe the immigration policy of the Government, both now and from the time it has been in office, is an appropriate one; I think it is a correct policy.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that in some discussion I will seek to have with the honourable member for Kalgoorlie I will be able to persuade him of the error of his assessment. I do not think that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie would claim that he is infal- lible. Some of my colleagues on the front bench doubt that. I have found that the honourable member for Kalgoorlie is capable of being persuaded to another point of view, and I will attempt to do it. As far as I am concerned, we are proud of the immigration policy that we have adopted.

Generally speaking, in regard to the area of immigration, with some exceptions that I would rather forget, there has been broadly a bipartisan position, which in this country is as it should be. In that regard, we have attempted since 1983, when we have had the responsibility for this important strand of decision making that affects not just now, but the very future fabric of our country, to blend into those decisions the appropriate considerations which go, as you know, Mr Speaker, to, firstly, what is the economic capacity of the country to absorb a given level of intake. That must always be a relevant consideration. We have taken that into account. Then the various elements are, as you know, Mr Speaker, the question of building up the skill levels in this country, the question of family reunion, the question of bringing in particular skills in the business area and, of course, always throughout the program, a very strong humanitarian component which has-I pay tribute to the other side-been a measure of the policy of those opposite as well as ours.

In this area, when we try to blend all those components to get a total aggregate figure for the annual intake, it is inevitable that there can be differences of opinion as to whether it is exactly right. Men and women of goodwill can have different views and different positions as to whether they have it exactly right. I reject the assessment that has been made by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie. As I say, I will attempt in conversation to persuade him of the error of his ways.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Community Services and Health aware that the Royal Children's Hospital in Melbourne has closed down its outpatient clinic and, in its stead, opened a number of private clinics, so that now patients who were formerly public patients are forced to be private patients and have to claim their treatment through Medicare? Is this a case of cost shifting? If so, what does the Government intend to do about it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the policy adopted by the Royal Children's Hospital to impose charges for many of the outpatient services provided by the hospital. This move by the Royal Children's Hospital is, in my view, a blatant piece of cost shifting, an attempt by the hospital to get the Commonwealth to pick up the tab for its patients by forcing them to become private patients and claim on Medicare.

ANSWER.PARA: Following discussions between my Department and Victorian health officials, I understand that the Victorian officials, recognising that it may be a breach of the Medicare hospital agreement between the Commonwealth and Victoria, are taking up the matter with the hospital. There is no doubt in my mind that the practice proposed by the hospital is a breach of the Medicare agreement in that Victoria is not maintaining the outpatient services it undertook to maintain when it signed the Medicare agreement in 1989. Accordingly, unless Victoria ensures that the hospital rectifies this breach promptly, the Federal Government will have no alternative but to invoke the penalty provisions of the Medicare agreement-in this case an appropriate deduction of Victoria's base funding grant equivalent to the costs of the transfer to Commonwealth outlays through increased Medicare and pharmaceutical benefits.

The Commonwealth contributes something of the order of $3.5 billion each year to the nation's health system. That is done on the basis of principles which have been agreed to between the Commonwealth and the States. They are agreements that are capable of review; indeed, in terms of the current national health strategy, again on the basis of some consultation with the States, there is determination to address any issues that may exist around questions of hospital funding.

The reality is that what is proposed by the Royal Children's Hospital is really privatisation. Essentially, privatisation is not only a shifting of the cost, in this case from the State to the Commonwealth, but essentially in principle an attempt to shift from the Government a cost across to the family.

That is why, when I referred to the Opposition yesterday, I did not do it lightly. The reality is that when the Leader of the Opposition said, as he said clearly in a press conference the other day, that `in principle personal financial responsibility originating with a family and targeting of welfare are key elements of our approach', he was making a serious point. He was entitled to be taken seriously, because philosophically what he was suggesting was that privatisation is at the heart of Opposition policy. Of course, going with privatisation, when that becomes the heart of the policy, certain consequences follow. In the same press conference, the Leader of the Opposition referred to $3 billion worth of cuts, a billion from welfare, and presumably additional cuts in terms of health.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I have a point of order. I took note of your comments yesterday with respect to standing order 144. However, I raise the point that the question certainly was in order, but the Minister is currently expressing an opinion. That opinion is not in line with the question and, therefore, under standing order 145 I ask that you rule it out of order, because the response is not relevant to the question.
—Show a bit of courage.

—I will show a bit of courage with the honourable member for Gippsland in a minute. It is an interesting construct that the honourable member for Isaacs puts forward, but of course it is out of order.
—If I could go back to the origin of the question: the question was directed towards--
—Mr Speaker, I have a further point of order. I wonder whether you could give me some indication as to why it is out of order.

—For the same reason I gave you yesterday. You cannot take a point of order on a question after the question has been asked and then try to relate the point of order on the question to the answer. The Minister is giving an answer that is relevant to the question, and as such he is in order.

—Let me return again to the question. The question dealt with the Royal Children's Hospital. The Royal Children's Hospital proposes effectively to privatise its outpatients, that is, to shift essentially towards families' responsibility in terms of health care.

ANSWER.PARA: The day before yesterday, the Leader of the Opposition indicated that that was fundamental to his understanding of what the Opposition's policy was all about, that is, that shift to family responsibility. It goes with that proposition that, if that objective is to be achieved, then clearly the overall level of expenditure will not be sustained. What the Leader of the Opposition indicated was that it was his intention to cut-and that was made clear during the last election-something of the order of $3 billion out of the expenditure, so that privatisation and then that commitment to make--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Standing order 145 says that an answer shall be relevant to the question. The point I wish to make to you, Mr Speaker, is that the question was a specific one relating to activities at a hospital in Victoria, and the Minister was asked whether he felt that that activity was a shift of expenditure responsibility from that hospital to the Commonwealth Government. We have now had a lecture about some shift of responsibility onto families. Since when has the Commonwealth Government been a family? I suggest to you that he is not relevant in answering the question and that, if he is unable to be so, you must ask him to bring his answer to a close.
—There is no point of order.
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins will cease interjecting.

—I rise on a point of order. Yesterday, Question Time went until nearly 3.30 p.m. because the Prime Minister was trying to give the Opposition time for a significant number of questions. There is now a clear strategy to disrupt Question Time. I urge the Opposition to get on with Question Time.
—Order! The honourable member for Burke will resume his seat.
—I do not need to take any more time--
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Mackellar.

—It is interesting that anywhere else except in this chamber the Opposition is prepared to defend propositions such as privatisation, $3 billion worth of cuts and a consumption tax. It is my view that those three elements are the essence of the Opposition's social policy. I think it is not unreasonable to refer to them as I see them. In the case of the Royal Children's Hospital, it is a move essentially to privatise. Frankly, if the Opposition was capable of getting out a single policy in the area of social policy, we could debate it in this Parliament. But as it is incapable of reaching agreement between its four previous spokespersons, we can only intuit what its policy is: the Opposition is simply incapable of arguing it.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. He would be aware of Senator Walsh's comments on the PM program last night. Does the Prime Minister agree that Australia has gone far down the `Argentinean road' and could not afford to `muck around' with the Coronation Hill decision? Senator Walsh's assessment is:

QUESTION.PARA: If it doesn't allow mining to go ahead, no mining company, free of having rocks in the head, will do any more exploration in that area and will have to think twice about exploring anywhere else in Australia.
Does the Prime Minister agree with that assessment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether it will come as a surprise or not to the honourable gentleman when I say no, I did not hear the program. I do not particularly go out of my way to chase up the statements of Senator Walsh. I intend no particular disrespect to the honourable senator in saying that. In all the things I do have to read, that is really not near the top of my priority list.

ANSWER.PARA: The substance of the question from the honourable member, however, is to do with the decision with regard to Kakadu and the report we have from the Resource Assessment Commission. Because I think the honourable gentleman is serious about the substance of his question, let me say that obviously we will be studying that final report of the Resource Assessment Commission very closely with a view to making a decision on that matter by early next month.

It is not going to be something that will be delayed for a long period, but I would hope the honourable gentleman would agree that the issues involved are of very considerable importance. It does seem to me from the way that he framed his question that he thinks there is only one consideration involved, and that is: what is available to Australia in terms of earnings from what can be produced out of a mine at Coronation Hill?

I happen to believe that is an important consideration, but I also happen to believe that there are other considerations that have properly to be taken into account. There are the considerations of the attitudes and the beliefs of the Aboriginal people in the area. There is the question of the possible adverse environmental impact of mining there. I am quite prepared to say to the honourable gentleman that I have not made up my mind on this issue. I believe that the strands of issues have to be taken into account. I do assert that there is more than the one consideration that has to be taken into account.

If that was the only consideration involved, there would be no need for a Resource Assessment Commission and an ecologically sustainable development process, but life is not as simple as that. I believe that the people of Australia do not want this Government simply to approach these issues with a one-dimensional view. I do not think the people of Australia take the attitude that all that the Government has to do is to look at some balance sheet and say, `Yes, if you dig up here or if you cut down there, there at the bottom of that line is a figure'. They certainly want us to take those things into account, and we will, but we will also take into account the other relevant considerations. We will make what I would regard as a decision within a reasonable amount of time, taking all of those factors into account, by the beginning of next month.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. How would the proposed protocol to the Antarctic Treaty improve protection of the Antarctic environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Grey for his question and for his interest in Antarctica. In fact, he went to Antarctica earlier this year. In the House yesterday the Prime Minister gave details of the very considerable progress being made towards achieving this comprehensive protection of the areas of Antarctica. I want to join in with my congratulations on that.

ANSWER.PARA: Not only will mining be prohibited, but also the proposed protocol will greatly enhance our obligations as Treaty partners to the protection of that environment of Antarctica. The draft protocol provides for science research to have priority over other activities permitted in Antarctica, but it will impose upon us very considerable obligations in relation to the protection of the environment and we will have to go through environmental assessments.

There will be three stages of assessment. One of them is an informal process which will operate on proposals which will have little or no impact on the environment; then there will be a more detailed proposal that would operate for proposals which would have minor or transitory impact; but activities involving the highest risk to the environment will be scrutinised by an international committee for environmental protection.

This draft protocol, in fact, refers to mining in only a few lines, but it also has a number of annexures which deserve consideration by all members of this House because they impose further obligations upon us. They not only outline the environmental impact procedures, but also state the obligations in relation to conservation of flora and fauna in terms of marine pollution, and waste minimisation.
The annexure on conservation of flora and fauna will require Australia to remove all sledge dogs by 1 April 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite laugh at this, but it is an issue of major concern, particularly to those people who have been to Antarctica and who have been involved in the polar expeditions. I can assure the House that this issue will be handled very sensitively. There will be discussion with the Antarctic expeditioners and with the committee which provides advice on Antarctic animal ethics.

ANSWER.PARA: The draft protocol should be finalised by 23 June 1991 which is, for the information of the House, the thirtieth anniversary of the Antarctic Treaty.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I ask you a question, Mr Speaker? —Order! There are many issues involved with questions and answers in the House. Whether matters are relevant or not depends on the question and the answer from time to time, and no Speaker has been willing to give the undertakings which the honourable member for Mackellar seeks.

—During Question Time the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that my question suggesting that Senator Gareth Evans would have sacked Mr Burke had Mr Burke not resigned was wrong. —Order! The honourable member for Mayo is not explaining where he was misrepresented; he is arguing the point--

—Order! The honourable member is bringing matters into the issue.

—On a point of order then: yesterday, when the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) made a personal explanation, you, Mr Speaker, allowed him to talk for four or five minutes and to debate the point, but because I am from the Opposition that is illegitimate. Is that right?

—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will resume his seat. Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Mayo can say where he was misrepresented. The honourable member for Mayo can tell the House about newspaper articles that mentioned what he said or what people said about him. To go to a misrepresentation does not--
—Hold your breath, Alexander, and go blue in the face.
—Order! To go to a misrepresentation does not allow the honourable member for Mayo to bring in a whole lot of other extraneous information.
—Order! The honourable member for Mayo will become a little less agitated for a minute or two.

—The Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories will not bother to help the Chair either. If the honourable member for Mayo can come to those particular points, the Chair will hear him.

—My point is that I am not drawing any extraneous information out from this, Mr Speaker. What I am doing is explaining firstly where the Prime Minister misrepresented me and, secondly, to be able to establish that he had misrepresented me, I have to establish what the facts were. I am pointing out to you, Mr Speaker-and I am sure you will appreciate this-that I was not wrong and what I said was certainly not immoral. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, I seek on behalf of the House some information from the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) in relation to the remainder of this session. According to the published information, after this week there are three scheduled sitting weeks. I would like an indication from the Minister as to how much legislation is yet to be introduced to be dealt with during the remainder of the session and, if there is an inordinate amount of legislation to be introduced, rather than resorting to using the guillotine as he has done on previous occasions will he arrange for the House to sit longer so that we can deal with the legislation in an appropriate way?
—Is the Minister able to provide the honourable member with an answer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we will probably do both. We cannot foreshadow exactly the situation in which we will find ourselves. Obviously there may be some advantages in having an extended guillotine that allows fairly full debate but still keeps matters batting up to the Senate at a reasonable pace. I think the Macklin motion cuts in on 7 June. Therefore we do have to clear an awful lot before 7 June.
—You have messed it up again.

—In response to the honourable member's description of our having messed it up again, let me go through a couple of reasons why it is, because I agree that we have had to operate a guillotine very heavily. There are several reasons for this and it is worthwhile contemplating them. I have attempted an analysis of them and we find ourselves, in terms of preparation of legislation, in a position not much different from that of the Opposition when it was in office.

SPEECH.PARA: We are sitting as many days as we did when the Opposition was in government and this year, on the scheduled timetable and the likely additions as we come back to deal with the Senate, we will probably sit a good deal more than its average. The point is this: since we started this two-week on, two-week off formula and added to it private members' Thursday we have substantially deprived Government-and rightly-of a considerable amount of control of the agenda.

In previous times, the tendency was to get one of the two Thursdays partially devoted in the morning to private members' business, with the other Thursday available for General Business when motions could be considered for part of the morning. The generality was that at the beginning of the sessions those motions were entertained. Towards the end of the sessions, they were dispensed with.

My firm conviction is that we should not do that. The reform that we have introduced, which gives over control of this Parliament from 9.30 a.m. until 2 p.m. every Thursday, should not be interfered with by the Executive and honourable members should be allowed to continue to have that time. It makes an enormous dent, if we look at past practice as opposed to past opportunity-effectively close to a day a fortnight-on the time available to debate legislation in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—If the honourable member does not agree with me, he should do his own analysis. It amounts to about one day a fortnight on which we could try to debate and deal with matters in this place. That accumulates over the period of time that we sit-we normally sit for about 10 weeks-effectively to an extra week and a bit that would otherwise be available to Government.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, there was the regular suspension of the 11 o'clock rule under the Opposition's particular mode of practice. In those days, in a four-week period, there were nine days of sittings, albeit for shorter hours, as opposed to what is effectively, under us, seven days of sittings with longer hours. When honourable members opposite had nine days of sittings with shorter hours of course they were in a much better position to extend those out to lengthy days. That is the situation in which we find ourselves in the control of our business.

It may be that honourable members will want to consider this from time to time in the future, if that is how they want their business conducted. In my opinion, there is no doubt that both the General Business Thursday and the two weeks on, two weeks off with longer hours as opposed to three weeks on with allegedly shorter hours, but which often ended up as longer hours, does in fact enable the average member of parliament to devote a great deal more time to his duties.

The problem that we confront with the guillotine is not solely a product of a problem common to most governments, that is, draftsmen in the Office of Parliamentary Counsel insisting on holidays-and it is not terribly easy to recruit to the Office, with the current comparison of Public Service and legal salaries-but involves the enormous difficulty in operating now without a guillotine. That difficulty is further impacted on by the practice over the last few years of operating the Macklin proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not having a crack at the parliamentary draftsmen now, are you?

—I do not think that we can fit any extra sittings in between now and when the Macklin proposition applies. We will have to get a deal of legislation through. I am not sure how many Bills remain, but it is a substantial number and there are more, on average, than we are now dealing with in a week. There is no doubt about that at all. Therefore, the likelihood of a guillotine is substantial.

SPEECH.PARA: The likelihood of us being called back to deal with subsequent consideration of that material when it comes back to us from the Senate is very high. I would anticipate that occurring somewhere in June or-although I would try to avoid this and a lot will depend on the Senate-perhaps even in July. I know that will not be a terribly popular decision with members, but it may be necessary, determined by how the Senate chooses to deal with our legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I ask the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) whether he would ascertain for the House the number of Bills that are yet to be introduced. He has indicated that there is a considerable number, but that he does not know how many. It would be helpful to the House to be informed, say, tomorrow of the number of Bills yet to be introduced and dealt with before the House rises for the winter recess.

—I will respond to that, by indulgence, if I might. I will try to get together the list of Bills that are yet to be considered. The honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) pointed out to me that words I said apparently appeared to be a crack at the parliamentary draftsmen. They were not meant to be, and I appreciate the fact that he pointed that out. I would not want any such implication to stand. The parliamentary draftsmen are as entitled as anyone else to a decent life.
—Including us.

—Yes, including ourselves. There are, nevertheless, difficulties posed in that area and the difficulties do not concern only the parliamentary draftsmen; instructions must come out of departments. These difficulties have been common to governments historically, and never has any government been able to effectively resolve them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I would like quickly to make the point in this debate, because it is an issue that concerns me, that every year, irrespective of the party in political power, we run into this log jam of legislation at the end of a session. I happen to hold the view that it is a bureaucratic conspiracy that neither the Government nor the Opposition is given the time by the departments to properly consider the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: For the last two or three weeks that we have been sitting, we have dealt with very little legislation because legislation has not been in the House. I put it to the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) and to those on my side of politics that it is time that we changed that rule and told the bureaucracy to get its legislation in place for the beginning of the session so that it is possible for the Government, the Opposition and the people of Australia to have a good look at it, and then allocate what is appropriate time to speak to it. We have recently had 20 or 30 speakers for quite small pieces of legislation and at the end will get one or two speakers for quite serious legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Leader of the House wish to respond?
—I agree, but I cannot do it by fiat.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker has received a letter from the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The urgent requirement for an immediate decision from the Government to approve the Coronation Hill Project and bring to an end the lengthy politicisation and procrastination over this important Project which is now a litmus test.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is time to bring out the facts rather than the fiction associated with the Coronation Hill project, and I bring forward this matter of public importance to do so on the basis that many facets must be taken into account in obtaining the right decision from the Government-the decision to proceed with the Coronation Hill project.

SPEECH.PARA: I bring forward this matter of public importance supported by my colleagues in the Liberal and National parties, and particularly by the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge), who will go into more details in respect of the important Aboriginal aspects which pertain to the Coronation Hill project. The coalition has always recognised that they are very important Aboriginal aspects which should be seen in perspective and properly dealt with. I have every confidence that the honourable member for Chisholm will detail that agenda in his supporting remarks.

In turning to the facts, let us begin with fact No. 1. Coronation Hill is not a greenfield mining site. It has been mined repeatedly before. There have been mines operating in 12 different locations in the vicinity of Coronation Hill. That includes workings on Coronation Hill itself and nearby El Sharana. For a period of about 10 years mining proceeded from one end of Coronation Hill, which included the extraction of some 25,000 tonnes of ore from the old Coronation Hill, or part thereof, disturbing a surface area of something a great deal less than a quarter of the Parliamentary Triangle. So honourable members might get it in correct perspective.

The new mine-the Coronation Hill project now proposed-would involve an area of surface disturbance of about one square kilometre, located again at Coronation Hill. It will be many kilometres from the northern wetlands area and important and sensitive parts of the Kakadu National Park, including the Jim Jim Falls, Obiri Rock and other areas that are in Kakadu National Park proper.

One can understand why the public is confused about the Coronation Hill project. Every time it comes up on television we see footage of areas a great distance from the Coronation Hill project, far beyond the conservation zone relating to those beautiful and delightful scenes that exist. Those who have had the privilege of going to the northern parts of Kakadu National Park would have seen that they are delightful scenes. They should be in a national park; they are in a national park. Coronation Hill has nothing to do with that particular agenda. I say loudly and clearly: let us get fact No. 1 established-it is not a greenfield mining site; it has been mined and explored by degrees before. Some 12 mines have operated in the area, with thousands of tonnes of ore being extracted. All of that has happened without, as luck would have it, any great and untoward disasters occurring. Quite the contrary, it has proceeded without great damage to the environment or to the spiritual well-being of Australians in the area and beyond. When we see the issue in that perspective perhaps we can then start to examine the true value of this Coronation Hill project.
Let us move on to fact No. 2. It has now been verified several times that the Coronation Hill mine will have little impact on the environment. I quote from the Resource Assessment Commission report:
A single mine, properly managed and monitored, would have a small and geographically limited direct impact on the known biological resources of the conservation zone.
I further quote from the report:
It is unlikely to have an impact on these biological resources in Kakadu National Park.
A single mine, such as that proposed for Coronation Hill is unlikely-
honourable members should note these words-
to present significant risks to the sustainability of the ecology of Kakadu National Park.

Indeed, on the environmental front it is clear. My colleague the honourable member for Pearce (Mr Chaney) has discussed this in more detail and will continue to do so in the effective way that he does. It has cleared the environmental hurdle not once but twice. It has cleared the Northern Territory environmental hurdles and it has gone on to clear the hurdles associated with the Federal level of government, and they are quite substantial hurdles. This is fully recognised.

Let me point out to the House some of the legislation enacted just to get this project up. Honourable members might like to know that at the Commonwealth level there is a welter of Acts: the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act, the Australian Heritage Commission Act, the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Act, the Environment Protection (Alligator Rivers Region) Amendment Act, the Lands Acquisition Act, the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act and World Heritage Properties Conservation Act. There are eight pieces of legislation at the Federal level before this one project can get under way.

Then we look at the Northern Territory level, and more than double the number of Acts are involved with this one project. Let us compare that with a lesson from Mali in western Africa where environmental considerations are taken into account as well. I refer to BHP's Syama gold project. Just note the following dates: April 1987, agreement with the Malian Government to explore the area; June 1988, reserves established; December 1988, feasibility study accepted by the Malian mines department and related environmental and other departments; February 1989, production permit approved; December 1989-2 1/2 years later-mine construction complete, and the first gold pour took place from that particular mine.

In Australia, six years later there is still no fundamental determination on Coronation Hill, although the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) today has set himself a timetable. Let the House not forget it. The Prime Minister today has set himself the timetable that by early June we will have an announcement on Coronation Hill. I will remind him of that, and I remind him that the Macklin cut-in date is apparently Friday, 7 June. That now seems also to be the cut-off date for compliance with the Prime Minister's undertaking to be decisive, once and for all, on the matter of Coronation Hill.

Quite apart from the fact that the environmental hurdles have been crossed, we then have the economic facts relating to this project. The Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) keeps on speaking of a mere $82m in its failure to calculate properly. Even in accordance with the Federal Government's model, it is around $200m that is truly involved with this project, and even more than that in terms of export income. I point out to the House that there are significant resources of gold, platinum and palladium. There is also, as I am sure the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) agrees, a reasonable expectation of increased resources, as is often the case when a mine proceeds in a particular area. Significantly, it is Australia's only known substantial resource of platinum and palladium.

What are those two items used for? They are used in the battle to comply with standards, to make progress with regard to the world's problems associated with greenhouse gases. They are, in a sense, pro-environment products. The greenies, in their wisdom, in battling against this project and delaying it at every turn, with the complicity of members of this Government, are in fact reducing Australia's capability to produce two products-platinum and palladium-which make a positive contribution to the battle against greenhouse gases through the use of particular devices relating to motor vehicles and others. I think that is an important point.

On the economic front, let me make it very clear that it has been assessed by independent sources-not the companies involved, not the joint venturers-that this would generate no less than 630 new jobs nationally. Have we reached a stage where we can afford to be dismissive of 630 jobs, when we have the unemployment figures coming out tomorrow? We had a period of record unemployment and record contraction in employment, yet this Government fiddles when action is required. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that on the economic front Coronation Hill stacks up, quite apart from the environmental front and quite apart from the precedent which exists.

Fact No. 4 is that it is really a litmus test, notwithstanding what the Prime Minister said at the Australian Mining Industry Council dinner last week. The mining world and many others around the world are watching closely to see whether in this non-election year the Government can stay the course. The Government does not have a Federal election or a Northern Territory election to do battle with, and yet it still cannot mount the courage to proceed with a decisive decision on Coronation Hill.

I am drawn to some comments by Senator Walsh. I do not always agree with Senator Walsh-I can understand that the Prime Minister, who used to take a lot of notice of Senator Walsh's words, no longer hangs on his every word-but he writes a pretty tidy column in the Australian Financial Review and I am attracted to some of his comments. I am attracted to some of the comments he made last night. He said in effect that the mining industry will regard this as a litmus test. He continued:

If after all of this time and the Government having once shifted the goal posts after the ball was kicked, as we did in 1989, if the Government does not allow Coronation Hill to proceed on the terms that I have suggested, it will be regarded as a litmus test by the mining industry, regardless of what the Prime Minister had in his mind at that time . . .

That is a very clear cut statement from Senator Walsh and it is one with which I agree. The truth of the matter is that the mining network of the world is watching this decision as it is watching the uranium policy mining decision. It cannot understand Australia's illogical approach to these critical issues. It is bitterly disappointed with Australia's approach to those issues and it is massively shifting offshore with a number of key decisions: for example, where is Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd drilling this month? It is drilling in the middle of Burma-a long way from Australia-as part of a major and costly exploration program in preference to drilling somewhere else in Australia. There are still many areas of great prospectivity which we have not yet tackled in Australia which could boost our oil resources.

I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this is really a litmus test. This requires from the Government a positive and firm decision, and the sooner the better. The Government has delayed and delayed the decision. It has created additional hurdles. As the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) has pointed out, the first hurdle was the Northern Territory environmental considerations. When one reads in the report and sees first-hand the extent of the damage to the country by buffaloes, as confirmed by Professor Skidmore, it really is very ordinary country. It qualified and managed to meet those criteria at the Northern Territory level.

The second hurdle was the Commonwealth imposition of certain environmental considerations and the RAC report process. It has even qualified on that hurdle. The third hurdle is now the Aboriginal side of the equation. I do not happen to belong to the brigade of the believers of `dig it up or cut it down'. There must be a very sensitive and careful consideration of those environmental criteria, of the Aboriginal aspects and the like. But that is no excuse for failing to reach the ultimate decision required of the Government, given all the studies that have been made into Coronation Hill and in the interests of all Australians.

It really is now or never if we want a vigorous economy, an economy where there is leadership from the Prime Minister, leadership from this Government; rather than the horrific rural economic recession we have already exacerbated by the policies of this Government, and the overall recession leading to the loss of jobs in every State at this time-more so in Victoria. It is now or never on the question of whether we are going to have an economy that progresses through this difficult and competitive decade of the 1990s; or whether we are going to revert to a cottage economy with candle power.

I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that there is a better way forward. It requires some hard decision making by this Government, but the Government has no more excuses for not acting with regard to Coronation Hill. It has report after report on which it can base its action. It must now move quickly and make those decisions. It must bring to an end the two-year interregnum, the cynical ploy, the political posturing, involving the RAC. Act now, act quickly, act decisively in the interests of all Australians in relation to Coronation Hill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) has put forward a rather tortuously expressed matter of public importance (MPI) which ends up with the words `litmus test'-I am not quite sure what of. In any case, I would like to start with a confession: I have not seen the report. I see that the Leader of the National Party has a copy and no doubt he sat up all night reading it. I grabbed a briefing as I came out of my office. I have been in Dubbo this morning. I see from the departmental briefing that the first recommendation is that the inquiry recommends that the Australian Government makes decisions relating to the use of the zone's resources as soon as possible. It looks as though the Leader of the National Party has actually read that. Today, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said that we will be dealing with it as soon as possible. I do not know what point there is in the MPI.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not surprised to receive a matter of public importance on this issue. The feverish emphasis of the matter of public importance is indicative of the fever now prevalent in the Opposition ranks. Let us be perfectly clear what this matter of public importance is about. It is not about, as some members of the Opposition would have us believe, just mining. It is not even about the development of a particular mine. I know that is strange for some of the Neanderthal economists opposite, and I know it is strange for some of the thrill seekers in the press gallery.

The real issue involved in this Government's consideration of mining at Coronation Hill is: how is the national interest best advanced and what are the circumstances and conditions which guarantee the advancement of the national interest? The national interest is broader than just the revenue generated by a particular project, although that is a very important consideration. The national interest is broader than just the issues of employment and investment, although these are important considerations. The national interest is broader than the environmental implications of a single project, although that is also an important consideration. The national interest is broader than the interests, in this case, of the Jawoyn people, although, to my mind, that is a critically important consideration.

The national interest is best served by understanding, assessing and integrating all these considerations. A critical component in making a balanced, consistent and sensible decision on extraordinarily complex resource issues-issues which are more than one dimensional-has been the establishment of the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC).

Being instrumental in the establishment of the Resource Assessment Commission, I can honestly tell this House that my view has never been that the RAC should take the decisions which properly are to be taken by government. Rather, the RAC's whole function and purpose is to provide the Government with a fulsome analysis on environmental, cultural, social, industrial, economic or other aspects of resources and their uses.

I agree with the Leader of the National Party when he talks about the fact that the general public has been hoodwinked to some degree. When we get a Coronation Hill story on the television, we see some footage of these beautiful areas-policy by pictures and slogans. Many people have been into that for a long time in this country.

I also agree with the Leader of the National Party when he says that this area has been mined before. I will just make two very important qualifications. An area does not have to be beautiful to be of environmental value. One of the side benefits in the RAC studies of this area has been the studies done by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation on wildlife and parrots. There is a lot in that area that is of supreme environmental quality. The other qualification is that because an area has been mined it does not necessarily-I emphasise the word `necessarily'-mean that it should continue to be mined. Let us be quite precise about that.

Again, I must emphasise that the establishment of the RAC will not and cannot lead to decisions made independently of the Cabinet process. Governments make decisions on the basis of the best possible information. The RAC was set up to assemble information which should not be challengeable regardless of where a particular public attitude is coming from. We have the paradigm of economics and the paradigm of ecology. That is what the RAC has been set up to do. It is my view that it will achieve that status and the standing that the Industry Commission has achieved through the enormous role it has played in industry policy.

In this view I differ profoundly from the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), who formed the view in the second reading debate on the Resource Assessment Commission Bill 1989 that the establishment of the RAC would usurp the responsibility of government. I have never been of that view.

It is sensible to remind the House of the policy principles which will guide the operation of the RAC. These principles are: firstly, there should be an integrated approach to conservation and development by taking both aspects into account at an early stage. Secondly, resource use decisions should seek to optimise the net benefits to the community from the nation's resources having regard to efficiency of resource use, environmental considerations and an equitable distribution of the return on resources. Thirdly, Commonwealth decisions, policies and management regimes may provide for additional uses that are compatible with the primary purpose values of the area, recognising that in some cases both conservation and development interests can be accommodated concurrently or sequentially, and in other cases choices must be made between alternative uses or combinations of uses.

Those principles have not changed. Rather, they have been put into effect in a proper and serious fashion by the Government when it decided to refer the Coronation Hill issue to the RAC. It is crystal clear to me, although obviously not to the Opposition, that complex issues require detailed analysis. That is why the RAC was established. That is why the issue of mining at Coronation Hill was referred to the RAC. That is why the Government now is in a position where the issue, for so long a contentious and divisive issue, can be resolved in a concrete, substantial and final way. That is the Government's approach. We believe in open inquiry. We believe in testing arguments against analysis. We believe in receiving and listening to the best possible advice.

I know that is difficult for the Opposition to comprehend. The Opposition, holding as it does to the Neanderthal school of economics, believes in none of these principles that I have just enunciated. Therefore, I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that the Leader of the National Party misses the point completely in his wording of the matter of public importance. He refers to the lengthy politicisation and `procrastinisation'-I think that is a new word-over this important project. He completely misses the point. Detailed analysis is not procrastination. Detailed analysis is not politicisation. It is a new-found habit, apparently, of the Leader of the National Party to detract from and deride the serious work done by serious professional officers of the Commonwealth Public Service.

He recently said that, if this is the best that could be produced by the bureaucrats from the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, the Australian Wool Corporation and the International Wool Secretariat, then perhaps a 15 per cent reduction in the size and salaries of the bureaucracy was needed, attacking people who cannot hit back. He made that clear in a more recent radio show, when he said:

I'm not reaching a viewpoint that there is another agenda operating out of Canberra out of the bureaucracies of Canberra, indeed perhaps even Minister Kerin to somehow bring about a greed of agony and adjustment in the bush at far too faster rate and this wool plan yesterday is an example of that.
Maybe he has covered himself, but I think he is attacking bureaucrats. Attacking bureaucrats is an ugly habit and it does him no credit whatsoever.

What he is suggesting is that the efforts of professional scientists, economists, biologists and geologists are merely procrastination. I reject that implication. The reason I reject it is the reason which has been a guiding principle to me in approaching policy issues. That principle has been that facts and analysis beat the socks off prejudice and ill-thought through opinion. I enjoin the Leader of the National Party to adopt that principle as a matter of habit.

The Resource Assessment Commission has presented the Commonwealth with a series of options. They are, firstly, mining to proceed at Coronation Hill and the remainder of the conservation zone to become part of Kakadu National Park; second, mining to proceed at Coronation Hill and the remainder of the conservation zone to remain a conservation zone, but no further mineral exploration to be permitted until experience at Coronation Hill has been evaluated; third, mining to proceed at Coronation Hill and further mineral exploration to be permitted in the remainder of the conservation zone, with any proposals for additional mines to include assessments of the cumulative, cultural and environmental impacts of such proposals, assessment of their economic significance and evaluation of experience at Coronation Hill; fourth, mining not to proceed at Coronation Hill, but further mineral exploration to be permitted in the remainder of the conservation zone, with any proposals for mining to be considered when more detailed information is available about the mineral resources of the zone, including assessments of the impact of such proposals on the cultural and natural environment and assessment of their economic significance; fifth, mining and exploration not to be permitted at Coronation Hill or elsewhere in the conservation zone-the whole of the zone to become part of the Kakadu National Park; sixth, no mining or exploration in the conservation zone unless Aboriginal custodians request it; and, lastly, the conservation zone to remain a conservation zone, but no further exploration or mining to be permitted until the outcome of the Kakadu stage 3 land claim is known.

They are the seven options put before us, and there is also a series of recommendations that I do not have time to read into Hansard. But these are very sensible recommendations. After all this inquiry, if one looks at these recommendations and the knowledge behind them, one will see, I think, that the RAC is well on the way to becoming a body that is going to soon have the sort of status in Australian policy making that I have always hoped that it would achieve. It is setting forward clear options. Some of those options could be boiled down so that we could be looking at three or four options.
The Prime Minister says that we will be looking at this, probably in June. We are picking up the first recommendation, which is:
