The inquiry recommends the Australian Government make decisions relating to the use of the zone's resources as soon as possible.

The Prime Minister said that we will. In addition, the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) has received an Aboriginal heritage report on the Kakadu conservation zone by Mr Justice Stewart. The two reports will be considered in tandem by the Government.

Let us make it clear that this discussion will not set the future parameters for future Government policy in relation to mining projects or other issues. The issues central to Coronation Hill-environmental, economic and Aboriginal issues-simply do not apply to the overwhelming majority of mining projects in this country. That is why I reject the argument that Coronation Hill should be considered as a litmus test for the future of mining development in this country, if that is the sort of litmus test that the Leader of the National Party is referring to. That is also the reason why I reject the efforts by the Leader of the National Party to portray it as such.

The leaders and the decision makers of the mining industry understand these issues better than does the Leader of the National Party. They will continue to make their commercial decisions on the basis of commercial returns. They will continue to assess world markets, world prices, the cost of investment and the cost of production. That, more than anything else, will drive development in the mineral sector in this country.

The Government recognises that all industries have to adjust to the legitimate concerns of the community to deal with environmental issues. That is why we now have the ecologically sustainable development process, and that is something for the long term. That is something in which all groups are participating, and participating constructively and competently.

Anyone who believes that the attitudes of Australians are unchanging about the environment and resource use is, quite frankly, a mug. Australians want a clean environment. They want a legacy to be left for their children. If it is not believed that attitudes have not changed, talk to anyone under 30 today. They do not want to see the practices of the past continued as though the practices of the past were perfectly satisfactory.

It has been among this Government's achievements that it has administered economic, resources, rural and environmental policy with a view to the long term. The decision which this Government will take on Coronation Hill will be seen within that context. It will be taken with a view to the long term. It will be taken after the most exhaustive analysis, and it will be right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wooldridge Dr M.R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coronation Hill is insignificant geographically, so much so that it hardly rates a mention on any map of the Northern Territory. Yet this insignificant geographical site has been catapulted into public prominence because of dithering, duplicity and political expediency.

SPEECH.PARA: In this matter of public importance I am going to develop two points. The first is that this decision, which comes to us now after a delay of two years simply because of political expediency before the last election, has the potential to stop any mining project anywhere in Australia under section 10(4) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984. Secondly, this duplicity, this dithering and this political expediency have been at the expense of the Jawoyn Aboriginal community.

The view I will expand on is based very firmly on the belief that, in remote and much of rural Australia, the only opportunity the majority of Aboriginal people have for any sort of independent economic future, free of welfare dependency, is through the benefits that mining will bring their communities.

The first point I want to make is the effect of section 10(4) of the report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) by Mr Justice Stewart. To get the full sense of this, we really have to compare the two reports. The Resource Assessment Commission report is a lengthy document which canvasses all the views and could even be called balanced. The second report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is quite different. It is hardline, it is in totally different language and it is very explicit. The two are quite inconsistent with each other.

The report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs says that the conservation zone could be put in danger even by putting it in the national park, and this would be against the Act. Mr Justice Stewart has broken totally new ground because, essentially, what he is saying is that a significant or sacred site can be defined very, very broadly. This was never the intention of the original Act. In the second reading speech of the then Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), when he introduced the legislation seven years ago, he said quite specifically:

The Bill speaks of significant Aboriginal areas and defines area to include a site. The use of the word area rather than site will allow flexibility . . . . It is not meant to close off a huge area and will not be administered in that way.

Yet what we have here from the report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs is the very clear implication that the entire Sickness Country, an area of 3,500 to 4,000 square kilometres, is out of bounds.

If honourable members think this is a one-off situation, that there will be no further Bula sites around Australia, and that Aboriginal culture operates in a vacuum and is a static quantity that does not change over time, they are very wrong, because the interpretation of this Act means that any area of significance, no matter how trivial to Aboriginal people, can be declared a sacred site. No-one denies that sites associated with ceremonies or traditional customs still used today, and areas adjacent to and associated with those sacred sites, are of profound importance to Aboriginal people and must be offered protection. An example known to anyone visiting the escarpment at Kakadu is Mount Brockman. The operators of the Ranger uranium mine nearby know that uranium is there and say quite openly that it will never be mined.

The notion of Sickness Country, which has only come into the custody of the Jawoyn people this century, probably late this century, and the notion of the gold being the blood of Bula-a notion that is not even a decade old-show that Aboriginal tradition is in a constantly changing state of flux. So, firstly, by defining the Act so broadly as to include anything and, secondly, by having no particular reference point in time for the Act to apply means that over time, even over very short spaces of time, changes can occur in response to pressures on Aboriginal people and those changes can alter the entire playing field for one of our most important industries.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has totally missed the point that, if one procrastinates, dithers and takes years to come to a clear position, Aboriginal tradition and culture can change even in that time. Attitudes will harden and pressures will be brought to bear on Aboriginal people that may totally change the whole scene in just a couple of years. That is what has happened here. The interim report of Mr Justice Stewart was quite inadequate when it described the contradictions in evidence from Jawoyn people as being both minute and apparent. He left those two words out of his final report.

His contradictions include such things as the fact that six years ago two of the three senior elders were as strongly pro-mining as they are today anti-mining and that in 1985 the most senior traditional elder said to Bob Ellis of the Sacred Sites Protection Authority, when taken aside, that mining could still go ahead. In 1968, when the sacred sites were first signposted to protect them, the Aboriginal people did not even bother to go up the valley where Coronation Hill existed, because there was nothing there. The contradictions were neither minute nor apparent. But it is not the nature of the contradictions I am concerned about, because people have the right to change their minds over time. I am concerned that this whole process over a prolonged period has hardened attitudes rather than seeking to resolve the differences, and all this has been caused by simple inactivity and procrastination.
This was put very well by the Australian Labor Party senator from the Northern Territory, Bob Collins, who stated:

It is with some resignation that I note that the debate on this matter is proceeding along familiar lines. The environment groups have formed a formal alliance with the Jawoyn working party. This alliance has simply confirmed that the groups will accept no quarter on the issue. There will be no tacit support from these groups for any compromise solution, nor did I ever think there could be. The key players who are now running this debate are well known to me. A small number of them are consummate ratbags. All of them are running on an agenda that has nothing whatever to do with the long term interests of the Jawoyn community. The Jawoyn people are simply convenient cannon fodder for them in this battle and they will happily fight it down to the last Aborigine.

That is a senator and Minister from the Government's own Party. Then, in recent days, he expanded on the pressure put on Jawoyn people by this dithering and delaying on the Government's side of politics. On the issue of pressure, he said:

Pressure is always applied, consciously or unconsciously, when people raise the mining issue in discussion with Aboriginal people . . . The commission is happy to accept it has got a splinter of the true cross, in terms of information, while considering of little significance the information obtained by-
other people. He pointed out that the Jawoyn people in recent years have been under increasing `pressure' from the anti-mining green lobby.
The Government is damned in Justice Stewart's own report. On page 159 of that report, he states:

The past and future role of Commonwealth agencies in serving the Jawoyn community may be an issue that the Australian Government will wish to consider. Within the Katherine region, initiatives under the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy seem to be having very little impact . . .

So for all the lofty rhetoric, the Government has failed where it really matters to the Jawoyn people. It has failed in delivering any meaningful improvement in services on the ground; it has failed in improving their quality of life in any meaningful way; it has left them to be manipulated, and to have their attitudes harden.

The Government has now given this issue very little possibility of resolution, whereas three years ago all this could have been fixed quite simply before the attitudes had hardened. Aboriginal people can change their views over time. Anthropologist Erich Kolig has pointed out that Aborigines have shown themselves to be willing to set aside dogma in the pursuit of a better opportunity. This is a significant strand of opinion in current Jawoyn thought, so it is vital that a decision be taken quickly.

It is vital that no more damage is done to Jawoyn people, and it is vital that they be allowed to talk directly to the joint venture to see whether they have any common ground in this issue. As it is now, the Government has left them exactly where they were five years ago-in poverty, dependent on welfare, with little hope and little future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of the Kakadu conservation zone first has to be understood as a particularly complex one. For an Opposition to call for a resolution and decision by the Government is a reasonable thing to ask, except that when it says it wants an answer, it means it wants an answer to go ahead and mine Coronation Hill. That is okay; that is the Opposition's point of view. But do not confuse that request with the essential request of the Government and the response by Mr Justice Stewart, which is that these matters are the various matters which must be considered in the question of whether or not mining should take place at Coronation Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating here a mine site, sitting within a conservation zone, sitting within a national park, overlaid by Aboriginal land and heritage claims. One can understand the complexity of the debate. What I wish to do is to draw to the attention of those who will read Hansard or are interested in the debate the sorts of options that Mr Justice Stewart has arrived at. They are not all yes/no options. That needs to be appreciated. There are, in essence, as the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) has pointed out, two reports under consideration by the Government. The first is a report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) on the Kakadu conservation zone, on the question most importantly of the particular significance of this site to the Aborigines-to the Jawoyn people-and Mr Justice Stewart finds:

Accordingly, I report that the Minister could be satisfied in concluding that the area of the Conservation Zone is a significant Aboriginal area under section 10 (1) (b) (i) of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984.

The Government must take account of this recommendation. Much more importantly, it must take account of its own legislation. It is our legislation and we have to take account of it and make a decision within the bounds of it, otherwise we will be taken to court.

I note in passing that Mr Justice Stewart comments that the Jawoyn people's views had evolved to this point in time, and he notes that they may continue to evolve on the question of whether or not they would allow mining at Coronation Hill. That is the sort of question that the honourable member for Chisholm has raised and he is right to raise it.
The second part of the report to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs goes to the extent of the possible injury to, or desecration of, the area. In concluding his remarks he states:

. . . the Minister could be satisfied that a threat of injury to or desecration of the Conservation Zone exists if the Commonwealth Government takes decisions that are likely to lead to one or more of the following:
He then talks about mineral exploration or mining occurring in the conservation zone. That is one report arising out of the Resource Assessment Commission.

The second report goes to the question of options and whether or not there should be mining. There are seven options in all. I hope that people read all seven of them because three of the options talk about mining proceeding at Coronation Hill, but there are two other options which talk about stopping the mining and two further options which talk about making the mining subject to, in the first instance, the request of the Aboriginal custodians or, in the second instance, the outcome of the Kakadu stage 3 land claim.

I wish simply to run through the benefits and losses that occur under the most important of those seven options. The Government has before it now the best evidence possible upon which it can make a decision about the future use of the conservation zone. It needs to add weight to the evidence and it must rate the veracity of the evidence which Justice Stewart lays before the Government. He has done no more and no less than that.
Option A is essentially the go-ahead for mining. Justice Stewart says this about that go-ahead option:
Mining to proceed at Coronation Hill and the remainder of the Conservation Zone to become part of Kakadu National Park.
The benefits of that option are as follows:
* National and regional economic benefits, including employment of some Aboriginal people and payment of royalties and other monies to the Jawoyn.
* Better understanding of the geological processes that formed the Coronation Hill ore body, possibly leading to similar discoveries elsewhere.
* Incorporation in Kakadu National Park of that part of the Zone that is of greatest archaeological and biological significance-the Scinto Plateau.
* Possible contribution of mining infrastructure to recreation and tourism potential of the Zone.
* Some tourists may visit the area to see the mine.
On the other hand, in this whole question of balance there are also the losses. They are:
* Adverse impact on the cultural and religious values of many Jawoyn people.
* Possible legal action over mining of a sacred site.
* Some recreational uses of the area may be curtailed during period of mining and some tourists could be permanently discouraged from visiting the area.
* Some (unquantifiable) risk associated with unknown elements of the fauna and flora.
* Loss of `whole catchment' concept of conservation.
* Loss of public confidence in national park integrity.
* Possible adverse effect on nomination for World Heritage listing of Kakadu National Park.
All of those matters have to be weighed, even under option A which is, essentially, the go-ahead option. The total stopper option is option E, which states:
Mining and exploration not to be permitted at Coronation Hill or elsewhere in the Zone, the whole of the Zone to become part of Kakadu National Park.
The benefits of that option are:

* Incorporation in Kakadu National Park of the entire catchment of the South Alligator River, apart from that part in Arnhem Land and the Koongarra mineral lease, as recommended by the Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry.
* In accordance with the wishes of the Jawoyn custodians of the area and of many Jawoyn people.
* Enhanced confidence of Aboriginal people in the attitude of the non-Aboriginal community to their beliefs.
* No risk of mining-induced effects on the environmental and cultural values of the area.
* Subject to land claim outcome, royalty payments to the Jawoyn from national park income.
* Increased confidence on the part of those in the community concerned with preservation of national park values.
* Increased standing among elements of the international community.
* In accord with international and national definitions of national parks.
Arraigned against those benefits are the following losses:
* Loss of economic benefits from mining and associated employment and royalty benefits for Aboriginals.
* Loss of opportunity to understand the geology of the mineral deposits in the Zone.
* The possibility of adverse effects on investor confidence in the mineral industry.

So option A, the total go-ahead option, has a series of costs and benefits and option E, the total stopper, has a series of costs and benefits. I will not go through option D in detail. It canvasses the following:
Mining not to proceed at Coronation Hill but further mineral exploration to be permitted in the remainder of the Zone,

That is not a real option. If the mining industry is knocked back on Coronation Hill I do not think it will bother with any further exploration in the zone itself. I do not see that option D is at all realistic. However, option F is an interesting and very difficult one. It says:
No mining or exploration in the Conservation Zone until the Aboriginal custodians request it.

In other words, the Government could opt to pass the decision about mining to the Aboriginal people themselves. Of course, that would place a significant amount of pressure on the Jawoyn community, and it is a matter that has to be handled extremely carefully. Nevertheless, the benefit that might arise from this option is that at least it will enable the Jawoyn to weigh up for themselves the balance between their cultural and religious beliefs and the benefits and losses of mining.

On the other hand-and the honourable member for Chisholm is quite right-the Jawoyn people have waited for some considerable time now, and have already been under a considerable amount of pressure whilst awaiting a decision on this. The great and major loss that might accrue under option F is that they would be placed under further considerable pressure and further lobbying, if you like, from both the Northern Lands Council and the mining community.

It is a difficult decision. We are now at a point where the Cabinet will make its decision. I applaud the efforts of the Resource Assessment Commission. I know that the Government, on the basis of the best evidence now available to it, will make the correct decision for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF (URANIUM CONCENTRATE EXPORT DUTY) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate without requests.

DEBATE.TITLE: SINGLETON MILITARY AREAMAJOR EXPLOSIVES STOREHOUSES, MYAMBAT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the second and third reports of the Committee for 1991 relating to the following proposed works:

SPEECH.PARA: Redevelopment of the Singleton Military Area, Stage 1, NSW
Construction of major explosives storehouses, Myambat, Stage 1, NSW
Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The first report I have just tabled deals with stage 1 of the redevelopment of the Singleton military area in New South Wales. The limit-of-cost estimate for the work is $29.3m at November 1990 prices. The works referred to the Committee comprise: living facilities for 198 staff and 552 students; working facilities for depot company headquarters; redevelopment of roads and provision of car parking; construction of new range control buildings; extension of area engineering services; site works; and furniture and fittings.

SPEECH.PARA: The Singleton military area was acquired during the Second World War and some facilities from that time are still in use. Temporary facilities were constructed in 1965. In 1989 the Headquarters Infantry Centre was set up, comprising some of the corps functions previously performed in Canberra, the School of Infantry, and various support units. Many of these units work in temporary dilapidated buildings. Much of the living accommodation is below services' scales and standards of accommodation. Staff and students currently use six different messes in two different areas of the base. This is very wasteful in its use of manpower and maintenance funds. The Singleton range is intensively used and is relatively small when compared with other military ranges. Range control buildings are near the centre of the range, inhibiting optimum utilisation of the facilities. In particular, entry cannot be effectively controlled.

The works recommended by the Committee form stage 1 of a plan to redevelop the whole Singleton military area. It is currently the Army's highest priority because of the emphasis on improving living-in accommodation for all personnel. The Committee took particular note of the energy conservation measures proposed by Australian Construction Services for these works. It reiterates its belief, first expressed in its report on the redevelopment of Cabarlah in Queensland, that it should receive copies of analyses carried out on all projects referred to it to ensure the efficient energy conservation measures are included. Australian Construction Services intends to call tenders in a number of small contracts which should ensure a significant proportion of the work is attractive to local contractors. Australian Construction Services will also consult with the local Commonwealth Employment Office about the approximate numbers and mix of labour required for the project.

The Committee was impressed by the Army's `good neighbour' policy which is designed to minimise the impact of noise pollution and to ensure that complaints received are promptly investigated and followed up. The base clearly has a good relationship with the local community; it is also clear that there is strong support for the proposal in the Singleton area. The Singleton Shire Council stressed the need for the Army to acquire and maintain an adequate buffer zone around the base. The Council has placed zoning controls to prevent encroachment by large numbers of very small landowners, and has pointed to the need for consultation about subdivision proposals in the vicinity of the base.

While the Committee is aware that defence policy prevents funds being spent on museums, it recommends that the Department of Defence examine ways of providing upgraded facilities for the Infantry Museum at Singleton. The Committee would like to thank personnel at Singleton for the work that went into its visit on 31 January 1991.

The second report I tabled deals with stage 1 of the redevelopment of the Myambat supply depot in New South Wales. The limit-of-cost estimate for the work is $34.4m at July 1990 prices. The works referred to the Committee comprise the construction of 30 earth-covered explosive storehouses with associated road works; the construction and extension of living and working accommodation; the upgrading of the sewerage system and the water supply, and the upgrading of the railway siding. The Army's wholesale ammunition holdings are stored in five depots in eastern Australia. They were established during the Second World War. Many of the explosives warehouses are not suitable for the storage of the most hazardous types of ammunition in accordance with the United Nations-North Atlantic Treaty Organisation principles. Many living and working facilities are inadequate and constitute a repair and maintenance liability.

Studies have recommended that in the medium term the Army should reduce its national wholesale depots from five to two: Myambat and Wallangarra in Queensland. The Committee is concerned about this decision because Myambat is in a relatively isolated location. The Committee believes a study should be done of the costs and benefits of retaining Wallangarra as a second national wholesale depot, and that it should receive a copy of the results of this study. The Committee was told that energy consumption for the proposed buildings will not be great compared with many military establishments. I have already referred, in my comments on the Singleton report, to the Committee's belief that it should receive copies of the analyses of energy usage on all projects referred to it. The same recommendation has been made in the report on Myambat.

The Committee noted the work done by Army personnel at Myambat to sustain a good relationship with the local community. It believes it would be worthwhile to hold another public meeting to explain all the impacts the proposed works will have on that community. Rosemount Estates winery raised a number of concerns with the Committee, including the inclusion of land in the safety arc from the depot, the adverse impact of the destruction of explosives, the location of the sewerage plant and fires being started in the depot. Defence will advice Rosemount of the results of computer modelling which will determine the location of the safety arc. It has also ceased demolishing the explosives causing Rosemount's problems. The Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works is satisfied that the sewerage plant is in a suitable location. While there have been fires in the past depot staff take measures to reduce their causes and to deal effectively with those which start. Nevertheless, the Committee has recommended that Defence continue to resolve outstanding issues with the winery.

Works in this project will provide the most urgently needed facilities and engineering services. The project has been divided into two phases and a further stage will be undertaken when funding is available to complete the redevelopment of Myambat. The Committee would like to thank the personnel at Myambat for the work which went into its visit on 30 January 1991. I commend both reports to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Singleton and Myambat are both in my electorate of Hunter and the Federal Government's developments announced by the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) today in his capacity as Chairman of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works are most welcome.

SPEECH.PARA: The development, expansion and upgrading of the Singleton army base and the Myambat ordnance supply depot will be of great benefit to the economies of both Singleton and Denman. They are welcomed and appreciated by the citizens of those two localities. I extend to Mr Hollis and the other members of the Committee the thanks of the communities for the decision announced today. The developments announced will provide a tremendous boost in employment opportunities and will also provide the Department of Defence personnel already located at Singleton army base and at the supply depot with the type of accommodation they deserve. It is a very happy day for me to see that the Public Works Committee has approved these two major developments in my electorate. I thank the Chairman of the Public Works Committee.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Robert Brown, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
The purpose of the Bill is to amend the Departure Tax Act 1978 to provide that the rate of departure tax be increased from $10 to $20 with effect from 1 August 1991.

The decision to increase departure tax to $20 follows the announcement by the Government in December last year to increase by $23m funding for the promotion of Australia as a tourist destination. The increase in departure tax will serve to offset this additional tourist promotion expenditure.

The increased promotion will allow Australia to capitalise on recent growth in tourism and will lead to significant job creation. It is estimated that 8,700 jobs are created for every 10 per cent increase in international visitor arrivals. Australia's departure tax will remain on a par with similar taxes collected in a number of other countries. The proposal to increase the rate of departure tax to $20 is expected to double the revenue generated by departure tax and, allowing for tourist growth, is likely to result in an increase in revenue of approximately $35m in 1991-92 and $37m in each subsequent year.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum for the Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Jull) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Griffiths, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill will make a number of miscellaneous amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 to tidy up the legislation. Some of these will shorten the administrative decision process, consistent with the Government's micro-economic reform initiative. The Bill will enable the joint authorities to delegate jointly to Commonwealth and State or Northern Territory officials the more routine administrative decisions that they are required to make under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967.

It is intended that only decisions that do not diverge from established policy will be delegated. If there is any disagreement between the two officials involved on any matter to be decided, the matter must be referred back to Ministers for a decision. This amendment will streamline the administration of the offshore petroleum legislation without weakening ministerial authority over decisions made under the legislation.

The Bill will also replace the requirement for holders of offshore petroleum titles to lodge securities with a mandatory requirement for titleholders to take out insurance against potential liabilities arising from their operations. Currently, the requirements for insurance while usually attached as a condition of grant or renewal of a title are not mandatory.

The amendments will reduce the administration costs borne by industry while ensuring that the community is well protected against any liabilities arising out of offshore petroleum operations. While we never have had a major spill from petroleum exploitation operations in this country, this action will ensure that, in the unlikely case that an oil spill does occur, environmental clean-up costs will be fully met by the operators and their insurers.

Seismic surveying undertaken by contractors on a speculative basis over offshore areas not held under a petroleum title is a valuable means of encouraging exploration. It encourages exploration companies to express interest in, and to bid for, exploration permits over these vacant areas.

Such action can only enhance the offshore search for petroleum in Australia. This Bill will provide an additional incentive for such operations by giving the designated authority the discretion to extend the confidentiality period for the basic information collected in such operations to up to five years prior to providing public access to the information.

The Great Barrier Reef is a national treasure which all responsible Australian governments must manage and protect from damage for all time. This Government has made it clear that there will be no exploration for petroleum in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park or the coastal area extending up to the low water mark.

Exploration in the five petroleum exploration permits, granted under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, has been inactive since 1971 and operations were formally suspended in 1974. Given the Government's commitment to a total ban on petroleum exploration in the park, continuation of the five permits was seen as anachronistic. The Government therefore announced its determination to terminate the permits on 26 July 1990.

One of the two companies with permits in the Great Barrier Reef region, Chevron, has favourably responded to our request and agreed to voluntarily surrender its four exploration permits in the area which were held by its subsidiary, Keydrill Australia Inc. This action demonstrates-I am sure the House will agree-Chevron's standing as an environmentally concerned corporate citizen.
This Bill will enable the Government to terminate the remaining permit in the region, Q/11P.

An amendment to section 130 of the Act is proposed to clarify an ambiguity that currently exists with respect to domestic gas phase royalties obtained from the North West Shelf project. The change is specifically intended to define that category of royalty that the Commonwealth agreed to transfer to Western Australia to ensure the long term viability of the liquefied natural gas (LNG) export phase of the North West Shelf project.

As it is currently drafted, no distinction is made in the legislation between Commonwealth royalties obtained from the domestic gas and LNG phases of the project. This ambiguity has been drawn to the attention of the Western Australian Government and it has indicated that it has no concerns in principle with the change.

The Bill also clarifies two minor possible ambiguities in the Act. First, a more precise definition of exploring for petroleum will ensure that all relevant operations are covered by the Act. Another amendment will clarify the obligations of a holder of an access authority to affected titleholders.
Finally, the Bill will remove minor inconsistencies and overlap between the Act and the Crimes Act 1914 which have occurred because of amendments to the Crimes Act 1914.

Section 132 of the Act, which is now redundant because of recent amendments to the Crimes Act 1914, will be repealed. Other amendments will extend the scope of offences dealt with in sections 133 and 135 of the Act to cover inchoate offences. Another amendment to section 84 of the Act will remove an inconsistency with other parts of the Act by requiring that a person knowingly provides false or misleading information in the test for offences under the section.
None of the amendments have any significant financial impact although the amendment to section 130 of the Act may have the effect of deferring minimal payments of royalty to Western Australia.
I commend the Bill to the House, and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Jull) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Griffiths, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) (Royalty) Act 1967 to enable the efficient and correct determination of royalties from those areas subject to offshore petroleum royalties. Royalty is collected on a calendar month basis and is shared between the Commonwealth and the respective adjacent State.

As a result of the Government's decision last year to extend the coverage of the resource rent tax legislation to the Bass Strait region, the North West Shelf project, Australia's largest resource development, is the only producing region subject to the scope of this legislation. The Government's decision not to extend resource rent tax to the North West Shelf project was in recognition of the vast sums of financing involved in the infrastructure associated with the development, and the sensitivity surrounding the export phase of the project.

The proposed amendments are intended to clarify a number of matters of detail which are not specifically addressed by the legislation and give legislative support to administrative practices. They will, therefore, not add any further administrative burden on either government or the petroleum producers.

The amendments will allow for an interim royalty to be paid by the producers in circumstances where full agreement on royalty arrangements has yet to be finalised between the parties. On finalisation of the royalty agreement, adjustments to the interim royalty paid will be made.

The amendments will also enable any royalty payment that has been made by the producers to be considered as an interim payment until such time as the full details of the royalty calculation have been verified and accepted. The current provisions provide insufficient time to satisfactorily verify the information submitted by the producers, resulting in the potential for incorrect royalty payments to be made.

In addition, the amendments will facilitate the adjustment to royalty in cases of overpayment or underpayment arising from the incorrect application or interpretation of an agreed or determined procedure contained within a royalty agreement.

The amendments will not result in any additional administrative and compliance costs, but will provide added clarity of and certainty in the provisions. The impact of the proposed amendments is expected to be revenue neutral.
I commend the Bill to the House, and present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Mr Howard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1990-91[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 5) 1990-91APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1990-91]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate is resumed on this Bill, I remind the House that it has been agreed that a general debate be allowed covering Appropriation Bill (No. 4), Appropriation Bill (No. 5) and Appropriation Bill (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In September of 1988 the then Victorian transport Minister, Mr Jim Kennan, issued a media release which read, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: `This year's State Budget allocation to Berwick City was $1.04 million for main roads and $188,800 for local roads.
The increased allocation for construction and maintenance of local roads reflects the Government's commitment to developing a local roads infrastructure in this fast developing area', Mr Kennan said.
Mr Kennan said major works to improve the Princes Highway would begin this financial year.

He said Phillip Huggins, ALP candidate for Berwick, had pointed out community concerns about possible future traffic problems on the highway between the Mulgrave Freeway and the Berwick bypass. As a result of Mr Huggins' representations, the Road Construction Authority has brought forward the start of widening works between Hallam and Berwick by twelve months and they will now begin next year, he said.

The provision of on-off ramps on the bypass at the Berwick-Cranbourne road will begin during this year and be completed in 1990. Mr Kennan said the $2.5 million project would greatly improve access to the freeway from Berwick township.

It is incumbent upon me to point out to the House and to the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table, that the Australian Labor Party candidate, Mr Huggins, lost the election of 1988 to the sitting Liberal member, the Hon. Rob Maclellan. The obvious pork-barrelling by the State Labor Government just prior to the 1988 election has unfortunately not brought home the bacon. On 20 September 1988 Mr Kennan wrote a letter to Mr Max Pawsey, the City Engineer, stating that the Berwick bypass on-off ramps:

. . . with an estimated cost of $2.5 million, are being investigated by the Road Construction Authority for commencement of preliminary works in the current financial year. Major works will commence in 1989/90, with completion expected in the following year.

The on-off ramps were commenced not in 1988-89 but in 1990-91. Minimum expenditure has been made and several weeks ago the contractors vacated the site and removed all site establishment, including the toilets. There is nothing there to show any progress except two pylons and some minor abutment works.

I now refer honourable members to a media release issued by the Minister for Land Transport on 2 July 1990. The title of that press release was `Extra Lanes to Ease Traffic Flow at Berwick'. That media release read, in part, as follows:
The Federal Government has agreed to fund the construction of extra traffic lanes on the Princes Highway to alleviate traffic congestion between Berwick and Narre Warren, south-east of Melbourne.

The Federal Minister for Land Transport, Bob Brown, said a third lane would be built in each direction along a 4.7km section of the Princes Highway west of Berwick and westerly on-off ramps would be located at the Clyde Road/Princes Highway intersection.
Work is under way and will be completed next year at an estimated cost of $11.5 million, Mr Brown said.

A visit to the City of Berwick by Mr Brown in February of 1990 was part of the Federal election campaign to retain for the Labor Party the seat of La Trobe, which I now hold. It was another rolling of the pork barrel-perhaps a little repetitious. In late November 1989, the former member for La Trobe, Mr Peter Milton, contacted both the Minister for Land Transport and the then State transport Minister, Mr Kennan, to vigorously complain about the fact that the State Government had not honoured its pork-barrelling commitments from the 1988 State election and that Berwick was suffering. Among other things, Mr Milton was quoted in the local newspaper as making the following comments:
. . . although the roads corporation-
I note that Victoria keeps changing the name for its road construction authority-
had assured him the work would be finished within three years, he was unhappy that work due for completion this financial year would not be done.
Mr Milton said: `I am particularly concerned that the construction of run-off ramps into Brentwood Estate be finished as soon as possible.'

Berwick desperately needs the Princes Highway to have a third lane from the Hallam hotel to the Princes Freeway at Berwick on both sides of the highway, and off-road ramps are needed to cater for Brentwood traffic at the freeway interchange with Berwick-Cranbourne Road.

Mr Milton's efforts for intervention by the Federal Minister were appropriate, because the State Government road funding pork-barrelling promises had not been kept and the then member for La Trobe was under some pressure to hold his seat. I have to say that the former member's concerns regarding traffic bottlenecks and traffic flow were well justified, but the antics displayed at the time and the subsequent media release by the Federal Minister have not in fact achieved success. Mr Huggins did not win the State seat of Berwick, which was held by the Hon. Rob Maclellan. Mr Milton did not retain his Federal seat of La Trobe, which was won by me. We heard promises, promises-but then words are cheap, are they not?

Now we see that the works on the Princes Highway have been further delayed and the on-off ramps have disappeared. Perhaps the tooth fairy came and took away my on-off ramps. But then perhaps she took away the workers as well. The problem I have is that I gave away fairy stories a number of years ago, and I tend to doubt all that.

Obviously the State Government is deferring Federal Government funds intended for a specific road construction project to areas where it feels it might gain or retain a State seat. The redistributed State seat of Berwick, which is to be contested, I believe, by the failed former Treasurer of the State of Victoria, the Hon. Rob Jolly, needs only a 4.3 per cent swing to give the seat to the Liberal Party. It is my view that Mr Jolly has Buckley's hope of holding Berwick and I would think the Australian Labor Party sees that particular electoral situation in the same light. That being the case, somebody is playing funny games with Federal road funding dollars in order to win or retain some other State seat for the failed Labor Party that has bankrupted the State of Victoria.

With all that by way of background, I now turn the attention of the House to a critical bottleneck between the Mulgrave Freeway and the Princes Highway bypass of the village of Berwick which is to be nominally known as the Hallam-Narre Warren bypass, which is also fast becoming another political football which the Government does not want to know about.

In October 1990 an economic valuation report of the Hallam-Narre Warren bypass was prepared for the City of Berwick by expert consultants. In November 1990 that evaluation report was made available to me in order to assist me in making representations to State and Federal Ministers for a listing of the project as a priority road.

The problem we have is that this huge blockade in a major national transport artery has become another buck-passing exercise where no-one in either government wants to take responsibility and no-one wishes to give priority. From the evaluation report it is clear that if there were to be a review of Victoria's national roads program, the demonstrated priority, according to the Commonwealth criterion, of the bypass would be higher than that of projects such as the western bypass, the eastern arterial and the Greensborough bypass. I note, for the sake of honourable members and the Minister, that the Hallam-Narre Warren bypass has not yet been included in any forward strategy reports sent to the Commonwealth Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Beazley) under the Act.

Given the current recession-the one we had to have-it is imperative that road projects be pursued that will provide positive economic benefits not only to Victoria but also to Australia as a whole. Having a State that is on the downward slide economically is not beneficial to the productive health of the nation as a whole. The Hallam-Narre Warren bypass has potentially higher returns to Victoria than almost any other road project, and consequently has the potential to assist in the stimulation of the national economy. The five-year lead time for such a project makes the early inclusion of the bypass in Commonwealth and Victorian priority listings most urgent. The role of the bypass is to link the production areas of the growth corridor and beyond to Gippsland and to the interstate distribution system which is focused on the metropolitan area.

The bypass has the potential to reduce distribution costs for manufacturing and primary industry and facilitate tourism and release capacity on the Princess Highway east for local shopper and business traffic between Dandenong, Fountain Gate and Berwick. The Princess Highway to the east of Melbourne concurrently serves high volumes of commercial, interstate tourist and export production, including power, oil and paper industries in the Latrobe Valley; export and import replacement in the manufacturing sector; agricultural products, including fresh vegetables and dairy products; and international and interstate tourism to Mount Baw Baw, the Gippsland Lakes, Tasmania, via the Sea Cat, and other attractions.

The proposed Hallam-Narre Warren bypass would not only serve to promote these interests but would also provide an opportunity for a system of express commuter buses to serve the residents of the growth corridor who cannot reach the already overloaded and unreliable rail system. This factor will be of critical importance as the south-eastern growth corridor becomes developed and population levels move towards the 400,000 mark in the next 30 years. It is expected that traffic levels will grow from the present 40,000 vehicles a day to about 70,000 by the end of the decade. The thought of a 12-hour peak period on the Princess Highway is horrendous.

The estimated cost of the proposed bypass is in the vicinity of $57m in today's dollars. The anticipated construction period would indicate the project could be completed by the turn of the century. More than 60 per cent of the land required is currently owned by Vicroads with the remainder reserved under the local planning scheme for acquisition as subdivision takes place. The economic evaluation report concludes that the Hallam-Narre Warren bypass project would have a pay-back period to Victoria in economic terms of three years if the project were completed by 2001. Returns to this magnitude are considered rare in public infrastructure planning.

This road has the support of local government and the local community. I seek the support of the House and this Government in having the Hallam-Narre Warren bypass declared as a national arterial road and placed as a high priority for construction at the earliest possible date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91. During the past few months there has been much discussion about waterfront reform. There has inevitably been a lot of rubbish talk. Unfortunately, too many people, especially those on the Opposition benches, when they talk about waterfront reform, confuse it with reform of the Waterside Workers Federation. Anyone who knows anything about the waterfront realises that the waterside workers are only one aspect of the waterfront, one link in a very complex chain. When the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) threatens to put the troops onto the waterfront, does he have in mind that those troops are going to deal with all the complexities, such as the paper chase, the trucking queues and the late arrival of goods, which have nothing do with the waterside workers at all?

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, we do need reform on the waterfront. Who has been to the fore in promoting this? The very group that is abused by the Opposition and abused by much of the media in Australia. If honourable members do not think that this is so, they should look at the rubbish about waterfront reform that has been in the media during the past week. Most of the media commentators are as misinformed about the waterfront as are honourable members opposite.

A report released in February by the Association of Employers of Waterside Labour showed that between September 1983 and December 1990 labour levels fell by 647, with a further 490 employees marked to go by mid-March 1991. Furthermore, 600 workers retired with less than the agreed golden handshake. They were generally in such poor health that they were unable to wait until the enterprise agreements were finalised. Waterside workers recognise the need to lift production and bring Australian ports up to world standards.

In a secret ballot in October 1989 wharfies voted 4 to 1 in favour of the reform program. Performance indicators for June 1990 showed disputes were down and shipping delays halved in most ports. Consultation and negotiation, combined with rationalisation and streamlining of labour, unions and the stevedoring companies, is paying off. The interim stevedoring industry award, ratified by the Industrial Relations Commission last year, is the first step towards rationalising up to 20 different awards. It also provides true flexibility for the formation of enterprise agreements.

A review of job classifications with the aim of developing a new career path for all waterfront workers is nearing completion. The new classification will enable workers to become multi-skilled and will further increase productivity and dislodge some longstanding work demarcations. As an example, the elimination of the watchman classification-this has happened recently at Port Kembla-has resulted in 300 people leaving the industry, saving some $30m.

Mergers of the six main maritime unions are now well advanced. The waterside workers, the seamen, foremen, engineers, supervisors and the Merchant Service Guild of Australia have agreed in principle to form a Maritime Federation by 1992. At the same time, unions with only a few members on the waterfront are agreeing to transfer their members to the new Federation. This will greatly simplify negotiations and reform by creating a single bargaining unit. The objective of the agreement was to ensure a reliable, efficient and competitive industry. Prior to signing the agreement the unions had taken the initiative and created their own productivity schemes.

We hear many horrific stories about costs and delays on the waterfront. According to a recent report in the rural press, Australian shipping and stevedoring was so inefficient that it was cheaper to transport salt across the Pacific from Mexico than from South Australia. It claimed that this was exactly what one company had been forced to do. The report, which the Sydney Morning Herald leader writer took up as a further example of the Federal Government's failure to implement micro-economic reform, was raised in Parliament by the then shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson). There was only problem with this. When subjected to scrutiny the report was found to be wrong. Customs records show that Australia has never imported any salt, except for minute quantities of a very special variety used in medicines. None of this comes from Mexico. This is true of so many of these examples that members of the Opposition and others and leader writers of the papers trot out time and time again.

Myths about waterfront inefficiency abound. In fact, the Government's three-year reform program, aimed at improving waterfront productivity by 30 per cent, has already been exceeded in some terminals only 14 months down the track. At national Australian terminals, where a new enterprise agreement is already operating, labour costs have fallen by 34 per cent. Meanwhile, stevedoring costs at Australia's 19 grain terminals are down by an average of 70 per cent. In crude terms, productivity has so far been achieved by fewer people doing the same work.

During the past few months, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have had the opportunity to visit most of the ports in Australia, and let me tell you who is to blame for most of the delays on Australia's waterfront. Those who shout loudest about the inefficiencies on the waterfront are often those most to blame.

There is the chaotic system of paperwork. For example, the steaming time for a ship from Singapore to Fremantle is often only four days. Time and time again the ship will arrive at Fremantle before the paperwork does because of the antiquated paperwork system that we have. When the paperwork arrives, an endless paper chain then has to be gone through before the goods can be cleared. Of course, this delays the ship and delays the unloading of the cargo or its removal from the port. When honourable members opposite and others criticise, they never mention this. It is always the poor old wharfie who gets the blame, and time and time again it has absolutely nothing to do with the Waterside Workers Federation.

Do not overlook that good industrial relations term `the deliberately engendered dispute'. I have received a lot of evidence about deliberate delays on the wharf not caused by the wharfies but by businesses, and they do this for their own reason. Again, who inevitably gets the blame but the wharfies.

We hear a lot about the subject of demurrage. It is quite evident that at times consignors or consignees will choose to leave their containers at a terminal or depot because it suits their business requirements. Commercial interests, we are told, are supreme irrespective of the demurrage charge applied. One example I was recently given in Adelaide was of a refrigerated container with cargo that had come in from Europe. The shipping line wanted to turn that refrigerated container around because it needed it-we always have a problem here getting empty containers.

The shipping line wanted to use this container rather than having to ship an empty box across from some other part of Australia. The demurrage for that container started off at $25 a day-this was after the third day, because the first three days are free-then it was escalated to $75 a day because the shipping line wanted it moved. The cargo remained there in that refrigerated container not because the documentation was lost but because a particular client-a particular business-had a need to do so, and it was cheaper for it to pay $75 a day demurrage to leave it on the waterfront. But who got the blame? Again it was the wharfies. It had nothing to do with the wharfies. This is repeated time and time again.

The other interesting point on those charges relating to demurrage is that it is a common practice, as I have seen, for example, for a depot to apply a daily charge to a shipping line for boxes that are held after the three-day period. When these charges are then passed on to the shipper, the consignor or the consignee they are considerably increased. This does not show in the invoice that the shipper receives for the goods, so profits can be significantly increased by delays. If we use a unit rather than a dollar value ranging from one to 25, a shipping line may be being charged one to leave cargo there, but may be recovering 25. That is passed on and, of course, again the waterside workers always get the blame.

Let us turn to what waterfront reform is really about. As the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) said yesterday, the waterfront is a reactor. It does not make anything. It makes nothing at all. It does not build anything. It provides a service. People bring things to the waterfront by sea and take them away on land, or vice versa. The timetables are very much determined by those who use the waterfront, whether by sea or by land. It is not done by the waterfront. The waterfront reacts.

But what do we find? Exporters turn up at the waterfront after the deadline for a ship has closed, wanting to get boxes or bags on the vessels. Why are they not there on time? Usually they have a minimum of seven days notice, and often it is 10 days notice. Why did the cargoes not come in at an even pace over those seven or 10 days? Explain that to the exporters; explain to them why 90 per cent of the trucks that go onto the waterfront are empty and come out full, or go in full and come out empty.

Why are these exporters not getting a decent deal on transport service rates to and from the waterfront? Why have we got this nonsense going on there? Why is it that when goods come onto the waterfront they sit there waiting to be taken away? The first three days on the waterfront are free when goods come off the ship. Fifteen per cent of the goods go out on the first day; 20 per cent go out on the second day; and there is one almighty rush on the third day. All that rush generates a peak and generates congestion, and who gets the blame? Again, the wharfies.

The exporters will always tell us that everyone is tucked in behind the big shed-blame them. But, as exporters, they do not get their goods to the wharf on time, and they do not check with their agents to see whether they could get a better rate by having the goods there a few days early. As importers, they do not check whether they could get a dedicated time for their ship's arrival, so that they could get an even spread of ships arriving at the terminal thus reducing the peaks and the congestion. None of these things have been done. The truck queues are not caused by the wharfies, but by the shippers who cannot organise to get their cargoes to and from the ships. The farmers who scream loudest are among the worst offenders in this regard.

We have to have an efficient system for moving cargoes in and out of the ports. For some truckies-and I say this coming from a trucking background-payment for queuing is a convenient money earner. We have to stop this business of trucks unloading and then leaving empty. There has to be better coordination. There is truly little point in clearing the obstacles at the waterside if the ones at the wharf gate remain in place.

I know you know the answer to this, Mr Deputy Speaker, but it is interesting and I will mention it to the House: what is the most expensive aspect of the waterfront today? The most expensive aspect of the waterfront today is the tugboats. That is where the real cost is today. But do we hear this from the Opposition or from the leader writers in our national newspapers? No, we hear that the waterfront is the site of some of the worst work practice rorts, overmanning and inefficiency. But it is not the wharfies, it is the other players on the waterfront.

What is always missed out is that there are many players on the waterfront. We heard again yesterday about all these wonderful overseas ports, and that we are going to be compared with Rotterdam and Singapore. If there is to be a comparison between our ports-say, Port Kembla-and Rotterdam or Singapore, then give our ports the equipment and we will deliver the results. These comparisons are always very selective and members opposite are very selective in what ports they pick out in Asia too.

They should go to some of the ports in Thailand and a few of the other ports in Japan-go to Yokohama in Japan-not the few that they pick out. Singapore-that is all we hear. They should go round the ports of South East Asia and make a comparison with the Australian ports, even with the inadequate equipment that we have in the Australian ports. Give us the equipment in our ports-a couple of cranes and so on-and we will give the products.

The other point about making comparisons in connection with the waterfront is that it is not only the equipment but also the users of the waterfront. Would the business people of Singapore or Rotterdam go on with the nonsense that the business people in Australia go on with? Would they have all of their cargo come in late and things like that? If we are going to make these comparisons, let us compare apples with apples and compare the whole work, not just one aspect of the waterfront.

I must say that the hypocrisy of the Opposition about the waterfront is really amazing to me. Sometimes I wonder whether any of the honourable members opposite have ever visited the waterfront. I have never seen any of them wandering around Port Kembla and I know that the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) at the table has not seen any of them wandering around the Newcastle waterfront, as I was doing the other week. Their ideologically blinkered view distorts any rational debate with them regarding reform of the waterfront.

Despite all the waffle from Opposition members about the waterfront, has anyone ever heard them say anything except to criticise the wharfies? I have not heard of one plan-and I would like to hear of one from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)-from the Opposition to increase productivity on the docks. Why? Because it does not have any plans. The only plan it has is to bash the workers and to put the troops in there. It should just try putting the troops in there.

Honourable members opposite would be much more credible on waterfront reform if they could come up with their own plan for eliminating some of the waterfront practices of the users of the ports. For example, what would the Opposition do about the queuing, about time delivery of cargo, about electronic transfer of documents, about antiquated equipment? The Opposition will not speak of these issues because it has absolutely no policies on them.

Let me make it clear: no-one argues that sorting out the ports is easy. I am not saying that. But it is simplistic to think the problem lies only with the wharfies. The Waterside Workers Federation has been largely restructured, and it has done it without industrial disputation. If the Opposition wishes to talk of inefficiencies and rorts, it should look at the other users of the waterfront and lift its eyes above the waterside workers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst we have the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) at the table, could I briefly say that the excellent exposition on the needs for the Berwick bypass by my colleague the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) equally applies to the Eastern Freeway extension in Melbourne and to the Scoresby arterial, but I will not go into that at length. I would say to the previous speaker, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), that that was also an outstanding exposition on what is wrong with the waterfront-warts and all in all sorts of areas-but I remind him that it is his side of the House which is in government and it is his side of the House which is not fixing the problem. Why does the Government not fix it up? Why does the honourable member come in here and have a go at us?

SPEECH.PARA: We are here today to talk about Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, Appropriation Bill (No. 5) 1990-91 and Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1990-91. Appropriation Bill (No. 4) relates to the Gulf war funding, and we of course supported the Government in this. It is about a number of defence measures which are unfortunately tinkering, but tinkering in the wrong direction for the most part. A number of my colleagues have dealt with that earlier today in great detail. It is about funding for veterans' affairs overruns, small amounts for more training places, support for Austrade and for tourism and, finally, extra money for the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).

Appropriation Bill (No. 5) deals with funding for compensation to the States resulting from the new companies and securities regulation arrangements, pharmacy restructuring, disaster relief, compensation to Victoria-and I might add that Victoria needs compensating in a whole host of areas-in respect of new petroleum tax arrangements and the purchase of Telecom's shareholding in Aussat.

TALK.START.PARA: —You need sympathy, too.

—As the honourable gentleman at the front here says, we need a lot of sympathy down there as well. The last measure, the purchase of Telecom shareholdings in Aussat, is part of the Government's totally inappropriate telecommunications restructuring strategy, and we will be talking about that in the next couple of weeks in considerable detail, as I understand it.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier speakers from this side of the House have dealt in detail with a number of those measures, and they have also indicated that we will generally support these Bills, but we will be moving some amendments commenting on the Government's fiscal irresponsibility and economic mismanagement. My intention is to pursue some particular areas of the Government's legislation in more depth.

Firstly, I wish to briefly comment on ATSIC. I have to say, as a member of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs, as I have travelled around the country fairly extensively in the last few months with that Committee, that I am yet to be convinced that this extra layer of bureaucracy is actually worth the cost. It is a subject I will pursue on a separate occasion in this place.

I wish to concentrate on the Government's attitude to industry, the economy and especially to technology and science take-up in the manufacturing and commerce sectors. Having announced a number of policy changes in the last few months, the Government now seeks appropriate funding for some of these initiatives.

Since the statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) on 12 March we have seen other legislation resulting from that Building a Competitive Australia document. The Government has now clearly signalled its course. It has some of it right. It is going in the right direction in some areas, there is no doubt. But I believe it has wimped out on much that should be done. At least the Government has now signalled the areas of the new industry winners and has very specifically picked out some industry winners-the areas and the winners it proposes to back-so we know where we stand. These areas are resource-based industries, chiefly minerals and agriculture, and especially their value-added products; manufacturing and information industries; environmental research, technology and services and medical research and biotechnology. These choices in essence define the Government's view of where Australia should be earning its export dollars by the twentyfirst century.

I have nothing against any of these areas in particular but I would suggest that the missing ingredient in the scenario is the solution to the nation's most intractable problem, and that is how we are going to commercialise and capture the economic benefits of the clever products, processes and technologies of our scientists and engineers as they come up with them over the next 10 years.

The Government plans to offer ongoing tax concessions for industry research and development (R&). Why? If it reduces the general tax rate and if it reduces the level of business cost layers, surely this will far outweigh for all potential users the 125 per cent tax concession which inevitably has to come out of John Citizen's pocket.
The honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) on the Government side put it nicely when he said:
Australian manufacturing had no history of innovation of taking product development to international markets.

He went on to describe the Government's treatment of research and development as shabby. He said that its neglect in not encouraging the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) was one of its greatest failures. From the navigation system Interscan to the black box flight recorder, to the biotechnology breakthrough of gene shears and the Sarich engine, the list of Australian discoveries which failed to find a local backer and went offshore makes quite sobering, if not downright disquieting, reading.

The measures provided in the March industry statement to rectify this problem remain at the margin in the absence of cold hard cash to make it happen. I am not talking about hand-outs. The market has been starved of investment cash because of this Government's deliberate policy of high interest rates and its failure for eight years to control inflation. One can gut the economy, and if one does it often enough one does get lower inflation, and that is why we have it for the moment. But the trick will be to sustain it when we come out of the recession.

There is also the problem of industry attitudes. A recent study by the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce reveals that only one in three of our 16,000 manufacturing firms has made any significant investment in high technology and most of that, I might add, is for extra capacity rather than replacing the core machinery and technology that they have; so the core is gradually rotting away. Of course, high technology itself represents the biggest element in Australia's manufacturing balance of payments deficit. Most of the high technology that we do use has to be imported, and whilst the March industry statement attempts some measures to address both aspects of the problem-for example, as I have mentioned, the extended 125 per cent tax incentive for research and development and revised government purchasing procedures-it is by no means certain, in my view, that it will fix it or really go very far to help the situation.

I am pleased that the Government lays commendable emphasis on the need to upgrade national skills to handle the new technology and to develop a more competitive industry sector. However, to quote Julian Cribb in the Australian when he was commenting on the Prime Minister's March statement:
The statement boosts the opportunities for the `brightest and best' by enlarging postgraduate awards, but fails to address the deepening degradation of resources and facilities by the universities.

By their own estimates, the universities are almost $1 billion worse off in real terms than they were at the start of the 1980s, yet together with public organisations such as CSIRO, the Australian Nuclear Science &Technology Organisation, and the Australian Institute of Marine Science, they form the nation's fountainhead of cleverness-both in terms of people and ideas.

Yet this Government has consistently starved those organisations of funds. The Government should use its purchasing clout in information technology to support those who do the right thing in terms of exporting. It should not be handing out taxpayers' money only to professional research companies. There are a lot of information technology companies in this country which have been around for the last decade, surviving almost exclusively on handouts, which never actually produced anything that is commercially viable. It should not just be handing out taxpayers' money to those professional research companies; it has to concentrate far more on the development part of the R& and not just the research.

The Government is still into picking winners, quite clearly, and we have seen examples of that recently. What stuns me is this: did those on the other side not learn anything from John Cain and our very unfortunate experience in Victoria from picking winners? It was a proven policy failure and an absolute disaster. As I have said in this place before, the Government should be tackling the big issues, the things that will have a significant impact for the better, by encouraging innovation across the board. Until this happens this country will continue to go down the economic gurgler at an alarming rate.

The Government's role is to provide long term investment in research, in education and in human capital. It must educate management as well as the unions and it must assist with overseas marketing intelligence. Its role is not to pick winners by bringing a particular product or a particular process to market or the indirect funding of doing that with taxpayers' money. I am afraid that the Government's recent proposals are going to give us more public servants. It is proposing more boards and it is into making more Australian information technology just a simple subcontractor of overseas companies.

The partnerships for development program is unproven at best and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce is unfortunately very reticent about giving us any real information. At best it is unproven and is a sop to our ego, I suggest, at worst. Where is the evidence that it is worthwhile? Recently we have seen the introduction of fresh bounties-for example, the citric acid bounty, a fresh bounty for one particular company. Where is the lowering of protection that the Prime Minister promised us? Has the Prime Minister not actually misled the House on that matter?

Comfort measures in the information technology sector have also been increased. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean) has demonstrated his heavy interventionist line, which is a proven policy direction failure from the past. He has done nothing meaningful for Australian information technology companies. His rhetoric sounds fine, but it lacks substance, and transparently so.

The Government was given the four key areas which are vital to wealth creation in Australia in a report in 1989 by the Prime Minister's Science Council, which was entitled Resources for Science and Technology and their utilisation. I do not agree with everything in the report, especially its advocacy of picking winners. But I must say that I do agree with its basic analysis that Government policy needs to address four things: improving market knowledge; improving communications; building skills and competence; and setting future strategic priorities.

I ask the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown), who is at the table, to relay the following questions to the Minister for Science and Technology: does he know why Australian companies are shying away from Asian exports? Why does the Government not provide genuine market intelligence? Why has the Government not tackled the problem of dumping? Why does it not market Australia as a skills haven? Why has the Government not ramped up its training places much more during this period of high unemployment?

Young people in my electorate and around the country-my electorate is an outer eastern suburban seat in Melbourne; we get many young people looking for jobs because unemployment has more than tripled in the last 12 months-are looking to get their skills upgraded, trying to go to the technical and further education colleges and trying to get into Austudy and they are being turned away in their thousands. Apprentices are being laid off because the building industry is in a disastrous state. If they cannot get back into an apprenticeship within 12 months-and for many that just will not happen-they will never, therefore, qualify for their apprenticeship.

Where is the third runway decision to boost our tourist trade in Sydney? Apart from selecting a few particular projects-again, I suspect, winners-via cooperative research centres, how does the Government propose to create, and I will use the Prime Minister's favourite words, `the nexus' between the academic, scientific and business community? Surely business will invest only if it has confidence and sees a return for its shareholders.

I remind the Government that artificially contrived schemes will just collapse. Look at the Victorian Economic Development Corporation. I remind the Minister that what we need is not just scientific push going out to industry, but industry has to perceive, for sound commercial reasons, the need to pull ideas from the universities and from other R &D facilities. In this way it will be motivated to be committed to the process or product that is produced and actually see it right through to the end.

I ask the Government: where is its commitment to building skills and competence? Where are the strategic priorities? If one believes that picking winners is the right thing to do, it is still only a tactical approach. Where is the strategy? Where is the implementation of a vision by the Minister for Science and Technology?
