Where is the foreseeing of the tremendous growth in communications, in the quantum leap forward in transport technology or in the information industries? There has been no vision by the Minister for Science and Technology; there have been words, but no action.

Unfortunately, Australia will be reduced to the status of a south sea island unless the Government holds to its pledge to eliminate all tariffs for the manufacturing sector by 1996. There is no other choice, it is the only way forward. The idea that Australians can hide behind a protective barrier, build up industrial muscle and compete against the world I am afraid is an illusion. Australia must readjust its economic priorities to mesh into the Asia-Pacific Rim which will become-this is a very interesting statistic-the world's second largest market in the coming decade.

It is a mistake to try to spot or target industries and then find special niches for them in the fast growing Asian economies. Often people hold up Singapore as a good example. Places such as Singapore tried that strategy and failed, and they had to change their course. I accept that large amounts of public funds must be channelled into research and development. Australian companies, though, will not know what particular industrial areas they can excel in until they actually get out there, compete and start to have some successes. They cannot be picked too far in advance; there has to be a broad based attack and then some will succeed because some will inevitably fail.

Nobody could have foretold that with a small population Australia would throw up champion cricketers, golfers and, from time to time, champion tennis players and swimmers. But small countries can get out and compete. There are certain industries where Australia has a natural advantage because of access to raw materials which would be viable if our industries became competitive. But we have neither used this advantage nor made our industries competitive. What happens? The Japanese and Koreans import our iron ore to make steel and then compete with us by selling it worldwide. There is a whole range of industries based on our minerals which do not have to be transported vast distances just to add value. We can add value to them in Australia and then export them.

Our food processing industries-this is an area where we have great difficulty in terms of our food products-are another area of comparative major advantage. If we want to go in for it in a big way, we should not be exporting frozen meat, we should be exporting processed foodstuffs, such as television dinners and lunches ready for the microwave and made to Asian tastes. We should get out into the marketplace, research the market and see what is required. We should then package it, process it and ship it out and we would get far higher value and profit than just sending out the bulk quantities of frozen meat.

All of these things are possible, but it requires research and development and whole teams of research workers out in the field defining tastes and preferences and then having the product packaged differently for specific tastes. Whatever the field, we will not know until we have opened it up and it must be on a profitable and competitive basis, not with a prop from the Government.

The voters have seen this Government for what it is-a sham, which protects the inefficient and sacrifices the ordinary working man or woman in my electorate and in the rest of Australia. There are thousands and thousands of them out there. The official figures for unemployment are dramatically understated, as we all know.

Ultimately, this Government has simply failed the nation. I suggest that it needs a new Prime Minister, a new Treasurer and a new policy direction. Most Australians know this. Unfortunately for Australians it is symptomatic of this Government that it is so out of touch with what is happening in the real world that it simply does not recognise the depth of our plight nor is it prepared to respond with the necessary urgency. If the Government cannot change-and it shows little sign of doing so-then it should be prepared to resign and make way for a coalition Government that has the policies, the vision and the will to do what is so necessary for Australia and for Australians both now and in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Appropriation Bill (No. 4), the Appropriation Bill (No. 5), and the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) provide additional appropriations to meet the cost of additional commitments and expenses incurred by the Government since last year's Budget. These additional costs include $278.2m for defence outlays. This sum includes costs associated with Australia's contribution to the Gulf war.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity to publicly record the gratitude of the Australian people for all defence personnel who served in the Gulf during the recent conflict. During my visit to the Middle East in March this year, I was told by senior coalition commanders that Australia's service personnel were second to none in their professional capability and in their determination to successfully accomplish the task in hand.

Together with Senator David MacGibbon and Colonel Ross Bishop, I was privileged to visit HMAS Sydney and HMAS Westralia during patrol operations and to talk with many of the crew. I also had the opportunity to visit the Australian medical contingent on board the United States hospital ship Comfort.

The respect held by coalition commanders for Australian service personnel is testament to the good quality of training principles and procedures employed by the Australian Defence Force. There was excellent interoperability of Australian naval forces with United States (US) naval forces. RIMPAC exercises have proved to be invaluable training operations. Nevertheless, coalition warfare is an area that warrants more detailed study by both Australia and US defence authorities. This is to ensure maximum defence capability in the event of future conflict, when once again Australian and US forces will stand shoulder to shoulder to defeat an aggressor.

I note from the second reading speech by the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) that an additional $206.3m was appropriated for so-called `price movements and variations in progress on a number of projects, including payments for Anzac ships and submarine refit'. I have consistently stressed in this House the fundamental importance of maintaining an effective force of submarines as a strategic deterrent. It is a tragedy for Australia that the Government did not exercise the option it held to purchase two additional Collins class submarines. I sincerely hope, particularly for the young men and women of Australia, that this decision will not jeopardise the security of our country.

So it was with astonishment that I read recently that a member of the House claimed in a letter to his electors that he had `contributed to the Government's decision not to order two additional submarines, so saving Australia $800m'. He said that these savings would be available for more productive social and economic programs.

This statement is shameful. It is addressed in sanctimonious language. It is a boast that the defence capacity of this country will be weakened. With few exceptions, voters in my electorate would share my utter contempt for the statements expressed by this particular member of parliament. The people of my electorate, together with millions of other Australians, trust this Government to provide adequately for the defence of Australia. They also trust that their parliamentarians would never be involved, nor attempt to be involved, in any act or omission which would weaken Australia's defence forces. I know that I speak for the overwhelming majority of members of this House when I assure the people of Australia that, as elected representatives, I and others who share my views are determined, at whatever cost, to ensure that Australia has a Defence Force capable of protecting Australia, defeating an invader and contributing meaningfully as a responsible partner to the ANZUS alliance.

The appropriations for Defence also include an additional $29.6m for defence facilities and an additional $6.8m for defence housing. I congratulate the Government and the Defence Housing Authority on the tremendous work that has been done to upgrade defence housing stock throughout Australia.

Not long after I was elected, as a member of the Public Works Committee I visited Darwin, where I inspected a number of defence houses. The result of seven years of Liberal Party neglect was evident. No action had been taken to repair and maintain defence houses in Darwin. I believe the appalling housing conditions for defence personnel all around Australia were a major contributor to the widespread low morale which I found amongst Defence Force families at that time.

It never ceases to amaze me how any service personnel can vote for a Liberal or National Party candidate. Over the years, I have made a careful study of the performance of Labor and non-Labor governments with respect to the conditions of service of defence personnel, and it is consistently Labor governments who ensure by legislation that defence personnel are paid fair salaries, are adequately housed and are provided with attractive conditions of service, including retirement benefits. Non-Labor governments are tardy in providing these essential conditions of service.

I also note that additional money is provided for the welfare of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, including the sum of $8.2m for community development and employment projects. This scheme has been successful in many Aboriginal communities throughout Australia. It has been outstandingly successful at Palm Island, where unemployment is in excess of 90 per cent for a population of about 3,000 Aboriginal people.

The people of Palm Island endure chronic unemployment, inadequate health service, bad roads and a lack of other basic services but, most importantly, there is a chronic shortage of housing. The people of Palm Island need 100 new houses immediately. At present there are on Palm Island houses which have up to 20 people in occupation. Most houses on Palm Island would have about a dozen residents. This overcrowding causes enormous strain on family relationships, interferes with children's education and, in my view, is responsible for much of the social disruption on Palm Island.

I appeal to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner) for urgent funds to provide 100 additional houses on Palm Island for the Aboriginal people. It would be the most important contribution he could make to the welfare of Australia's largest Aboriginal community, located on Palm Island.

I have mentioned just a few matters to which, in my view, the Government should respond in a positive and substantial manner as soon as possible. I now turn to an issue which is causing great concern to the people of my electorate. This issue is the decision by Liberal and National parties to introduce a consumption tax, in the unlikely event of their coming to government. Opposition to the consumption tax proposal comes from a wide cross-section of people in my electorate-farmers and business people, defence personnel, students, retirees and the sick-and particularly from the women of my electorate. They do not want a consumption tax. Indeed, the Townsville Bulletin in its editorial on 4 September last year began with these words:
The last thing we need is more taxes.

If the Federal Opposition has its way, Australians will have no choice. They will be forced to endure a consumption tax. Pensioners, people on low incomes, and other Australians who are genuinely in need will loathe a consumption tax. They do not yet comprehend what they would be letting themselves in for under a Hewson-Fischer government. On 26 July last year, a report from Canberra, published in the Townsville Bulletin, read:
Opposition Leader, John Hewson, yesterday denied he was softening up the Coalition to adopt a consumption tax as official policy.
Less than one month later, on 16 August, the Australian reported:

After more than a decade of debate on the value of a consumption tax, the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, emerged from a marathon meeting of opposition MPs in Canberra to say it had been adopted as Coalition policy.

The Opposition Leader's earlier denial of the coalition's embrace of a consumption tax proved to be false, just as the coalition's economic policies overall are without substance and without benefit for all Australians.

Who could trust a Liberal-National government whose leader denied that a consumption tax was policy one month and then announced its adoption the next? Who could trust such a government to offer compensating payments to low and middle income earners? Even if it did, such a system would be a nightmare to operate, would cost billions of dollars and would add to the inflation rate.

Imagine the pressure on wages as the trade unions sought wage increases for their members to compensate for across the board price rises. Make no mistake, this would be one of the inevitable outcomes of a consumption tax imposed on the Australian people by the Liberal and National parties.

Above all, a consumption tax combined with $3 billion-or possibly more-in spending cuts as promised by the Liberal and National parties would be harsh in the extreme on the poor of Australia. It would cripple the welfare system, which is one of the most efficient systems anywhere in the world, thanks to the concerned positive actions of the Hawke Labor Government. A consumption tax would rip into Australians who can least afford it. It would be a tax on the Australian family and would reduce incentive; it would be a tax that would inhibit economic growth in this country. One only needs to look at the experience in Canada, where a goods and services tax has been introduced. There a bureaucratic nightmare has now emerged leading, it is predicted, to almost decades of legal battles in administrative courts and other courts over the interpretation of various sections of its goods and services tax.

I share the view of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who has consistently, to his credit, opposed the introduction of a consumption tax. Many people from time to time criticise the honourable member for O'Connor, but on a number of issues in speeches to this House he has made more sense than many other members I have heard from in more than eight years in this House. On this issue, the honourable member for O'Connor is right: a consumption tax is wrong as a tax system and is against the interests of entrepreneurs and business people who are willing to put in the hard effort and expect to be rewarded for that hard work through a fairer tax system. A consumption tax is not wanted by the people of Australia.

I am told that honourable members are to limit their speeches in this debate, but I wish to say a few words on the issue of welfare. The statements issued by the Liberal and National parties are causing me a lot of concern. I find they are willing to farm out the welfare budget to charity organisations and to use the private sector to pay social welfare benefits. The people of my electorate find that scenario horrendous. These intentions have been canvassed widely in the media, as early as October 1990 and more recently. I cannot understand why the Opposition is pursuing this objective, and there is no real evidence why it should, despite some of the rather bizarre writings on certain experiences in other countries, particularly the United States of America.

The distribution of the welfare budget by voluntary agencies would provide a Hewson-Fischer government with a way to wield the axe on welfare. It would take a Sherlock Holmes to recognise, identify and elaborate on government cuts in welfare spending. It is a sneaky way of cutting into welfare. Criticism of pruning would be easily diverted away from the Government into the laps of voluntary agencies. Most welfare agencies are chiefly urban based, so guaranteeing welfare delivery to regional Australia, particularly remote areas-areas that I represent-would be almost impossible. Protecting this private agency system advocated by the Opposition from corruption is something else again. Corruption in its various forms would be one of the inevitable outcomes of having numerous agencies making decisions on discretionary payments without dependable national standards. Welfare fraud and overpayment would be rife. In stark contrast to the Liberal and National parties, the Hawke Government expects to save up to $400m a year with greater use of computer cross-matching and accelerated claimant matching.
On 18 October 1990, Professor Stuart Rees of the Department of Social Work, University of Sydney, said:

Dr Hewson's ideas about the efficiency of transferring some of the responsibilities of the Department of Social Security to community welfare organisations represent a narrow view of welfare and a misunderstanding of the role of government.

Decades of advocacy of central governments' responsibilities were aimed at removing the stigmatising practices so beloved of the selfrighteous moralists of years ago. Dr Hewson's utterances suggest that such attitudes are still alive, even in the mind of a prospective Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us who wrote that letter, Ted.

—I will mention the honourable member in a minute. On the same day, Dr John Tomlinson, Director of the Australian Capital Territory Council of Social Services, spoke out in similar vein, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday's call by Dr John Hewson, asking Australians to consider abolishing the Department of Social Security and handing welfare functions over to the states and voluntary agencies to cut out duplication and deliver services locally, defies logic . . . His idea that voluntary agencies would handle the type of income-support functions now handled by social security takes no account of economies of scale, equity, equal distribution of services nor the complex nature of the Australian incomes security system. In remote areas where voluntary agencies have no presence many rural people would never be assisted. Senator Alston today argued that the database of personal details, which are collected by the department should be handed over to private firms which could then conduct reviews of beneficiaries and pensioners. This would destroy the confidential nature of these inquiries. I would think it would not be long before an even cheaper option would be proposed, such as the concerned citizens in the town rounding up all the pensioners and beneficiaries in the local community hall and subjecting them to a kangaroo court inquisition about their personal and financial difficulties.

Those financial difficulties would be severe enough, but add them to the burden of a consumption tax forced upon the nation by a Liberal-National government, and we discover suffering in the extreme. The expanse of hurt caused by a consumption tax in Australia would not be confined to welfare recipients and pensioners. Indeed, farmers, part time and self-employed workers would not be fully compensated. This is very evident, particularly for people in North Queensland.

I conclude on this note: the Hawke Government has tightened the tax system since 1985 to ensure that all taxpayers pay their full share in such a way as to avoid making the lower income earner suffer. The expanding tax base has alleviated the need for a consumption tax-if indeed there ever was a need. The capital gains tax, fringe benefits tax, substantiation requirements, the prescribed payment system and increased audit activity by the Australian Taxation Office have all contributed to this particular process. I am saying here and now that the coalition leadership is working on a consumption tax of 15 per cent. That is the kind of tax it will introduce in the unlikely event that it gains government. It is going to affect millions of Australians. It is going to reduce the standard of living of the poor of Australia particularly, and expose them to economic hardship. A consumption tax or a goods and services tax-call it what you like-is not a painless answer to Australia's economic well-being. In fact, it will be an economic disaster and cause social misery for millions of Australians.

Finally, I urge the people of Australia at the next election to make a judgment between the parties of Australia. One party, the Liberal-National party coalition, stands for the introduction of a consumption tax and for the privatisation of welfare services. One party, the Australian Labor Party, is opposed to the consumption tax. It supports the continuation of the delivery of welfare services by the Department of Social Security and other government organisations. It stands for the increased economic well-being of the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before commencing my speech on the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1990-91, I cannot let go by the opportunity to comment on the speech of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay). The goods and services issue will be sorted out in due course. I am sure that the views of the Opposition on that issue will be presented in a full and proper manner before the next election. I also wish to address an issue that the honourable member mentioned with respect to service people when he said he did not believe that any service people could support the Opposition. I point out to him that all three returned service people in this House happen to be on the Opposition side.

SPEECH.PARA: He raised the issue of the safety and security of our country, and said that the Government would not allow it to fall below acceptable levels. I would point out that the regular Defence Service personnel in this country today are outnumbered two to one by a crowd at the Melbourne Cricket Ground. The infantry that we could put into the field within three months is outnumbered 20 to one by the paid-up members of the Collingwood Football Club. That puts into perspective the situation of our defence forces at the present time.

I will return to my speech. I welcome the opportunity to speak in the debate on these Appropriation Bills and I will use this time to discuss a number of concerns I have with the economic policies and direction of the Hawke-Keating Government. I find this Government's approach to solving economic problems fascinating-in fact, I find the Government's approach to solving economic problems quite unbelievable. I do not understand the logic behind this Government's approach to economic policy, and I do not understand how a Labor Government can be such a generous friend to big business and yet have policies which are so oppressive to small business.

The Government's record is one of double standards. Since its election in 1983 this Government has been a good friend of big business, an even better friend of the trade union movement and the trade union bureaucrats and an outright enemy of small business. Yet it was small business that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) called `the engine room' of the Australian economy when he wrote to small businesses in my electorate during the 1987 election campaign. It would be a gross understatement to say that the Treasurer's rhetoric has not been matched by his actions.

This Government has very close links with the trade union movement. The Government speaks of the accord. I speak of the Government's betrayal of its duty to the Australian people. This Government's links with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) go far beyond what is acceptable to the majority of ordinary Australians.

When Australians elected the Australian Labor Party (ALP) to office they did not expect, or want, the ACTU to play such an important and decisive role in the decision making process of government. But, of course, the ALP must pay back favours to its mates in the unions-at ALP preselections union representatives comprise 60 per cent of delegates. The Government should govern for all Australians, not just for its mates in big business or for its very good mates in the union movement.

This Government, as part of an expansive micro-economic reform package, should be thinking about saving jobs and creating jobs. The Government's figures grossly understate the level of unemployment facing this country-the problem is far worse than the Government will admit. The Government's statistics do not tell the real story-that many businesses cannot afford to pay redundancy packages so they keep their doors open until, finally, they go to the wall. This is of course detrimental to the workers because they do not get their redundancy payments and, in many cases, they do not even get their holiday pay. Yet, to protect its mates in the union movement, the Government refuses to discard the centralised wage fixing system that belongs to an era long past.

Unemployment should be a major concern of the trade union movement and a Labor government, but it is not. The Hawke-Keating Government and the ACTU do not care about the thousands upon thousands of Australians who are becoming unemployment statistics. They do not care about the thousands and thousands of young Australians who are being denied the opportunity of finding a job when they leave school-and all this is part of the Treasurer's recession that we had to have. It is all a part of the recession which, to start with, this Treasurer said was not going to occur. The Treasurer's incompetence never ceases to amaze me. I urge honourable members to read the Treasurer's rhetoric in last year's Budget speech. Page 1 states, `Economic policy has worked and is working'. If it was not so serious it would be laughable.

At this stage I wish to bring to the attention of honourable members some statistics concerning youth unemployment in my home town of Melbourne. Last week Senator Michael Baume, the shadow Minister for youth affairs, released figures which stated that the level of youth unemployment in Melbourne is grossly understated by the Government's figures. Senator Baume's figures suggest that the real level of unemployment in Melbourne for people aged 15 to 19 years is around 45 per cent and not the 27 per cent claimed by the Federal Government. Young Australians, and in particular young Victorians, can thank the incompetence of the Federal and the State Labor governments for this national disgrace. For too many young Australians `the lucky country' is something that they will only read about in history books.

The Treasurer knows very well that significant changes are required in the labour market if we, as a nation, are to improve our productivity and consequently improve the prospects for employment. However, he also knows that the radical reforms required will always be vetoed by the institutional forces built into any Labor government-the union movement.

If we are to advance into the next century and become part of the world economic community, we must move away from the current centralised wage fixing system and adopt a system of enterprise bargaining-real enterprise bargaining and not the enterprise bullying that this mob speaks of. But while we have this Government in office, its accord with the trade union movement will remain a barrier to all worthwhile reforms.

As one who comes to this place with first-hand knowledge of industry, I am aware of the current crisis facing industry and, in particular, the manufacturing sector. In this instance I am speaking about small manufacturing industry. It is weighed down by an antiquated labour system; wages are determined by a centralised system with little reference to productivity; work practices belong in another century; taxes are ever increasing; and business confidence is at an all-time low. The current system is closing down businesses at an unprecedented rate and as a result unemployment will continue to increase.

Bankruptcy figures released on 24 April reveal that between January and March this year 3,434 businesses in Australia folded or went into voluntary arrangements. The Treasurer must realise that behind every one of these bankruptcies there are many people who have lost their jobs, their homes and, in many cases, their families-so the problem is of a much more serious nature.

It is of particular interest to note that the States with the biggest increases in bankruptcies all have Labor governments. Victoria recorded a 75.2 per cent increase, Queensland had a 60.2 per cent increase while Western Australia had a 59.1 per cent increase. For the people who have lost their businesses and the people who have consequently lost their jobs, the Treasurer's recent talk of a recovery is a cruel hoax.

Other micro-economic reforms which are required in order to boost this nation's productivity must include changes to work practices. In this speech I wish to highlight some of the rorts which occur on the Australian waterfront. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), has, in the past, highlighted the following rorts: in 1991, two drivers are still required to operate a crane that has one seat and three levers; in 1991, waterfront gangs still draw for `nick-off' days where the lucky winner can return home on a full day's pay; in 1991, 14 waterside workers still front up to perform the task of bulk unloading of commodities-a task which actually needs just three workers; in 1991, dust allowances, hot weather allowances and wet weather allowances are still paid to drivers who are operating in closed air-conditioned cabins; and in 1991, two extra `spare' men are still employed on each vessel in some ports and these `spare' men have no jobs and are not allowed to be employed, even if a job arises during their shift.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is outrageous!

—It is outrageous. What an amazing story to place before this House and, unfortunately, these examples of rorts are not isolated cases. They all impact on Australia's productivity, they all have a major impact on wages and the costs are inevitably passed on to the consumer. Waterside workers are a privileged class in Australia and this Government has extended those privileges.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1989-90 financial year the average weekly earnings for wharfies had climbed to $750.36 per week against the all-industries average weekly earnings of $542.30. They have since climbed to $824 for the year ended 31 March 1991. For this amount they actually worked an average of 26.7 hours per week. On top of that, their superannuation arrangements have employers contributing 12.65 per cent of base wages compared with 3 per cent employer contributions in most other industries.

What does the industry get in return for such excesses? Sadly, the answer is complete inefficiency. Container movements on Australian wharves are 12 an hour while in Singapore there are 25 an hour and in Taiwan there are 30 an hour. If the Port of Melbourne were to double its efficiency, it would still be considerably less efficient than the Port of Singapore. The source of this information is the Victorian Minister for Industry, David White-a Labor Minister-who has pointed out that it takes between 103 to 107 separate pieces of paper to shift one container in the Port of Melbourne. While this inefficiency flourishes, the Hawke Government procrastinates about reform and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) stitches up further pay increases for his mates on the wharves.

At the beginning of my speech I said that this Government was out of touch with the problems facing our economy. It has put the cart before the horse. It expects the recovery to come from the private sector, yet it does nothing but hinder its progress. When is this Government going to start removing some of the obstacles facing industry in this country? When is it going to do something about the many taxes and charges confronting businesses? Company tax, trainee guarantee contribution tax, sales taxes, taxes on bank accounts, long service payments and holiday pay loadings-the list is endless. Add to these the many taxes and charges levied by State Governments, such as payroll tax and Workcare costs, and one is talking about an economic nightmare for small businesses in this country. This Government has displayed a total lack of desire to implement any worthwhile reforms. To the contrary, the Government has added to the burden.

To illustrate my point, I refer honourable members to a report in the Melbourne Sun-Herald of 19 April 1991 where the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) is reported to be calling on employers to offer bonuses to workers with good attendance records in an effort to discourage sickies. The Minister was also reported as supporting the idea that workers suffering from alcohol and drug problems should be given paid leave to get treatment. The Minister is obviously totally unaware of the costs already facing small businesses-he totally disregards or has no knowledge of the fact that each day businesses are closing their doors, many as a direct result of this Government's policies.

In conclusion I state quite clearly that Australia is facing a crisis. It is unquestionably the worst small business crisis since the Second World War and irreparable damage has been done to the small business community by this Government. At the same time we are facing the worst rural crisis since the 1930s. Unemployment is exploding with many young Australians facing the bleak prospect of dole queues. The Australian dream of owning one's own home has been taken away from many Australians and our standard of living is declining at a rapid rate. Our gross foreign debt has grown to $165 billion with every Australian now owing $9,114 as part share of this debt.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unbelievable.

—It is unbelievable, as the honourable member for Parkes says. Servicing this debt costs 20c in every dollar of export income. All of this is a legacy of eight years of Hawke-Keating mismanagement. The only areas growing in the Australian economy are government, bureaucracy, liquidators and second-hand auctioneers. The only other growth area in this country is the ego and sheer arrogance of the Treasurer. I find it fascinating that the members of the Labor Party are even considering replacing the Prime Minister with the Treasurer.
—They must be desperate.

—I think they are. It symbolises to me how out of touch the Labor Party is with the ordinary Australian community. I challenge the Labor Party to go ahead with its leadership coup. The next election with Prime Minister Hawke at the helm will be a wipe-out for the ALP--
—Kerin wants a go!

—He may want the job, too, as the honourable member says; however, with the Treasurer in the Lodge, it would be the greatest electoral defeat in the history of the ALP and I would welcome the opportunity to witness the holocaust.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment tonight on the International Wool Secretariat (IWS). In this regard I am delighted that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has come into the House especially to hear my speech. The farming community is concerned that too much money is being spent in this area and that the IWS is becoming too remote, servicing the elite end of the market-the West European cocktail circuit. There is a feeling that perhaps Australia should pull out, go it alone on promotion and promote only Australian wool.

SPEECH.PARA: Before we consider these issues seriously we should look at what the IWS has done in the past, particularly in light of the serious plight of the woolgrowers today. The aim of the IWS is to improve the long term income of woolgrowers by increasing worldwide demand for wool. The IWS was founded in 1937 with three original members; namely, Australia, South Africa and New Zealand. In 1970 Uruguay joined that trio, and between the four of them they now supply 80 per cent of all wool traded internationally.

It is interesting that 97 per cent of Australia's wool production is exported, although most of the wool we use domestically is actually imported because of our small carpet wool production. The headquarters of the IWS are in London, though it has its process and product development centre in Ilkley in Yorkshire. It also has an international wool fashion office in Paris, which serves all the apparel fashion services, and at Delft in Holland it has its knitting and styling workshop. Altogether it has 40 operating branches around the world, divided into five main areas; namely, America, Asia, western Europe, eastern Europe and developing countries. In total it employs 950 staff, so it is a big operation. It is concerned overall with product development, styling, fashion, product marketing, publicity, market information, planning and quality control. In other words, it is involved at all stages of the processing and distribution wool pipeline.

The IWS is an unincorporated association of the four wool boards or corporations of the countries I mentioned earlier. The constitution it now works under was finalised on 16 September 1986 and is subject to English law. It has a couple of spin-offs: the IWS Nominee Co. Ltd, which holds the assets of the IWS and also the Woolmark registrations, and it has the Wool Development International Ltd, which is concerned with the sale, distribution and licensing of technologies and equipment developed from the research centre at Ilkley.

It is worth looking at the IWS board. It has a chairman, currently Hugh Beggs, who will step down shortly. The arrangement whereby the Chairman of the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) is the chairman of the IWS has been in place since 1961. As well as that, there are 13 other members of the board. Six of them are Australians, coming from the Australian Wool Corporation, three from New Zealand, three from the South African wool board and one from Uruguay. I think it is remarkable that this board only meets once a year. There is, of course, a board committee of nine members plus a non-voting managing director. The chairman of the IWS heads the board committee. There are four other members, one from each member country, and four other members on top of that, two of whom come from Australia, so that Australia provides at least four of the nine members. They meet five times a year. Their job is to run the functions of the board in between the annual meetings of the IWS board proper.

That IWS board has various committees under it. I realise this is getting very complicated, but it is worth outlining this. There is a board committee, an audit committee, a research policy committee and a research and development coordination and advisory committee. The Australian members have the job of reporting back to the Wool Council and the Wool Corporation on a regular basis.
In his very useful report, Sir William Vines makes certain comments on the IWS-AWC relationship. He says that that relationship is largely harmonious but that:
From time to time there have been strains at staff levels on specific issues.

He refers to comments that the Wool Council made of the IWS. He said that it has concerns about `the economic capability of the IWS' and `the objectivity of certain statistical indicators of performance'. He also says that IWS staff have various complaints about the Wool Council. They have complained that `the AWC's attempts to influence them can be excessive' and that `the AWC staff do not always have a correct understanding of international marketing and promotion issues'. In addition to this, the Vines committee considers that `the board of the IWS has not provided effective direction and oversight of the organisation'.

The Vines committee also believes that the IWS board structure does not serve the organisation well and points out that most of the functions of the IWS board have been delegated to the IWS board committee, which I spoke of earlier and which meets five times per year. Vines says:

It is apparent that the Board has failed to provide on a continuous basis the degree of guidance, direction and oversight of the organisation that would be regarded as necessary and normal in a commercial company engaged in a similar business. The problem has been exacerbated by the practice within the AWC of rotating membership of the IWS Board. Further, because all members of the Board and of the Committee are resident in the Southern Hemisphere, they cannot be in touch on a regular, continuous basis with the markets in which the IWS operates.

I think that is a very important quotation. He goes on to say that the membership has a strong grower bias and that the committee strongly believes that the IWS board should, in the main, be comprised of people with proven skills in international marketing and promotion, finance or the management of large international organisations. Further he says:

The Committee considers it inappropriate for the Chairperson of the AWC to be also the Chairperson of the IWS. There is a clear conflict between the two positions which must make it difficult for the Chairperson of the AWC to be critical of policies in IWS or of its performance.

Vines goes on to recommend that the IWS board be made up of 13 members. He says that there should be eight core members, three coming from the Australian Wool Promotion Committee. Of course, that will not be set up; it will be a sort of AWC mark 2. He says that the views of those three should always prevail. Naturally, they will be Australian members. He says that it is important that they come from those skilled in marketing, promotion, finance and international business-in other words, they will not be necessarily grower members. Of the other five members of that core committee, he says that two should come from the New Zealand Wool Board, two from the South African Wool Board and one from the Uruguayan equivalent.

He also makes the interesting recommendation that three members be appointed from the Northern Hemisphere who are experts in marketing, finance, textile industry or multinational business. In particular, he recommends that one come from western Europe, one from North America and one from North Asia. He says that the chairman should come from those three Northern Hemisphere countries and be elected on stature and suitability. The chairman would not have a casting vote. That is a very interesting recommendation because there would be many in Australia, particularly amongst Australian woolgrowers, who would perhaps feel uncomfortable that we would be losing control of the IWS board if that took place.

He also recommends that a managing director be appointed by the board to sit on the IWS board, so there would be 12 in total. Their job would be to monitor the performance and assess the success or failure of the IWS's specific programs and activities. Sir William Vines makes further recommendations on what will become the Australian Wool Corporation mark 2 and the Wool Council-that they `ensure that growers are as well informed as possible about IWS objectives and performance'. I would concur with that entirely. That has fallen down in the past.

Further, he states that `the IWS be responsible for wool promotion in Australia' instead of the AWC doing that, as has been the case in the past. That is a sensible recommendation, although I would not want to see that Australian promotion section subsumed or overshadowed, if we are to be included in the wider Asian sector. That is something to be looked at.

Vines also recommends that woolgrowers should be enabled to vote on any proposed changes to the apportionment of the wool tax. He says that this would give added accountability of the IWS and would give growers the power of veto over changes to IWS funding levels. That suggestion has merit, although before I would fully endorse it we should look carefully at the cost of doing that. I know that in the meat marketing area it costs the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation about $100,000 just to maintain the register, so we would not want to rush headlong into such a proposition without looking at it carefully.

Australia's contribution to IWS funding comes from 3 1/2 per cent of the total levy charged to woolgrowers. That tax levy is devoted to promotion. In 1989-90, total IWS funding from all countries was $261.4m-a considerable amount of money. Of that, Australia contributed $188.6m, or 72.3 per cent of the total budget; New Zealand contributed $50.8m, or 19.5 per cent of the budget; South Africa contributed $19m, or 7.3 per cent of the budget; and Uruguay contributed $2.2m, or 0.9 per cent of the budget. There was a residual adjustment of 0.8 per cent. If that total amount is translated into what it costs each of the 60,000 Australian growers, on average each grower is paying $3,000 per year to the IWS. As some people are running only 10 or 20 sheep, obviously the average dinky-di grower is contributing much more. When at least $60 per week is outlaid to the IWS, a grower would be entitled to know something about how it is functioning. That has not been the case in the past.

If one interviewed the average Australian grower on what he knew about the IWS, one would find that he knew very little because he has heard very little back in the past. The IWS has a base budget amount. It has a matrix system of funding and an additional funding segment. Vines comments that this is very complex and difficult to administer and should be simplified. That idea may well have merit. The IWS has undertaken in recent months a new promotion strategy. Previously it was putting about two-thirds of its effort into value and one-third into volume building, but that percentage has been reversed due to the recent collapse in the wool market.

Vines, in commenting on the IWS, makes some other interesting observations. He talks about the Woolmark, which, of course, is used on pure wool products that are sold. He says that the Woolmark is rarely used on casual lines and rarely used on lines that go out into the young market-the teenagers and 20-year-olds-which is the large volume market. That is something to be very mindful of.

Vines makes a comment on one of the people who put submissions to the inquiry. That person said that what was needed was a `snappier, more colourful and fashionable' image. Vines, in dealing with that in his report, said that perhaps we need a new Woolmark in this country. We do have a wool blend mark, which can be used when a garment has 55 per cent or more of wool in it, but that is rarely used and not too many people know about it.

Nowadays, with new technologies, wool can play an important part in a garment which has as little as 20, 30 or 40 per cent wool. Vines recommends that we look at instituting a Casuwool mark, which would be used for the more casual products, and wool could then get the credit for the percentage that it contributes. We could have a Casuwool 30, Casuwool 40 or Casuwool 50, for example, for a 30, 40 or 50 per cent wool contribution. That would supplement or perhaps replace the wool blend mark, which is not used so much now. That idea has considerable merit and I would certainly endorse it.

Some have been very critical of the IWS and have made comments, for example, that more marketing innovation is needed. Of its total $261m funding, 51 per cent-in other words, $133m-goes into advertising. It is pertinent to contemplate that that is three to four times greater than the amount Qantas Airways Ltd spends or that is spent on Foster's beer.

Wool needs positioning in the market with advertising campaigns more than it has been. We should be looking to set the image for wool for the next 10 years. People have commented to me that too much money goes on busybodies running around the world promoting wool in an inappropriate fashion, which ends up selling very little extra wool. Some say that private research people involved in processing wool in Italy, for example, are well ahead of what is done at Ilkley and that the people at Ilkley are, in a sense, reinventing the wheel, even with a product like cool wool. Another person has commented to me that spinners and knitters are being bribed to use the Woolmark symbol and that we need greater coordination in what is happening with marketing around the world so that we do not waste some of this money.
In my final comments I would like to get back to the information available within the IWS not getting back to the growers. The IWS report to 30 June 1990 says:

Wool also lost competitiveness against other fibres in some important markets, particularly the US and Western Europe, as earlier wool price increases fed through the textile manufacturing and retail systems. This was reflected in increased fibre substitution in blending.

The report was referring to the 1989 year. Had growers known about that and had they also learned that the market for textiles as a whole was weakening and that there was a declining interest in fashion evident amongst many consumers-had that sort of information been getting back-I do not think there would have been the headlong rush into wool that we saw in this country.

There is no doubt that the wool industry should be looking for new ideas and new textures to give it a marketing edge into fibre competition. More fibre blending has led to new effects and new synthetic fibres are coming out, including what are called the microfibres. All this is putting pressure on pure wool and on the Woolmark merchandising. United States wool usage halted because of the trade reaction to the higher prices, as happened in the developing countries. All this is reported in IWS reports, but it has not been getting back to growers. Had that information got back clearer and earlier than it did, I think we would not have had the trouble we have had.

In conclusion, in deciding over the coming weeks how we will structure the wool industry for the future, I believe it is vital that the role of the IWS be properly defined and considered if the full potential of the promotion and marketing dollar that the Australian woolgrower contributes is to be fully realised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the feelings of the last speaker, the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), but I feel I should say one or two things. I agree very much with many of the things he said about the International Wool Secretariat (IWS). As he well knows, the Government is well and truly at arm's length from that organisation and the only influence that the growers have had has been through the Australian Wool Corporation and thereby through its members' membership of the IWS board.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that Sir William Vines has made many observations about the International Wool Secretariat. Part of the reason I have established a new Australian Wool Corporation is so I could give it the key job of looking at all questions relating to marketing and promotion. There is under way a restructuring of the International Wool Secretariat that has come about mainly because of some shortage of funds-New Zealand's funds are down $20m this year, for example-but there has been a need for a reorientation for some time.

A lot of work is now going into the middle market and into trying to draw the IWS together. I feel as frustrated as the honourable gentleman does, because there is no way that he, I or the growers can directly influence the IWS. I would not say that the Corporation has been making anything other than its best efforts, but we simply have to do better. Any criticism, as has been put forward by the honourable member for Parkes, should be regarded by everyone as being quite constructive.

I believe that the Research and Development Corporation, as part of the new structure, being to one side of the old Wool Corporation and the new Wool Corporation, will have a much bigger influence in driving the necessary marketing research, as well as production and textile research, so that growers and the board of the new Corporation are far better equipped to deal with the International Wool Secretariat under the new arrangements.

For a long time I have had the view that there have been gaps in the way information has been passed backwards and forwards and that we needed a more cohesive structure. In addition, with the Australian Wool Industry Council, for the first time, other than with the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council, all the players and actors in the Australian wool industry, including exporters and people with overseas connections who understand what is happening in the marketplace out there in the world where we sell our wool, will have a role and an input. I think a lot more information will come through in that way.

There has always been a fear by many people in the wool producing industry that these people have a vested interest in getting at them somehow and taking an edge on a market with the information they obtain. But very little information leaked out of the Interim Wool Industry Policy Council and, if we can focus on some of those generic issues in the new Wool Industry Council, with the right information flows, growers will have a little better idea of what is being done on their behalf. I certainly hope that we get that situation, because what the honourable member has pointed to concerns many people.

There are always many allegations about money being wasted on research. I have always taken the rather robust view that one cannot do good research without wasting a bit of money. There has been an allegation around that people have been bribed to use the Woolmark. I can find absolutely no evidence of that at all. When Dr John McPhee, the Director of the International Wool Secretariat, was out here recently, he explained how that may have arisen, but from what I can find from other sources there is no truth in that.

I make one other point, on behalf of the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray). I would like to provide some information in response to a request from the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor), who sought further explanation of an item of proposed defence expenditure. That additional $29.6m required for defence capital facilities is attributable in the main to the general downturn of the building and construction industry. The downturn has resulted in much keener competition among contractors and subcontractors, leading to shorter construction periods being achieved across the board. In addition, the continuing commercialisation of the Department of Administrative Services' Australian Construction Services has led to significantly improved performance in the design and tendering of defence facilities. In other words, the Department of Defence has been able to spend the funds appropriated for capital facilities more quickly than anticipated at Budget time. I trust that that explanation is of help to the honourable member who raised the question.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991[COGNATE BILLS:SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991SOCIAL SECURITY (REWRITE) TRANSITION BILL 1991]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 April, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand it is the wish of the House to debate this Bill concurrently with the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 and the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991. There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY (JOB SEARCH AND NEWSTART) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Braithwaite Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight this House is debating three social security Bills-the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill, the Social Security Amendment Bill and the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill. I would like to deal with each of these Bills separately. Firstly, I refer to the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill. This Bill seeks to replace the current regime of income support to the unemployed with a new approach that was announced in February 1990 in the economic statement just prior to the election of that year. Unemployment benefits will be replaced by an expanded Job Search allowance-currently available only to those under 18 years-for all persons unemployed for up to 12 months and thereafter by a restructured Newstart allowance. The intended start-up date is 1 July 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: The changes represent the centrepiece of the Government's so-called active employment strategy which is designed to provide more active income support for the unemployed, with recipients being required to undertake training and other relevant activities in exchange for payment. The approach marks a shift from traditional passive income support. Job Search allowees who have been registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service for 12 months will be permitted to go onto the Newstart allowance. However, the transfer will not be automatic, as an application will need to be made.

Despite the second reading hyperbole of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), on behalf of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson), that the Bill would implement one of the most significant changes to the Australian system of social security since the 1940s, it falls far short of a truly active employment strategy for welfare recipients. In many respects, it merely formalises existing practices. For many of the unemployed it will be largely business as usual.

Under the Government's economic policies unemployment is forecast to rise further as more and more businesses fail, interest and inflation rates rise, our productivity and competitiveness decrease and the Australian Labor Party kowtows to the demands of the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

This Government's March industry statement failed to show any understanding of the magnitude of Australia's current problems. It supplied no new forecasts which would reflect the seriousness of our situation. It offered no explanation as to what went wrong in the past. It offered no adjustment to macro policy. Sadly, Labor's economic policies continue to provide for growth only in unemployment, insolvency and foreign debt.

I would like to mention here the Government's current attitude towards employment of people with disabilities. Sheltered workshops around the country are under threat of de-funding because they do not meet the principles and objectives of the Disability Services Act. My colleagues and I have received many letters from parents and service providers protesting about the Government's quiet phasing out of these much needed services. I believe that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), who is at the table, would have received these complaints also. They all say the same thing.

Whilst the aim of encouraging people with disabilities to live and work in the community with minimum supervision is laudable, it is not a practical answer to the overall problems, as it does not take into account the present rate of high unemployment, which, in the unlikely case of job availability, would naturally favour the able-bodied and able-minded applicant. It does not take into account either the difficulties faced by the handicapped employee who, in the case of failure to adjust to either an everyday workplace or social situation, does not have the security of the sheltered workshop to return to in times of trouble. Instead, responsibility would fall back onto the parent. Without organised activity and social contact that failure would become a repeated but gradual pattern of regression.

The Disability Services Act does not take into account the needs of the profoundly and intellectually handicapped, whose skills and behaviour levels, despite intensive training, will never, now or in the future, reach a high enough standard to enable them to live or work independently in the community. When will the Minister listen to the parents and skilled service providers and ease their fears by stating categorically that there is, and always will be, a need for sheltered workshops for some of the people with disabilities and ensure their continued funding?

There is an inconsistency with, on the one hand, one Minister stating that jobs are universally available to people with disabilities and yet denying these people access in the Public Service and in his own Department and, on the other hand, another Minister making provision for a huge influx of able unemployed because the jobs are just not available.

I return to this Bill. Although it is relatively long-but, I am pleased to say, in the new plain English style-much of it is taken up with a restatement of existing practices but under new names. The main features are as follows. The first one is that allowances are to be open ended. The maximum time a client can spend on the Job Search allowance will be 12 months, but there will be no time limit on the Newstart allowance. Unlike the practice in many other countries, this new approach continues to allow indefinite receipt of income support, albeit after jumping a few more low hurdles. The principle of potentially permanent receipt of what was originally intended to be a temporary or transitional payment between jobs fundamentally changes the nature of the benefit, and will send misleading signals to those starting out on social security.

We believe it is very important that there be a sense of urgency, as long as adequate income support arrangements are in place for those who remain unable to find employment. The coalition's Economic Action Plan of October 1989 proposed that unemployment benefits would only be available for nine months, during which time counselling and access to training programs would be available. We still maintain that allowing for the payment of a relatively short fixed term benefit for nine months, followed by a more rigorously determined discretionary payment, would provide more incentive to people to find a job. We stress though that no-one genuinely in need will miss out on benefits.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, before I resume I wish to recognise the dedication of the three members who are here tonight-you, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca) and me-in view of what is going on in other areas.
—And me!
—The honourable member for Adelaide is desperately trying to get into the act.

—Adelaide would not know what I mean. I now want to speak about the Newstart allowance. To be eligible for Newstart allowance, a person must be at least 18 years of age but below pension age, an Australian resident and in Australia and registered with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) as unemployed for longer than 12 months. Newstart allowees will also be required to enter into a Newstart activity agreement with the CES, which will oblige unemployed people to undertake various activities designed to increase their chances of gaining employment. Acceptable activities will include limited paid employment, training and education programs and voluntary work, as well as Job Search.

SPEECH.PARA: The agreement is the centrepiece of the Government's proposal. It is a step in the right direction, but it merely formalises the requirements that currently exist-although they may not always have been applied-for the receipt of income support. Also, much will depend on the extent to which such undertakings are monitored. The current activities test often means in practice that an applicant is required to nominate two potential employers approached for work within the last fortnight, but no effort is made to validate the claims. There is no time limit by which an agreement must be reached, and it will be possible to receive the Newstart allowance without an agreement having been concluded.

This state of affairs is most unsatisfactory, although it will protect clients where agreements are not reached due to, for instance, inadequate staffing levels in the CES. We believe that payments of Newstart allowance should be cancelled after two months if the client has not successfully negotiated an agreement with the CES, and it can be shown that failure to do so is due to the applicant acting unreasonably in the circumstances. What we are looking for is much more positive and much more active than what the Government is putting up at the moment. We shall be moving an amendment to this effect at the committee stage. I should like to add here that the Opposition welcomes the fact that Newstart allowees will be permitted to engage in voluntary work, although I am disappointed that those on Job Search allowance (JSA) do not have to meet such a requirement or are even able to carry out that voluntary work.

During the debate on the social security legislation just last year, I mentioned the case of a young person in my own electorate who was told by the CES that she was forbidden to do any voluntary work while receiving the Job Search allowance, and that she had to apply for two-and only two-jobs a fortnight. The CES worker told her mother that she would be unable to apply for her two jobs if doing other work, and if she was found to be doing the same, her allowances would be terminated immediately. How does the Government reconcile this approach with the new requirements that, to receive Newstart allowance, applicants are obliged to undertake various activities designed to increase the chances of gaining employment? `Acceptable activities' include limited paid employment, training and education programs and voluntary work, as well as Job Search.

As to the 12 months unemployment requirement, only after a person has become one of the long term unemployed will more intensive use of the CES be required of Job Search/Newstart allowees. The Department has acknowledged that 12 months was chosen arbitrarily as a `nice round figure' for determining the point of intervention. We believe that earlier intervention is far more appropriate to arrest falling morale and rusting skills, despite the fact that the earlier the intervention, the more expensive the exercise. If it succeeds in getting an applicant back into the work force at an earlier date, then there is an overall saving both in funding and in the morale of the client. The Government's proposed approach is curative rather than preventive. We believe that CES intervention should be made available to Job Search recipients after six months, and we shall be moving an amendment to that effect.

As to the role of the CES, the requirement for a minimum period of registration with the CES of 12 months before being eligible for the Newstart allowance is curious, given the unreliability and often irrelevance of CES data. The Department of Employment, Education and Training itself, which administers the CES, admits that such data are `neither an accurate measure of unemployment nor a reliable indication of changes in unemployment'.

This assessment has been reiterated by the Department of Social Security (DSS). Thus, it will be possible for someone who has not been unemployed according to the definition applied by the DSS-that is, actively searching for work-but who has been registered with the CES as unemployed, to go straight on to the Newstart allowance and receive the associated prioritised access to training programs. This implies poor targeting of training program assistance and, hence, an unnecessary waste of public money.

Also, the DSS definition of unemployment is far tighter than that used by the CES, and checking of residents occurs far more regularly. We believe that for this reason it would be more appropriate to make access to the Newstart allowance dependent upon having JSA or unemployment benefits for nine months, and we shall be moving an amendment to this effect. To be eligible for the Job Search allowance, a person must be at least 16 years of age but below age pension age; an Australian resident and in Australia; registered with the CES as unemployed; and under 18 years of age or, if over 18, not having been registered with the CES for 12 months or more. For those aged 16 to 18 years, the rate of JSA will be the same as is paid now. For those over 18, the rate of JSA paid will be the equivalent to current unemployment benefit rates. As I mentioned earlier, the requirements relating to registration with CES rather than receipt of unemployment benefits is inappropriate. We shall be moving an amendment to the effect that applicants will be eligible for the Job Search allowance if they have not received JSA unemployment benefits for more than nine months.

We support the proposals concerning the rules for the sick unemployed whereby those who fall sick will be allowed to remain on Job Search allowance-and be excused from the activity test-for up to six weeks, after which an application would need to be made for sickness benefits. For Newstart allowees the period of grace will be 13 weeks. Taking clients off one benefit to put them on another for short periods, as was previously the case, is administratively costly and pointless when both benefits are paid at exactly the same rate.

I now address the issue of relaxed reporting requirements for older unemployed workers. Unemployed people aged between 55 years and the relevant age pension age, who have been continuously in receipt of a DSS pension for the previous 12 months, will be excused from having to report to DSS fortnightly on their Job Search activities. We are advised that reporting in such cases will be required at intervals of up to 12 weeks. While this provision may be reasonable given the poor work prospects of this group, especially in this Labor-engineered recession, we believe it is wrong to consign such persons so readily to the unemployment scrap heap, particularly if they are capable of work. They should at least be encouraged to undertake community based work projects.

The liquid assets test for unemployed benefits was introduced late last year in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990. The test allows for an additional four-week waiting period for unemployment benefits if an applicant is single with no dependants and has $5,000 more in liquid assets-that is, shares, debentures and deposits with financial institutions; or if the applicant has a spouse and/or dependent children and has $10,000 in liquid assets. The liquid assets of a spouse are also taken into consideration and, where the applicant has transferred liquid assets to his or her children in the four weeks preceding a claim for unemployment benefits, the transfer is taken not to have occurred. This provision is to apply to applicants for Job Search allowance and Newstart allowance.

During the debate on the Social Security 1990 Bill, the Opposition moved an amendment to rectify a very obvious loophole so that an applicant could not, within three months of the lodgment of the claim, dispose of liquid assets to anyone other than his or her spouse or children for less than adequate consideration without being caught by the liquid assets test. We intend to reintroduce that amendment so that those who dispose of liquid assets for less than adequate consideration to any person in the three months prior to lodging a claim for either JSA or Newstart are caught by the liquid assets test.

The Bill provides for a deferment period of two weeks for initial payments of JSA and Newstart where a person becomes unemployed as a consequence of a voluntary action without sufficient reason, that is, for resigning from work because it was no longer interesting; misconduct, for example, sacked for stealing from the employer; or for refusal of a suitable job offer. The deferment period rises by multiples of six weeks with each incidence of misconduct, sufficient reason or refusal of a suitable job offer. So, for example, where a person applies for JSA or Newstart for the fourth time in three years, having been sacked for misconduct each time, the deferment period before any payments will be made would be 24 weeks.

These measures provide an obvious incentive for people to retain current employment or to accept employment where an offer is made. But do they go far enough? By comparison, recent changes in New Zealand allow for deferment periods of 26 weeks if a person becomes unemployed through misconduct, leaves employment voluntarily or refuses two job offers organised by the New Zealand employment services.

It is interesting that the coalition's Economic Action Plan of 1989 recommended deferment of benefits for voluntary unemployment depending on the number of previous episodes. We welcome the Government's decision to adopt our policy approach in regard to voluntary unemployment and we support the extension of the deferral regime to misconduct and refusing to accept a job offer. However, we believe the adequacy of these disincentives should be subject to ongoing review.

We now come to changes to employment entry payments. Employment entry payments will now be made to JSA or Newstart allowees as long as they have been registered with the CES for 12 months or more. Currently such payments are made to those who have been on unemployment benefits for 12 months or more. The employment entry payment is currently $100 for those over 18 years of age and $50 for those below. It is designed to cover the initial costs associated with starting work and is paid just prior to the commencement of work.

For the reasons I have already outlined, CES unemployment duration data is unreliable. We believe it would be more satisfactory to provide the entry payment to those entering work who have been in receipt of JSA or Newstart for 12 months, and we shall be moving an amendment to this effect.

Finally, I should like to comment on the financial impact statement contained in the explanatory memorandum. This statement is obviously inadequate. It is merely a repeat of the February 1990 economic statement and is, therefore, hopelessly out of date since it does not take into account the recent dramatic downturn in the labour market, a critically important circumstance in a Bill dealing with a restructuring of income support to the unemployed.

Even then the projected net savings were extremely modest: $400,000 in 1990-91 and net savings of around $12m in subsequent years. The 1990-91 figure assumes payment savings of $16m, despite the fact that the scheme will not come into effect until the following year. According to DSS the savings will result from a non-legislated tightening of the activity test for JSA and unemployment benefits from January 1991. DSS claims that the estimates for expanded labour market program costs and JSA-Newstart savings have not been updated are difficult to believe. It is more likely that the recession has caused a significant negative blow-out in the net cost to revenue. The Minister should explain these apparent failings in the financial impact statement.

The Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill 1991 makes no policy changes. It is technical in nature and is aimed at ensuring a smooth transition from the Social Security Act 1947 to the plain English Social Security Act 1991. The Act comprises 600 pages with over 2,000 pages of explanations.

The Bill's four specific objectives are: the repeal of the 1947 Act; the provision of transition arrangements from the 1947 Act to the 1991 Act; the consolidation of applicable savings provisions; and the making of consequential amendments to other Acts. The Bill ensures that any pension, benefit or allowance under the 1991 Act that has the same name as a pension, benefit or allowance under the 1947 Act, and vice versa, corresponds to that other pension, benefit or allowance.

Provisions are also made so that a claim for a pension, benefit or allowance made under the 1947 Act which is not determined as at 1 July 1991 will have effect from that date as if the claim had been made under the 1991 Act. Similar provisions are made for applications for employment entry payments and a range of other services provided by social security to its clients.

I shall not go through the Bill clause by clause, save to say that each clause is written in plain English and is easily understandable, unlike so many Bills of a technical nature. The Bill has no financial impact, and we intend to support it. As I mentioned before, I wish the Government would put the Taxation Assessment Act in the same type of language.

The second Bill, the Social Security Amendment Bill 1991, proposes a number of minor policy and technical amendments to social security legislation. Among the more significant of the proposals are, firstly, that certain scholarships are to be exempted from income tests. Scholarships awarded from overseas to cover training and education, but not living expenses, and which are approved by the Minister will be excluded from the pension income test.

The Department of Social Security has indicated that the impetus for this initiative came largely from the case of Mary Guy, a Tasmanian invalid pensioner who won a $100 a week scholarship from the Leichenstein Association of Mouth and Foot Painting Artists. Such payments are currently not excluded from the pension income test. As a result Ms Guy had her invalid pension significantly reduced, although the scholarship was awarded to assist her in purchasing materials for her artwork. The case received considerable publicity, and rightly so. It is just another example of the Government's inflexibility in the implementation of its policies.

The proposal will be introduced retrospectively to 1 September, presumably to cover Ms Guy who was awarded her scholarship on 10 September 1990 and, given the very small number of pensioners likely to be awarded such scholarships, it is not likely to have any significant financial impact. We support this proposal.

Secondly, regarding the primacy of Commonwealth legislation in the recovery of overpayments from compensation claims, a recent Supreme Court of Victoria decision cast doubt on whether the existing Social Security Act permits the Commonwealth to recover social security payments, such as sickness benefits from compensation lump sum payments where State or Territory legislation makes such payments inalienable. The proposed amendment will assert the primacy of Commonwealth legislation over State and Territory legislation to allow the Department of Social Security to recover payments from clients once compensation has been paid. It will have only a small financial impact: savings of $3m in 1991-92 and $3m in 1992-93.

In the case of individuals awaiting payment of compensation arising from injury received, the usual practice is for the Department of Social Security to pay sickness benefits to tide them over until compensation is paid. Once compensation has been paid the Department recovers the benefits that have been paid from the lump sum received. The Supreme Court of Victoria decision has put in doubt the legality of recoverability in some circumstances. This proposal merely acts to reassert what has been current practice.
