Thirdly, regarding changes in the treatment of funeral bonds, moneys invested in funeral bonds will be exempt from the pension assets test provided that the bond has a contribution limit of $5,000 or less per funeral, or $10,000 or less in the case of the funerals of a married couple. Where income from such bonds is not payable until maturity-that is, on the death of the investor-it will be exempted from the pension income test.

Many funeral directors offer prepaid funeral schemes into which investors are able to make contributions towards the cost of their funerals. Pensioners' funds held in such schemes are currently exempt from the pension assets test. Some investment companies have begun to offer funeral bonds also for the purpose of prepaying for funerals. Income does accrue on such bonds. This proposal will allow the same treatment for pension assets and income tests to be accorded to pensioners who choose to contribute to funeral bonds as to those who choose to invest directly with a particular funeral director.

Fourthly, the provision of legal basis for payment variations or cancellations performed by computer, will provide a legal mechanism for cancelling, varying or suspending certain social security payments through the use of the computer. Any such changes to payments will be taken to have been made because of a determination by the secretary. Only those changes which have no discretionary elements, such as the ceasing of payment of the sole parent pension when the youngest dependant child reaches the age of 16 or where a review form is not returned, will be effected by computer. All such computer determinations on behalf of the secretary will be reviewable.

In so far as computer initiated changes to payment will be changed with no discretionary content, this proposal will simply ease administration with no adverse impact upon clients. With regard to cessation of payments due to the non-return of review forms, such action only occurs after the Department has sent out a reminder to the client to return the form and usually a follow-up phone call is made by the relevant regional office. Also, in these circumstances, initially the cessation takes the form of a suspension of payments rather than a cancellation.

Fifthly, I refer to the proposal which seeks to add to the list of decisions made by the Minister which are not reviewable by the Social Security Appeals Tribunal. Under subsection 251 (1b) of the Social Security Act, the Minister may give, vary or revoke directions relating to the exercise of the Secretary's power to waive recovery of a debt owed to the Commonwealth by a client or former client. This proposal seeks to make them non-reviewable. In the past, there has been considerable concern over subsection 251 (1b). The subsection requires the Secretary in exercising the discretion to waive a debt to act in accordance with any directions issued by the Minister.

Ministerial rules and directions of this nature are not disallowable under section 251 (1c). They must merely be tabled before both Houses of Parliament within 15 sitting days of their having been made. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its seventeenth report of 1988 expressed the view that such provisions possibly involved an inappropriate delegation of legislative power, and recommended that such directions be made disallowable instruments.

Various welfare groups have expressed similar concerns. The Welfare Rights Centre in Sydney told the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs review of debt recovery under the Social Security Act and the Veterans' Entitlement Act that it is desirable for such determinations to go through the `normal parliamentary processes', preferring the basic elements of such determinations to be incorporated into the Act itself, and the detail published in the manuals. In consultation on this Bill, the Welfare Rights Centre has indicated that its past objections to decisions which are non-reviewable and non-disallowable still stand and it regards this latest proposal as unacceptable. The Australian Council of Social Service has expressed similar views.

Not only does this proposal seek to add to the list of non-reviewable decisions made by the Minister, it would also permit the Minister to make directions which are not disallowable. Reliance on the benevolence of the Minister in issuing such directives is no substitute for the transparency afforded by the proper consideration of the Parliament. The withdrawal from clients of the protection of the Social Security Appeals Tribunal review is similarly unacceptable. In committee we shall move an amendment seeking to remove the relevant clause from the proposed legislation.

Sixthly, regarding other proposals, a number of very minor technical changes are foreshadowed in the Bill, mainly concerned with refining the social security legislation passed by the Parliament in December last year. Included among these are a pushing back of the annual indexation of the pension assets test limit by several weeks to bring it into line with the date for the indexation of the pension income test free area; a slight tightening up on the payment of the employment entry payment for sole parent pensioners; and a clause to ensure that married or de facto persons aged under 21 who are separated by illness receive the single rate benefit payable to a person of that age. Also included is a minor change to the existing social security agreement between Australia and Canada so that Australian pensions which are payable to widows covered under the agreement will be able to be paid in Canada without any time limit.

I will just comment on the deeming provisions which have been reduced from 10 per cent to 8 per cent. It was due to the Minister's intransigence that we continued for a time with the 10 per cent. I fear for the pensioners in this regard.

The Opposition invites the Minister and the Government to fully examine our proposed and circulated amendments so that, if there is an amendment available, this may be addressed in the committee stage of the Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight the House is discussing three pieces of social security legislation. The first is the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill, which is designed to provide practical and continuing assistance to unemployed people in order to enhance their chances of getting a job. The second is the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill which provides, amongst other things, an income and assets test exemption for funeral bonds with a contribution limit of $5,000 or less per funeral-$10,000 or less in the case of the funerals of married couples. The third piece of legislation is the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill, which provides for the transition from the Social Security Act 1947 to the Social Security Act 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Although I wish to spend most of my time this evening talking about the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill, I would like to commend the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), who is at the table, on their work and the work of their Department in finalising the rewrite of the Social Security Act 1947.

It can be claimed with some validity that this particular Act affects a greater number of individual Australians in a more material way than almost any other piece of Federal legislation. Many of the people on whom it impacts are the poorest and most disadvantaged in our society. It is very appropriate, therefore, that this Act should be rewritten in plain English and have its format revised so that it is easier to access and to use.

The final document is quite bulky, as is the explanatory memorandum which accompanies it. Saying something complicated in plain English does not necessarily require fewer words as the people who were rewriting the legislation would have found out. Basically the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill, which is a much smaller Bill and is before us tonight, is interim legislation which will repeal the 1947 Act on 1 July 1991, provide rules for the transition from the old Act to the new one, and make consequential amendments to other Commonwealth Acts.

In returning to my main topic of discussion, the Job Search and Newstart proposals, I think it is necessary to take the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) to task. I am sorry that he is not in the chamber because I would have liked him to hear it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has gone; the State of Origin match is on.

—He should get his priorities right. I think it is necessary to take him to task over his criticism of the so-called open-ended nature of the support offered by this legislation. The honourable member reminded the House that at the last election the Opposition proposed to cut the unemployment benefit out after nine months. I am glad that he reminded the House about that because some people might have forgotten it. However, he then qualified this claim by saying that disadvantaged people would not be cut off the benefit if they could show that they were genuinely seeking work, or words to that effect. He did not provide any detail as to what constituted continuing eligibility for receipt of benefit, and that is crucial to the discussion we are having this evening. I believe that the Opposition's policy on unemployment benefit eligibility would be heartless and draconian-I have no doubt about that.
—Like New Zealand.

—That is right, just as the New Zealand Government has recently done. More importantly, the people of this country have a right to know what the Opposition is claiming it would do. The honourable member for Dawson and his colleagues cannot continue to play hide and seek with their policies for much longer. Eventually they will have to bring them out from whatever rock they are hiding them under and expose them to the hard light of day and public scrutiny. In the meantime, the honourable member for Dawson cannot have his cake and eat it. He cannot criticise the Government for providing indefinite income support on the one hand and then proffer that apology for a policy from the Liberal and National parties on the other. He must be more specific. Apparently the coalition's social security policies are as elusive and as devoid of detail as the utterings of their leader on subjects of national concern and interest.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the Government's Job Search and Newstart legislation-our arrangements are much more specific-it is proposed that people seeking work will be eligible to receive the Job Search allowance for 12 months. If, after that time, they have still not managed to find a job they will be required to apply for Newstart allowance. To be eligible for Newstart the individual will have to enter into an agreement with the Department of Employment, Education and Training via the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). This agreement will outline the endeavours expected to be undertaken by the individual in search of work. The individual is important in all of this because the agreement will be able to be tailored to meet his or her specific needs and the needs of the local region, which is actually crucial to the whole discussion of unemployment. As we in this House are all aware, different regions have different problems when it comes to getting jobs, or different regions have different qualities in terms of even having access to training.

Referral to training programs will be included in the agreement if such training is considered necessary for the unemployed person to obtain a job. The effectiveness of the Job Search allowance and the Job Search training program is now well-known as they have replaced unemployment benefits for young people since being introduced early in 1988. The allowance was paid to young people on the proviso that employment, training and educational options appropriate to the individual would be established with the Commonwealth Employment Service via an interview and be pursued by the young person as required. This has worked very well.

Community judgment of the Job Search allowance arrangements has been favourable, as Job Search has been successful in assisting thousands of young Australians to improve their skills and confidence and to obtain work-in conjunction with traineeships, I might add.

At the time of its introduction, however, its emphasis and intent were misunderstood and many people working with youth were critical that it was a backdoor way of taking kids off the dole. At first they could not see that young unemployed people would be better off if the Government utilised its resources to identify any difficulties that they had in obtaining a job and actively helped them to overcome such problems.

I can recall addressing a public meeting of youth workers on this very issue to explain the positive nature of the changes being made. It was unfortunate that this program-the Job Search program-when it was first being introduced was so misunderstood and so maligned in many local newspapers around Australia that people had simply not got the message and thought that we were bringing in a draconian measure, whereas ultimately it has proved to be a very useful and helpful measure to the young people concerned.

Concerns on some aspects of the legislation that we are discussing this evening have been expressed by such welfare rights organisations as the Australian Council of Social Service and the Welfare Rights Centre. The honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) raised a number of these in his contribution.

A major difficulty was the lack of the right of appeal to the Social Security Appeals Tribunal, if the agreement was not suitable for the person concerned or if there was a change in their circumstances. I understand that the Government has looked at this very sympathetically and accepted the need to have some such appeal, and I feel that that is a very important change to the legislation.

The Social Security Appeals Tribunal does a terrific job, and it is important that we ensure that, wherever there may be seen to be some compulsion or some difficulty placed on people who are unemployed and where it appears that they may in fact be being pushed into accepting an agreement which is not suitable for them, then there should be access to that appeal mechanism. However, I doubt very much that under the circumstances many people will have to resort to that appeal because they will be properly treated by the Commonwealth Employment Service staff.

The Newstart program is also well known for having assisted longer term unemployed people to obtain jobs. It too is a positive and intensively targeted program which identifies and builds on the strengths of unemployed individuals and helps them overcome any obstacles or weaknesses which may be preventing them from getting work. I will just read a couple of paragraphs from the Minister's second reading speech which actually relate to this area of Newstart. First of all, he says:
Experience has shown that the key to tackling successfully the problems of the longer term unemployed lies in integration of income support and other forms of assistance.
He goes on to say:
Between February 1989 and December 1990, 134,000 persons in the Newstart target group left unemployment benefit.
He also said:

Under the arrangements for Newstart allowance, therefore, the CES will have greatly increased responsibility for the long term unemployed. Willingness to undertake training or take advantage of other program advance will be a major condition of income support.

I think all of those things are crucial to our understanding of what Newstart implied under the previous system, when it was for the longer term unemployed, and what it implies now for all people over the age of 18.

By abolishing the ongoing unemployment benefit as such and replacing it with a combination of these two programs, the Government is committing itself and the Public Service to a proactive strategy for upgrading the skills of the unemployed and tailoring them more closely to the needs of the labour market. I would emphasise that involvement of the Public Service, because we cannot allow a situation-which this Government has not actually allowed but which some people in the Opposition might wish to see happen-where people are allowed to languish on unemployment benefit without anybody taking any interest in them at all and expecting them to be capable and able to find themselves, firstly, work or, secondly, the types of training and skills that are required to get them work.

Obviously, with programs such as Job Search, the job clubs that have been provided by Skillshare and other organisations around the country have been very important, because often unemployed people are not aware of how they should present for a job, and it is very basic skills like that which make the difference between them getting a job or not getting a job.

I think that any organisation that is prepared to take the time to present a person with a curriculum vitae, or some sort of document to help them detail their experience, will be making a great step forward in helping that person find themselves a job, because employers will look at that person as being more substantial than if he or she just appeared on the doorstep improperly dressed, perhaps inappropriately spoken and certainly without proper documentation of their experience. These are things that many of us in our society take for granted, but unemployed people do not always know that those skills are required, as well as a skill in their job area.

This intensive type of approach is greatly needed in the present economic circumstances so that unemployed people can improve their job skills and be in a much better position to get work when job growth begins again in earnest. It is similar to the very successful and more personalised service that some unemployed people have come to expect from programs such as Joblink, which is a program operating in Western Australia and of which the Minister may be aware.

Balga Joblink, which is in my electorate, was established with State Government funding a number of years ago and has been extremely successful in assisting unemployed people from very disadvantaged backgrounds to find work. Unfortunately, such services are not provided in all areas or in all States. It is questionable how long they would be funded by State governments, given the Commonwealth's overriding responsibility for income support and its emphasis on training and skills acquisition. Furthermore, the Commonwealth is ideally placed to offer such a service on a more universal, uniform and comprehensive basis through its existing CES and Department of Social Security infrastructure.

Skillshare, as I indicated before, is integral to the provision of the labour market training programs, and I am sure that the intention is that Skillshare, colleges of technical and further education (TAFE) and other labour market training forums be utilised to ensure that people have access to the best programs available, and that CES is consulted intensively and extensively about the availability of jobs for people when they come out of those training programs. In other words, the appropriateness of the training program to the labour market is a most important factor.

We must not repeat the mistakes of 1982-83. We must not let people languish on unemployment benefits. We must ensure that they have an opportunity to find skills, provide themselves with those skills and obtain work. We must also ensure that, in the course of their training, people understand that there are additional skills necessary to retain work. I think that is important, too, because getting a job is not always the hard part: keeping it is often very difficult, and people have to understand the expectations of employers in that regard.

The skills and capacities of individuals in our society matter: they matter to the person, they matter to their local community and their employer, and they matter to the economy as a whole. This Government has done a great deal to ensure that proper recognition of skills is occurring in our community. The quality of life of the individual and their self-esteem matters as well, and all members in this House would be aware that people who have been on unemployment benefits for a long time have a dearth of self-esteem. They often think nothing of themselves at all, and training is one of the areas by which they can start to lift their self-esteem.

Literacy is another area where training would be required for a large number of people who may be unemployed. I would recommend the programs provided by Skillshare and TAFE to anybody who knows of people requiring that sort of assistance. These aspects will be considered at every level by the CES in coming to terms with the agreement and the individual concerned. Unemployed people deserve to have their options for employment properly canvassed and considered by government departments and by the Government.

They deserve to have their barriers to employment ameliorated or removed. These barriers could be very diverse. They may well be literacy, as I mentioned, or a physical disability or a lack of skills. This is what this legislation is all about. I congratulate the Minister at the table. I hope he is able to take on board some of the comments made in our Caucus Committee and also by the organisations to which we have spoken. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is interesting that I followed the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) in the debate early this morning and that the honourable member for Bowman (Mr Sciacca) was also in the House. They are gluttons for punishment. But I think we are all being upstaged by the State of Origin match, so we probably should not get too excited.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to address my remarks to the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991. Before doing so, I want to make some general observations initially about the very real problem of unemployment and the different ways of solving it. There is no doubt that unemployment, as an economic disease, has afflicted this nation over the last 25 years or so. I remember growing up during the 1950s and 1960s, at a time when unemployment rates were actually very low. There was generally some limited amount of structural unemployment but, overall, rates were generally in the very low percentages, certainly below three or four percentage points.

In some respects it may be true to say that unemployment is a potential by-product of capitalism. Certainly, there are countries such as China-I am pleased to see the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) in the House; he has just returned from China and can speak with more authority than I can on this subject-which have embraced Marxism or other forms of capitalism and generally manage to disguise unemployment by creating a situation in which everyone ostensibly has a job. Inevitably, within these systems people are significantly under- employed. The fact that people are all employed means they are earning very low wages. As a result, countries which subscribe to those sorts of systems inevitably experience very low standards of living.

The demand for and supply of labour respond, as one would expect them to do, pretty much to the general laws of supply and demand. The fact is that the unions-and the Minister at the table, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), might listen to this, as it is largely his responsibility-have managed over the years through sheer coercion to establish or achieve wage rates that are generally in excess of a true market price for labour. Ironically, when one looks at the cold hard facts, one sees that the product of that approach by the unions in this country has been a direct contribution to a significant pool of unemployed people. It was said by somebody years ago that in the environment that we are experiencing today, one person's pay rise inevitably becomes another person's job--

TALK.START.PARA: —The person who first said that was the Minister's father.

—I thank the honourable member for Berowra for making that interjection, because that sheets it home, does it not? The Minister is sitting there squirming, I suppose. The Government's great claim of success in reducing real wage rates through the numerous accords with the unions has really only very superficially addressed the problem. It is patently obvious to most people, and it is even dawning on some honourable members in the Government at this very late stage, that the whole accord process has looked only at one side of the picture. Put in the context of the policies that we will implement when we come to government, it may be that many workers in the Australian work force are being under-rewarded. Our policy provides a challenge for people to earn more rather than less. The key variable of course is productivity. We believe that people should be provided with incentives to work and they should be given the opportunity to produce more and to be rewarded accordingly.

SPEECH.PARA: The centralised wage fixing system-so much has been said about that in the last few days--

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I suggest to the honourable member that this is not the earlier debate. This is the debate on the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill. He has been speaking for five minutes and has not mentioned the Bill.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, for that reminder. I will come to it. I did want to put in context the specifics that we are dealing with, because we have the Government bringing before us tonight and today in this Parliament what is in a sense a new approach or a new way of handling the unemployment problems. It is for that reason that I am attempting to paint the picture that in this country we have an enormous problem with unemployment. We have now recognised that Australia needs to become competitive on an international scale.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government desperately needs to produce a solution to the unemployment problem that it has created. Therefore, I remind the Parliament that the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe), in his second reading speech-I refer specifically to that-described this Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991 as `one of the most significant changes in the Australian system of social security since the 1940s'.

As the Minister pointed out, it involves the end of the unemployment benefit program. However, unlike the position that exists in most countries in the world, this new approach of which he is speaking still allows the almost indefinite receipt of income support, albeit after jumping a few more low hurdles. In his speech, the Minister claimed:
With the Newstart program we will not be repeating the disastrous social and economic policy of 1982-83.

The problem that he claims in that reference to the 1982-83 period to be his legacy will pale into insignificance beside the problems inherited by a coalition government in the next 18 months to two years. Our challenge will be to create in Australia a whole new attitude to work. You will remind me, I am sure, Mr Deputy Speaker, if I diverge too much-but we have had so many instances in recent days of how the Government's industrial relations policies are breaking down. There was the recent waterfront deal where we find that the waterfront workers are earning over $800 per week for under 27 hours work. It is no wonder that our waterfront is so inefficient by international comparisons.

In the context of this debate, attention is re-focused on the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES). I think many honourable members have had numerous people expressing concerns about the role of the Commonwealth Employment Service. I believe it is a bureaucracy which has numerous deficiencies. It has enormous scope for improvement in the delivery of the services that it offers. Many of its functions ought properly to be delegated to private enterprise. We members of Parliament hear story after story of employers being disenchanted with the ability of the CES to meet their requirements. There is anecdote after anecdote about people being sent to an employer by the CES to apply for jobs. They go through the motion of applying for the job, but when the crunch comes they are not seriously interested in taking the job. The whole climate in many respects has been wrong for a long time.

My having said that, there is, as the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) said in his opening of the debate for the Opposition on this subject, something to commend in what the Government is at least attempting to do with this legislation, for it does highlight the depth of the problem that we face in this country, that is, coming to grips with the plight of the unemployed. I resist any further temptation to sheet the blame home further than I have already done.

We in the Opposition endorse the concept of Job Search as an alternative to unemployment benefit. The way we see it-and, in a sense, perceptions are important-the terminology is conducive. The terminology suggests something more positive than the term `unemployment benefit' which these days is, in many ways, rather disparaging.

However, the big difference between the Opposition and the Government with regard to this issue is that we adhere to a fundamental policy position which sees benefits as being in some way finite. In other words, we are not prepared to embrace a position whereby people can go on to benefits and remain on them ad infinitum. There has to be a point where we say, enough is enough, and we are prepared to establish the parameters for those sorts of time constraints. The alternative, not only in terms of the enormous costs that are involved-costs which we in this country can ill-afford-but also the effects on the people concerned, is counterproductive. If people can successfully gain access to welfare-whether it be access to unemployment benefits which we are talking about now, or some other form of welfare-it has become fairly obvious from our experience in recent years that there is a strong tendency, almost a self-fulfilling tendency, for them to remain on welfare. They find it very difficult to break out of this cycle.

In a sense we might well be being kind to people by saying to them, as we might do, that after nine months on unemployment benefit-or whatever we want to call it now-we will seriously examine their position and reassess it very critically to the point where we may have to say to some of them, `Look, we believe you should be out there getting a job. We don't believe that you are serious about getting one, and you'd better go and get one because your benefit is about to be cut off'. That would be kind to a lot of people not, as has been suggested by the honourable member for Cowan and others, being unkind or treating people badly.

As I have said, my colleague the honourable member for Dawson has indicated our intention to move certain amendments which will recognise that principle which we on this side espouse strongly about there being a finite limit to these sorts of benefits. We believe that it is an important element of the payment of any social security benefits that there be that finite limit and that there be a period of assessment. There should be a critical examination-not only of these benefits but also of all benefits-as to whether the people who are gaining access to those benefits are, in fact, entitled to them on a continuing basis. That is an important feature of the amendments which will be moved by the honourable member for Dawson during the committee stage.

We support the Newstart activity agreement as being a move in the right direction, although it should be noted that it merely formalises the requirements that currently exist. We believe that the Newstart allowance should be cancelled after two months if the client has not successfully negotiated an agreement with the CES in circumstances where it can be shown that failure to do so is due to the applicant acting unreasonably. We also favour a requirement that CES intervention be made available to Jobstart allowance recipients after six months.

Our other amendments are similarly concerned, as I have said, with putting limits on benefit recipients. Also, the corollary to that, if you like, is in providing checks and balances on benefits so that they do not remain open-ended and there is a constant ongoing assessment and reassessment of eligibility and progress.

In the few minutes remaining to me I want to say a few words about the relaxed reporting requirements for older unemployed workers. The Government has stipulated that unemployed people aged between 55 years and the relevant age pension who have been continuously in receipt of a Department of Social Security benefit for 12 months will be excused from having to report to the Department of Social Security fortnightly on their Job Search activities.

I am aware that there are numerous circumstances where it has been a particularly onerous requirement for people in this age group to report. It is often demeaning for them and it may even be counterproductive in terms of their actually gaining re-employment. In some senses-and the honourable member for Cowan alluded to this as, I think, did the honourable member for Dawson-by recognising that someone aged 55 years is almost unemployable, we may be accused of consigning such a person to the unemployment scrap heap. That would be unfortunate indeed.

As others have said-and I would like to emphasise this-these people have a very real problem which deserves our sympathy and our closest attention. I think that for someone aged 55 and sometimes even 45, unemployment-particularly in today's economic climate-is a disaster because that person will have great difficulty gaining re-employment. Whilst we support this provision, nevertheless, we believe strongly that special consideration needs to be given to providing people who are in the category we are talking about-55 years and over-with useful activities even if they are not paid for doing them.
The Minister is quite right when he says:

Experience has shown that the key to tackling successfully the problems associated with the longer term unemployed lies in the integration of income support and other forms of assistance. Solving the problem of the hard core or long term unemployed is very difficult.

Certainly, overseas experience does not really give us much room for optimism with regard to our ability to solve the problem. In many respects, it probably demonstrates to us that the problem is, in many ways, insoluble. As I said earlier, it is a fact of life that people in that age group who have been retrenched or who have become redundant will find it very difficult to get a job. I suppose it is particularly demeaning-although I am not limiting it to these people-for someone who has been a senior executive or perhaps the managing director of a company which has gone bankrupt to suddenly find himself or herself out knocking on doors.

I believe that these people do need special consideration. Ultimately, they may well be forced to accept any job which becomes available. However, I believe that every attempt should be made to locate them where they can be most productive. Certainly, people in those categories can be productive. They have proved that. They have been productive and most of them want to be productive again and, in a sense, it is a great pity if they do not get the opportunity to be so.

The problem of the young unemployed is a different problem and it is of no less concern. If one were to add weights to the spectrum one may well see it as an even more concerning problem. The potential exists that some people may never actually experience employment as most of us have understood it. Many people have been forced to stay at school because of the unavailability of jobs, but sooner or later they will move out onto the job market.

The increased retention rates which the Government often trumpets as having been one of its great achievements really do not address the issue-they merely push the qualification hurdle a little higher. It might not be too long before a person needs a PhD degree in order to get a job as a taxi driver. The honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) would probably rue that prospect in view of his qualification, although I suspect that many people with PhDs are driving taxis at the moment. Our sympathy ought to go out to them-not that there is much wrong with driving a taxi; it is a useful occupation and I would hate to have 1,000 taxi drivers writing to me next week--
Dr Catley interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you. I am saying that people with a PhD qualification ought not to be driving a taxi-obviously, they are qualified and could be much more productive.

SPEECH.PARA: We may well have to come to grips with the fact that there are people in our society, particularly older people, who are unemployable for one reason or another and no amount of training or retraining will really solve the problem for them. To use a cliche, we ought to think a little laterally about how we are going to solve that problem. I think we need to place a higher value on voluntary work and community service of all sorts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to talk about the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill 1991, by which it is intended to replace the unemployment benefit with the Job Search and Newstart allowances.

SPEECH.PARA: The new income structure will comprise two separate payments: a short term Job Search allowance which will be available only during the first 12 months of unemployment, and a Newstart allowance for those who are unemployed for 12 months or more. Both payments will apply to unemployed people aged 18 years or over. The Newstart allowance represents a comprehensive and intensive process of contact, assistance and client obligation to deal with the more complex problems of prolonged unemployment. This allowance will be subject to a contracted arrangement between the client and the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES).

These two allowances are integral to the active employment strategy announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the February 1990 economic statement. The active employment strategy is designed to assist unemployed and disabled people to move from welfare dependency to full work force participation. The new payments indicate a more structured and comprehensive approach to labour market strategy.

The Government has become aware that the unemployment benefit, which has been in existence since 1945, no longer readily applies to today's unemployment situation. The underlying rate of unemployment has not been below 5 per cent since the 1970s, and throughout the 1980s long term unemployment increased. To some degree this was due to the increase in the participation rate, notably among married women, although structural changes were taking place in the labour market. The Government has seen the need for the long term unemployed to obtain skills and the experience necessary to return to the work force rather than being handed an unemployment benefit. In the past they could have received that benefit merely by mail, without active participation and doing little else. This often requires retraining and demands a much more active interaction between government, employers and the client himself.

Since the active employment strategy was conceived, it is quite true that Australia's labour market situation has worsened considerably; only a fool would deny that. This has put added pressure on the new system. It is being introduced on 1 July and it will place additional strains again. I notice that the previous speaker, the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), made some remarks about capitalism. He pointed out that it is a system which is intensely competitive, has down sides but produces an economic growth rate faster than alternative systems. Well, I think that is probably the same kind of attitude I would adopt towards capitalism, but I would remind him that an additional price that one pays in this sort of economy is the boom-bust cycle, which has been endemic since it first came into existence 200 years ago.

We are now in a downturn in the economic cycle. This downturn has been caused in part by the classic trade cycle of an imbalance between capital production and the production of consumer goods-most notably in the surplus of capital to be found in every central business district in the Commonwealth today. It is in part intensified by the international fluctuations, notably the international recession, which is to be found almost throughout the capitalist world. It has been worsened unfortunately by the Government's efforts in 1988 to offset the stock market collapse which led to the 1988-89 boom being over-extensive and the contractionary phase which we have now entered rather more sustained and deeper than it would otherwise have liked. It has been intensified by a rural crisis caused by a lack of external markets, by the banks' tardiness in reducing interest rates over the past 12 months and by a crisis of business and consumer confidence, most notably in the State of Victoria, which while excessive at a national level is perhaps understandable in the south east corner of the country.

We are unfortunate to be in this situation for the reasons I have just outlined. The point is that we must look to the future and how to get out of this situation. We have to get out of the recession with three conditions: firstly, lower inflation. It is quite clear that this is already being achieved and the next quarterly figures on inflation are anticipated to show a figure heading down towards zero. Secondly, there should be a better balance of payments figure; already the figures announced this week show that has been achieved-as exports are rising imports are falling, and our present balance of payment problems are caused by previous debt. Finally, and this is the importance of the measures announced and being debated tonight-we must get out of this recession with a greater level of production; that is, production for import replacement and, if possible, for export into the great booming markets, particularly of Asia.

A different Australia must emerge from this recession; it must be a different Australia with a different industrial and labour market structure. It will be a different Australia in which some of its industries have been shed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest, as I did to the previous speaker, that the honourable member return to the Bill.
—I apologise and I will return to the Bill as soon as possible.
—I suggest that the honourable member return to the Bill or he will not return to anything.

—As some of these industries grow and some shrink the labour market will need to be reorganised in order for people to take advantage of improving industries as they move out of declining industries. The active employment strategy is designed to achieve this as it is implemented on 1 July 1991. The active employment strategy indicates a change in policy for this Government. Among other people, I was a little concerned about how it would affect people in unemployment and people who have to deal with the unemployed. As a result, I sought the opinions of a range of people both nationally and in my own electorate as to how they envisaged the strategy affecting the situation of the unemployed. These people come from the local CES office, which is located across the road from my office, from the local business sector and from community retraining skills.

SPEECH.PARA: One of them, Inta Sellick, is the manager of Adelaide Options, a Skillshare project which will be deeply involved in this new active employment strategy. Inta says that she welcomes the strategy and believes that existing Skillshare and other employment training programs will be well placed to contribute to the extended training needs which will be created by the Newstart scheme. She also thinks that technical and further education colleges should be encouraged to broaden their focus to accept the training of the long term unemployed and that these facilities should be appropriate for participating in that.

However, she is concerned about various aspects of the labour market as they presently stand, that the economic environment is not so appropriate now as it was over a year ago for a training-based strategy, that there may not be enough jobs even for these newly retrained people to go to, that it may affect the morale of retrained unemployed and that there may be added pressure on existing services trying to retrain hard-core unemployed who do not believe that even when retrained they will be able to get back into the work force. I think some of these observations are timely and well taken, and I share some of her concerns about moving to a full blooded active employment strategy at a time of higher unemployment than when it was first conceived.

I note also that the manager of Job Prospects, which is the local Skillshare program-and I am on the board of it-has expressed similar concerns. I have been contacted by the Welfare Rights and Legal Centre, which operates in Canberra, and we have all read the complaints of the Australian Council of Social Service (ACOSS) about the response that the labour market and the unemployed are likely to have to this new active employment strategy.

I would like to make a few remarks about that which are intended to allay the fears that these very well meaning people, who will be at the centre of these retraining active employment strategy programs, have raised. I think some of their fears should be allayed. The point about the active employment strategy is that it is designed to assist those who are the most disadvantaged in the labour market back into employment. These people cannot be left to languish in a state of unemployment without help and merely receive welfare or unemployment benefits periodically. It is a strategy designed to help people into jobs by providing an enhanced level of client contact through interviews with CES officers and unemployed people and to enhance a range of labour market programs that are better designed to assist individuals' needs to get back into the work force.

If we look at expenditure on the four main programs for long term unemployed people, we see it has been increased by $113m, or 40 per cent. The centrepiece of these new arrangements will be activity agreements negotiated between long term unemployed people and CES officers with a view to getting them into a situation where they can re-enter the work force.

The guidelines for these agreements are being carefully drawn up at the moment by the CES. These guidelines are being developed in consultation with ACOSS, and I hope that that reassures ACOSS about the situation. They have not been finalised and fully approved by the Minister. They are being continually negotiated with a view to providing natural justice requirements for clients and to contain important review guarantees for them.

We do not claim-and it would be foolish for the Government to do so-that such an active employment strategy in a context of a downturn in the business cycle will be a panacea for the problem of unemployment. The point is that it will provide an active training program for people to enter training programs as the economy recovers-which is another lever of policy-to enable them to take advantage of growing industries and not to be saddled with unemployment in the long term. ACOSS has raised a number of other concerns about this active employment strategy and about these active employment agreements negotiated between CES officers and long term unemployed clients. I will make a few observations about its complaints.

First, ACOSS is concerned about the element of compulsion involved in the active employment strategy. I should point out that the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development recommends strongly the active society approach to long term unemployment and the link of a receipt of an income support system during unemployment with an obligation on the part of the recipient to undertake not just job search but also training and other activities to help them back into employment. The occasional letter to employers found in the yellow pages or even small advertisements for job vacancies in the local newspaper has been internationally and in this country found to be an insufficient method for actually acquiring a job, and retraining is a necessary part of the active employment strategy. To say that it is compulsion avoids the necessity of retraining the work force, particularly in an economy that is undergoing such rapid transformation as this.

The second concern of ACOSS is that the process of negotiating these agreements would be one-sided and would involve the CES official in fact imposing the conditions of agreement on the client. This would be unsatisfactory were it the case, but the Government is intending to ensure that clients would be fully advised in writing prior to attending their initial agreement interview of what the Newstart activity agreement involves so that they can prepare for the negotiation on an equal basis with the CES officials.

Thirdly, there are some clients who will be in trouble with literacy, language or learning difficulties-and this is appreciated, particularly among people of non-English speaking backgrounds or who have been long term unemployed and, as a result, have lost many job skills or even negotiating skills. To this end, we are concerned to ensure that clients can bring along mentors to the agreement process, that enhanced interpreter resources will be available, and that printed multilingual information will be available on the active employment strategy, the Newstart activity agreement, and so on.

Fourthly, concerns have been expressed that a requirement to participate in the labour market program should be imposed only where the nature of the course or program is specified and there is good reason to believe that a place will become available. These agreements must take into account the specific nature of the client's capacity and the availability of jobs and training programs in the area concerned-and I will return to Adelaide in that context in a moment-and cannot just be negotiated in isolation from the existing labour market and the place that the client may be able to find in it.

Fifthly, the Government has absolutely no intention to introduce, as ACOSS expressed fears about, any work for the dole scheme. That ought to be knocked on the head immediately. Sixthly, junior CES officers, it is feared, who are not suited or who are untrained for the job will be negotiating with long term unemployed people and will be unable to provide them with the necessary advice. The terms of the agreement in fact must be agreed by the client, and the assumption is that, where the client agrees, the terms will not be unreasonable.

Finally, we have seen in the press the fear that there will be no appeal rights. I am assured by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) that the Social Security Amendment Bill will be amended to provide for an appeal right on the terms of the Newstart activity agreement.

I hope that those remarks will allay any fears that have been expressed to me not only by ACOSS but also by the other agencies involved in the active employment strategy. If any further difficulties emerge, I hope that people in my area and other electorates will approach their local members because we are entering into a new active employment strategy that needs to be monitored carefully in a period of high unemployment. I appreciate the concerns expressed by these agencies. They must be, and will be, taken on board while I am able to speak in the Caucus.

The other kinds of objections which have been raised to this active employment strategy have been raised by the Federal Opposition from an entirely opposite direction. It appears to me to be intent on diverting an active employment strategy and employing punitive measures against people who are, through no fault of their own, unemployed over a long period.

The Opposition has said that it would reduce the amount of time a person can claim a Jobstart allowance to nine months and, as a result of more difficult provisions for getting onto Newstart, would actually halve the number of people who are able to go on to these longer term programs. Newstart would become harder to get and its provision would be, to quote the first speaker for the Opposition, discretionary. The last speaker for the Opposition said that at a particular time benefits would end as a policy of being kinder to people than would otherwise be the case.

No indication was given in either of the two Opposition speeches made so far as to how people would survive having been taken off these provisions. This must be of considerable concern to people who are faced with unemployment as a result of the downturn in the cycle, particularly when it is proposed that they get Jobstart for nine months; then there would be a transition of half of them to Newstart, the provision of Newstart being discretionary and able to be terminated after two months, which on my calculation gives 11 months reasonable certainty of income followed by a discretion.

The Government's goal is to get members of the population retraining and to encourage them to re-enter the work force by engaging in voluntary agreements with local CES offices, under which people can be brought along either to interpret or to act as mentors in how to structure the programs. They would then be subject to appeal rights. The strategy is a positive one designed to get people back into the work force.

One fears that the overall impact of the Opposition's policies is on the one hand to say that it will hand over large departments such as social security to charities-and, now we find, hand over the CES to private enterprise, according to the previous Opposition speaker in his remarks-and, on the other hand, dismantle the most successful examples of the retraining programs which will be integral aspects of the active employment strategy which we are now undertaking. The combination of all those things is a worry and should be a severe worry to those people who are entering unemployment at this time, a condition which I regard, as I am sure do most members on this side, as an extremely unfortunate situation which is beyond the choice of most people at this stage.

Let us look, for example, at the Skillshare program, which will be an integral part of these agreements reached between the CES and the long term unemployed. Skillshare has been one of the Government's most effective employment training projects and will be a key element in the active employment strategy. It is one of the most striking examples of the way in which a government and the community sector can strike up an effective partnership. In 1989 a report on Skillshare, called Skillshare: It's working, found that, of the 76,000 long term unemployed or disadvantaged job seekers that were helped by Skillshare projects, 26,500 found employment and another 12,000 went on to further education or training.

In my seat of Adelaide there are a number of Skillshare projects. The one that I am most familiar with is Job Prospects in Sefton Park, of which I am on the board. Admittedly, in more buoyant labour market conditions, Job Prospects has had the highest success rate of placing 50 per cent of the long term unemployed people who come through its front door into either jobs or further training programs. It is locally based with a board that includes me and, I might say, to his great credit, the previous member for Adelaide, who was a member of the Opposition, despite the fact that the Opposition was committed to abolishing the program. He was a decent enough individual to recognise that it served a very valuable contribution to the long term unemployed in the northern inner working class suburbs of Adelaide and that it deserved continuation. To be fair to him, he did his best to introduce the people who went through that program to those employers that he encountered in his fundraising programs and other activities.I tip my hat to the man. I wish that the Opposition would continue such an attitude towards active employment programs and retraining.

The active employment strategy will help, I trust, to fundamentally change the nature of unemployment as we go into the upturn of the business cycle, and I wish it well. Subject to the qualifications which I have voiced and some of the fears that have been expressed by people who are in the business of retraining-fears that need to be attended to-I support these provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gallus Mrs C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill, I would like first to comment on some of the remarks made by the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley), who has totally misunderstood the speakers who came before him and whom he quoted. The Opposition's policy certainly is not punitive and it is not to leave people who have no other means of support without support. People who will be moving off the Jobstart allowance and cannot get other employment will be moved onto a special benefit. Our policy is to move people quickly through the unemployment period so that they can get jobs, and only those who at the very end cannot get jobs will move onto the special benefits.

SPEECH.PARA: With April unemployment figures due on Thursday, this legislation comes at a very appropriate time. The unemployment situation in this country is appalling. It is appalling not only because the Government has failed to respond to the economic circumstances with appropriate policies, but also because it is as a direct result of Government policies that we have such massive unemployment. As a result of this Government's economic policies, 824,500 people were unemployed in March this year-275,000 more people than at the same time last year, which represents an increase of 50 per cent. These are disgraceful statistics. The Treasurer who created them should have resigned. For the same Treasurer (Mr Keating) now to be claiming that his policies are working because imports are falling is chicanery. Bringing the country to a standstill is certainly one way to reduce imports, but only this Treasurer would have the hide to pretend that crippling a country is an appropriate form of economic management.

We have 824,500 people unemployed-over 9.2 per cent of the work force. But even this figure, as bad as it is, does not reveal the extent of the dislocation that is occurring in the community. This figure excludes anyone who has worked for even one hour in the previous week. Hence it excludes all unemployed people who managed to find a couple of hours work. Labour force statistics for March 1991 show that, of more than 100,000 men between 20 and 34 who are working part time, over half would have preferred to have worked longer hours. Of all people working part time, 24 per cent would like to have worked longer hours. To the 824,500 people without jobs, the people to whom this legislation is addressed, we can add the 409,000 who are under- employed.

Furthermore, the 9.2 per cent unemployment figure does not include the number of previously full time workers whose jobs have been cut from five days to four, the number of workers who are being asked to take their long service leave or the number of discouraged workers, mainly women, who do not even bother to look for work any more.

Last Sunday, 5 May, the Age published Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) unemployment statistics. According to these figures, in March 1,054,000 Australians were looking for work. This makes Australia's unemployment rate 12.4 per cent, or 30 per cent higher than the official figure. CES statistics are not as consistent as Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, but they are still an economic barometer and, as such, indicate that unemployment is even worse than that 9.2 per cent figure would have us believe, even though that is bad enough.

The legislation before the House was designed to counter the Opposition's policy on long term unemployment benefits. Under this Government, unemployment benefits, originally conceived as a way to assist people between jobs, have become a way of life for some. Under this Government there were people who believed they had a right to live on unemployment benefits for ever. I can recall two delightful people who came to my office. One told me he was on unemployment benefits because he wanted to write a novel. The other said he did not like to work because it mucked up his social security benefits. This was before the recession and, except for antipathy to work, there was no reason why either of these people should have been on unemployment benefits.

As a country, we cannot afford to pay people who do not want to work to stay at home. I believe that the present Government has realised this and I am aware of the general tightening up of social security over the past year. To a large extent, this legislation puts into effect what is now practised. I think that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) has already mentioned that.

The major change brought in by this legislation is that the responsibility for excluding people from benefits will pass from employees of the Department of Social Security (DSS) to those of the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET). I shall say more on that later. This legislation was designed to get people back to work. In particular, it was designed to force those people who had decided that unemployment benefits were an acceptable alternative lifestyle, preferable to hard work, back into the labour force. For every job vacancy there are now 28 people unemployed. That means that of the 824,500 people who are presently unemployed there are no jobs for 790,000 of them-and there are no jobs because of the Treasurer's recession.

The majority of the people who are out of work today, who are on unemployment benefits today, simply do not have jobs to apply for. What is needed now are some policies from the Government that will help business get started again so that business can start hiring again. The coalition has already suggested a number of reforms that will help achieve this end.

Looking at the legislation in detail, I have concerns about it. I have concerns about the length of time the Job Search allowance (JSA) will be in force-12 months. Twelve months is a long time to be out of work. The longer a person is without work, the more likely he or she is to become one of the permanent unemployed. The move from temporary to permanent unemployment occurs for a number of reasons. First, employers discriminate against the long term unemployed, preferring to hire people with more recent work experience. Secondly, unemployment destroys people. It destroys their self-confidence and their self-esteem. It totally removes their pride and as a consequence they present as unattractive employment prospects. Thirdly, long term unemployment beneficiaries become trapped in a lifestyle which in the end excludes the work ethic. Fourthly, by being excluded from the workplace, long term unemployment beneficiaries lose contact with the rest of society and become alienated from it.

For these reasons, I believe that 12 months is too long a period for payment of the Job Search allowance. Active intervention of the type prescribed under the Newstart legislation should begin earlier. The coalition seeks to amend this legislation to limit the Job Search allowance to nine months and to require active intervention of CES at six months.

I have concerns about the red tape that the Newstart agreement will involve. I believe there is a danger that the Newstart agreement will become a bureaucratic nightmare with volumes of agreements, hours of negotiations and hundreds of counsellors with quite enormous powers. Those who are out of work not only will suffer the indignity of not earning their income but also will have the indignity of having their lives raked over by public servants, many of whom will be considerably younger than the people whom they are counselling. I have noted the efforts of the honourable member for Adelaide to reassure us on that point. I also note that I know a great many DEET employees and have a great amount of respect for them. However, there could be employees who are offensive to those people they are counselling.

The emphasis on skill acquisition is an important one and certainly an emphasis that this side of the House would applaud. It is essential that those whose skills are not in demand are given every chance to acquire new skills. Also positive are the options of voluntary work as part of the Newstart agreement. Not mentioned in the legislation is the current restriction on entrance to CES courses to people who have been registered as unemployed for six months unless they are specially disadvantaged. I note the reference of the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) in his second reading speech to early intervention. Although he does not clarify it, I take this phrase to mean what it means currently-which is intervention at three months for the especially disadvantaged, in particular, Aborigines, those with low literary skills and those with physical and mental disabilities.

I would like to suggest to the Minister that anyone who has been without work for three months is already especially disadvantaged. After three months, these courses should be open to all who have a problem obtaining work because of a lack of marketable skills.

There are several questions that the Minister has not answered. How many counsellors are going to be needed for the Newstart program to work? Will it be like the jobs, education and training program, where counsellors are claiming that to see four clients a day is too heavy a load? What is the estimated cost and salaries that the bureaucracy needed to implement the Newstart program? What will be the effect of having DEET personnel make the decision to cut recipients off Newstart benefits rather than Social Security?

I am curious about this because I can see that I will have people in my electorate receiving a letter from Social Security saying that they have been cut off benefits. They will go to the Department of Social Security with this letter and say, `What has happened? You have cut me off the benefits'. Instead of getting an answer from Social Security they will be told, `This is not our decision. This was not taken at Social Security. This is a DEET decision'. What does the recipient do then? He has to find out who at DEET is responsible, go home and make a separate trip to DEET. The Minister should be looking at a closer liaison between CES, DEET and DSS so that this type of thing does not occur.

The Minister mentioned long term unemployment in his speech, indicating that JSA/Newstart will address this problem. Of course, it cannot address the fundamental problem. The Minister has failed to acknowledge the extent to which this recession is going to add to the permanent pool of long term unemployed.

Of the three unemployment categories-frictional, cyclical and structural-structural unemployment is the main problem. Frictional unemployment will take care of itself as those people who are between jobs move on. Cyclical unemployment-the unemployment created by this recession-will look after itself when the economy gets moving again. Despite this, those people who have suffered as a result of cyclical unemployment will bear the scars, perhaps for the rest of their lives.

Structural unemployment is the heart of the problem-those people who stay on government benefits and have little or no chance of getting a job. Each recession increases structural unemployment. We saw this happen after the 1974 recession and the 1982-83 recession and we will see it again after this recession. Each recession adds a large number of unemployed to the hard-core of unemployed who are already there. After the recession, the level of hard-core unemployed does not return to its previous level; it plateaus at a higher level and that plateau becomes the new base. For many, this will become the never-ending recession. For Australia it means a permanent crippling impost to our already large welfare bill.

Our projected unemployment benefits bill for this year is $4.5 billion. Even if it drops next year, it will never return to previous 1990-91 levels because of the increase in structural unemployment. The community will have to keep paying this increased welfare bill-a permanent legacy of this recession.

There are three groups who are particularly at risk from this recession. The first group is those who were already unemployed at the beginning of the recession. The longer a person is without work the less likely it is for that person to obtain work. The second group is young people who have never had a job. Leave them without a job for too long and many of them are likely to pass into an alternative culture where they, too, become unemployable. Businesses are reluctant to hire 20-year-olds who have been out of school for three years but who have never worked. Currently, the unemployment rate for the 15-to 19-year age group born in Australia is 22.2 per cent. For the higher risk group-those born outside Australia-it is 27.9 per cent.

The third group is the older men who in normal times would have continued work until they were 65. Because of the recession they lost their jobs. But older men are less attractive job prospects and when the businesses start hiring again many of these older men will not be re-hired.

One group of older men is of particular concern. Government policies have closed down factories and constricted building. Unemployment is currently the highest in both the manufacturing and the construction industries-9 per cent and 11.5 per cent respectively. The people who are being laid off are the manual labourers over 40. These men have a strong work ethic. They have worked hard all their lives and they take pride in their work. Now that they are unemployed they are some of the hardest seekers after new employment. But the new employment is not there for them and it is not going to be there for them.

When the economy goes forward again businesses will have a large choice. They will choose their manual labourers from the younger, stronger and more mentally agile workers that are available to them. What happens to our older manual workers? How will Newstart help them? For many of them English is a second language and re-skilling into a non-manual job is not a real possibility. Similarly, those with low literacy will go on to the scrap heap of the unemployed. Some are already there. About half the men over 55 who are unemployed have been unemployed for over a year, and the figures will grow. This will be one of the legacies of the recession.

This present legislation has acknowledged the plight of the older unemployed. Section 525 of the Social Security Act 1991 allows for exemption from the reporting requirement for people over the age of 55 who are engaged in full time voluntary work. I think this is a positive move and I am sorry that the Government did not take it further. Community work is one way for the long term unemployed to maintain their self-respect and to feel that they too are contributing to society. It keeps them in contact with people and increases their chances of employment by showing prospective employers that they have been working.

Whether the Government likes it or not, we are a work oriented society and work gives us our identity, our self-respect and many of our social contacts. As the honourable member for Dawson has acknowledged, this Bill heads some way in the right direction. It recognises the importance of intervention to assist the unemployed to return to the work force. It recognises the importance of re-skilling to get those without marketable jobs back into the work force. However, it allows too long a period before active intervention.

The Bill has other problems that the honourable member for Dawson has alluded to, in particular, the open-ended nature of the Newstart agreement and the failure to close the loophole on assets handed over to a third person. However, the crux of the problem now in May 1991 is that there are no jobs. There are more than 800,000 people officially unemployed and even more hidden unemployed and these people are out of work as a direct result of the policies of this Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill. The honourable member for Hawker (Mrs Gallus) has talked about how the Government has allegedly created the present level of unemployment. The conservatives have been out of office for a record time in Australia's history since Federation, but they left us with double digit inflation, with double digit unemployment and they changed the method of statistical reporting. We still have not reached the levels of inflation and unemployment that were left with us in 1983. What is happening tonight is quite historic for Australia and it is great that both the Opposition and the Government have agreed that the unemployment concept should go and that it should be replaced by a new concept which is established under Job Search and Newstart.

SPEECH.PARA: A few years ago, in the mid 1980s, I attended a very large, well-attended rural crisis meeting in Yass. That meeting was quite militant. It consisted mainly of farmers who voted unanimously that unemployment should be abolished. Of course, they did not have in mind the sort of thing that is happening here tonight. The introduction of this legislation means that people will not be thrown onto the scrap heap and will not be made to queue up at soup kitchens.

This legislation is reflecting the common desire of those people at Yass, but it is also reflecting something else. It is reflecting a message from taxpayers that money which they contribute to revenue should be accountable and should be properly spent; that their funds should not be spent where a standard of cooperation is not evident. It also reflects a message from the parents of the unemployed, from people who work with the unemployed and from the unemployed themselves. That message is that there is a need for individual attention to each unemployed person. That is because each unemployed person is different.

We are all different; we have different skills. There are now some people who are unemployed who are very skilled in some areas and who possess many and varied skills. There are people who have some experience. While they may not be called skilled, they may be called semi-skilled, and there can be hundreds of different types of experience in the semi-skilled area. There are people with very little experience or no experience at all.

The proposals we are considering tonight try to look at each individual. Of course, each individual has different abilities. There are people with different intellectual abilities; people with different manual abilities; people who have different communication skills and abilities; people who differ in their ability to use numbers; and people who differ in their literacy ability. There are strong differences. As well as that, there are differences in presentation. There are people who present themselves well and confidently, and have high self-esteem. There are others who do not have that self-esteem. In fact, there are those who develop very low self-esteem, and that leads to defence mechanisms which often make them present a false front, and they say, `No-one wants me, so I don't want a job'. Of course, this is being extremely destructive.

This legislation is giving hope to the hopeless because eventually people should be able to be treated on an individual basis. It is a reasonable result to what taxpayers have been asking for-accountability, and payment where there is cooperation. Of course, this continues a trend which has been evident and is the reason why social security benefits have reduced. Some years ago there was a substantial reduction in social security benefit pay outs compared with 1983 when the Government came into office, because of the high drop in employment pay outs, and overall this Government is spending less on social security.

Under Jobstart people will be able to receive an allowance. They can then move onto Newstart where they will have an agreement set out with the Department. This agreement has been described by some, including the Australian Council of Social Service, which the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) mentioned, as being too tough. But there will be fairly tough requirements. This is understandable and, in fact, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, through the Commonwealth Employment Service, has been moving towards this already. So has the Department of Social Security which has actually been getting tougher on people who will not cooperate with schemes. I have actually spoken to people who have had benefits taken from them because they have been told that they were not cooperating on schemes. In some cases it is people who move away and have to attend a tertiary and further education facility perhaps in another town, and there are behavioural problems. Those people have been taken off benefits. After those people have been counselled twice and have not accepted that counselling, they have been taken off benefits.

I decided that I would publicise that fact and I made it clear to people that, especially when Job Search and Newstart commenced, things would be a bit tougher than perhaps some people had experienced so far. People will be told that they may have to go away for training. But every time I have put an article in a newspaper or explained just what is happening, I have had counselling from officers of the Department because they say, `Well, perhaps you shouldn't be emphasising this because we don't want people to think that there'll be nothing at all for them'. Of course, as the honourable member for Hawker has said, there is something; people can go onto special benefits. They can get something, but there is a degree of testing and it is that much harder for them if they do not cooperate.

A positive aspect of the proposal is that people can be diverted into training-into a system of personal development-so that they receive reasonable help. If they will not accept reasonable help, they may be told that they cannot obtain benefits without accepting the reasonable offers of assistance that are given to them by the Commonwealth Employment Service and, in some cases, by the Department of Social Security. So they need to accept it.
