Initially, with a reasonably high level of unemployment, which I believe will continue for a few months yet, it may be hard for the extra staff who have been appointed to cope with each person on an individual basis. People will need to understand that they will receive allowances if they are not offered that help and if they are not offered the help that will be available to them in the future.

Since the 1960s there has been a big change in the concept of unemployment. In those days statistics were quite different. While the rate of unemployment seemed to have been low even in 1961, when there was a crisis in employment, the figures were quite different because the number of people who claimed to be looking for work was far less. For instance, there were not nearly as many women saying that they were interested in obtaining work. Then in the late 1970s there was another change, when a lot more people became unemployed on a long term basis. Even today there are people who became unemployed when they left school in the late 1970s and who still have not obtained work.

All of the symptoms that I talked about are evident in those people-low self- esteem and the development of defence mechanisms. People have developed a habit of unemployment because they were not dealt with on a proper individual basis and they were not properly counselled. Once again, the unemployed were blamed instead of the managers of the system. Now at least government, the Public Service, members of parliament-all those involved-realise that people have to be dealt with on an ongoing, individual basis. So I recognise those two problems: the need for ongoing assistance and the need for accountability.

The Opposition has moved some amendments. They remind me of the old days when I was young and one of the few young people, I suppose, who listened to Parliament. In those days one would hear the Opposition reject the Budget by moving that the Budget be reduced by #1. In this instance, the Opposition is moving to amend the Bill by substituting the term `12 months' for `9 months' and that sort of thing. It is not really seeking to alter the concept of the legislation to any great extent. It is just trying to make it slightly tougher.

For a long time the Opposition has failed to come up with policies on a wide range of issues, including social security. As the Minister for Community Services and Health (Mr Howe) said earlier today during Question Time, if Opposition members will not tell us what their policies are then we have to take note of the kites that they are flying. They have flown a kite about the jobless, pensioners and people on social security being assessed by charity. They have flown a kite about chartered accountants paying benefits.

No pensioners, no unemployed persons and no-one on social security would be happy if they knew what would happen if they were assessed by charitable organisations of varying quality. The big ones are mostly run by good quality people who do not really want to do that work, and no-one would particularly want chartered accountants operating the payment system for social security. What Opposition members really want to do is implement the system which operates in the United States, where people queue up at soup kitchens and wander around the country without accommodation. Opposition members are going to rescue the system with their industrial relations policy and get more people into work. Their hidden agenda there is to get wages for Australia which will compete with those in other countries-for example, some of the Asian countries which can produce more cheaply.

This would mean again what is happening in the United States, where we find people receiving $3 an hour below subsistence incomes because of their enterprise bargaining system. We as a Government must never accept that concept of getting away from an award rate of pay per hour. We can talk about enterprise bargaining on penalty rates and conditions, but we should never accept the concept of enterprise bargaining on the amount paid per hour. At least if a person is on casual work he or she can go to another casual job. People are not a commodity on a shelf; they are not like other costs in a business-they are people.

The important Harvester case of 1908 should not be ignored by any government today. We cannot afford to allow any enterprise bargaining to include negotiation about an hourly rate which has been fixed by an award. That would impoverish people for a start. It would also actually reduce working incentive. Small business employers I have spoken with have freely admitted that, if they pay a low wage per hour, a person's work value drops. Some people would accept the concept of paying a low rate. Others would be forced to compete by reducing their hourly rate. We would then get the sort of situation that exists in the United States.

The Opposition's policy on industrial relations is one of social failure and bad economics. As far as social security is concerned, even though the Opposition is supporting this legislation, there is little doubt in my mind that people would once again become numbers on a file as has been the case for many years now. It would be little more than that-people just rolling up to report. People would be on benefits for nine months and then they would have big problems.

The worst thing about the policy enunciated by the Opposition until tonight is that it would not get people back to work. The cost-cutting that occurred under those opposite in a wide range of community services would occur again in the unlikely event that it was elected. We would get to the situation where once again it would cut out services such as the wide range of training schemes that will be introduced along with this legislation.

It is with great pleasure that I support the legislation. A lot of credit has to go not only to the Department and to the Ministers involved but also to the committees within this Parliament. Even tonight, when there are very few people in this place, there are committees meeting all over this Parliament actually working out policy--

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe you.

—The honourable member has been with me on those committees. The party policy committees are actually dealing with policy in detail. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins), the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) and the Minister for Community Services and Health have actually listened to honourable members who have been out there working in the electorates and have come back with information on whether the schemes which have been established are working. This is consolidating a wide range of programs which have been tried over some years.

SPEECH.PARA: Full credit should go to the previous Fraser Government for the way in which it improved on the regional employment development or RED scheme through a wage pause. I did not agree with pausing wages, but I did agree with the system of finding work for disadvantaged people, both men and women. This occurred under the wage pause. Full credit goes to the Hawke Government, too, for the community employment program, which was a further advance. What this matter is about and what training is about, and has been about in the last few years, is getting people into long term full time employment. This legislation is an important step in that march.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call the next speaker, I advise the House of the results of the very important event in Queensland tonight between Queensland and New South Wales in the State of Origin rugby league game, in which Queensland won by six points to four. I am sure all members of the House join with me in congratulating Wally Lewis and his victorious team.
—It is of zero interest to me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for bringing that special information to the House. It is a matter of zero interest to me, also. In speaking to the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill, may I first refer to a piece of information that you have given, Mr Deputy Speaker. For the benefit of those people who have joined us this evening, DEET stands for the Department of Employment, Education and Training; DAS stands for the Department of Administrative Services; and the Department of Social Security is DSS.

SPEECH.PARA: When making some remarks on this Bill earlier this evening, the honourable member for Cowan (Ms Jakobsen) referred to the open-ended nature of the current arrangements. That is exactly what my Party opposes, especially indefinite income support for those people who choose not to work. That is what we are saying.

If people choose not to work in this country, we say that we will not offer them funds to enable them to continue to do exactly that. That is all we are saying. For making those remarks, tonight the honourable member for Cowan called us heartless and draconian.

A friend of mine-I will refer to him as Roger-went out and got himself a job as soon as he heard there would be changes, and became an expert worker in a chicken factory. He thoroughly enjoyed his position. The honourable member for Cowan-I will get to the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Snow) in a few minutes-admitted earlier this evening that her experience already to this point showed that young people, after hearing what is ahead of them through changes to be made by this Bill, have already begun to address their training needs and those of the people around them. So a positive element is being established in the community. Tonight I did not hear one member on the Government side thank the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) for introducing this measure through his Party prior to the previous election. It was then taken up by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in his election speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not one did.

—Not one of them thanked the honourable member for Kooyong for introducing the measure into the House and into the Australian community. I am surprised that Government members allow us to take the lead on so many issues. It has taken the Government nearly 15 months, though, to get to this point, following the initial introduction by the honourable member for Kooyong and his band of merry men. The honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley)-if I can mention Government members who spoke this evening-spoke about an active employment strategy. That term was dropped by his own Government immediately after the campaign speech. An article by Margo Kingston stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, the Government's market research showed that people thought that in Government speak the word `strategy' meant nothing was actually being done.
So, the Government dropped that term and came up with Newstart, because it is more acceptable.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro made one mistake, when he did not recognise that the recession of 1982-83 was not a desired recession. We did not beg for it, we did not ask for it. We did have a drought, we did have a drop in commodity prices and we had the legacy of the Whitlam Government. Putting those three things together-it was not our choice to go into that recession, with the unemployment that ensued. However, the comment `This is the recession that we just had to have' came from the mouth of the honourable member's own Treasurer (Mr Keating). He said that we had to have this recession, and it is the ensuing unemployment that this Bill is beginning to address in an effort to help people. I come from the sad and sorry State of Victoria. Victorian employees on the edge were like the young red lobsters that are now no longer allowed to be dropped into a pot in Queensland. Anyone who does that will be fined $1,000. The young people on the edge and those on the edge of the employment circle were dropped into what could be termed the boiling water of this recession that we just `had to have'.

With over 700,000 people now unemployed, plus the hidden unemployment, we are perhaps talking about one million people being unemployed in Australia. My beautiful Victoria has been brought to its knees. We have possibly the worst unemployment figures ever, possibly the worst investment prospects ever, and possibly the bleakest outlook for business opportunities. Therefore, employment for those on the edge is undoubtedly curtailed. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Crean), would know this, because his electorate is next door to mine, and he would be receiving the same sorts of phone calls and experiencing the same problems as I am facing with my constituents. He also is in a very heavily industrialised area.

So who are these people on the edge? At one time it was the least educated, the least skilled. Perhaps it is now middle management, often talented women and men who would have been looking for further advancement but for the mismanagement of the Australian economy and the resultant recession we just had to have.

The Treasurer told us on a Special Broadcasting Service program that he likes to paint a word picture when he speaks in this House. Let him please paint a word picture of Victoria, and perhaps I can mention some basics that he might create this word picture out of: confidence, zero; capital, zero; investment, zero; job opportunities, zero; business collapses, everywhere. In fact, one writer, Mr Terry Vine, in our newspapers in Melbourne, said that there was chaos in the Australian community, especially in Victoria, but there was also a terrible silence about it.
Mrs Glenice Davies of West Melton, in writing to one of the newspapers, said:

We do care. We are just a little bit battered, bruised and weary and feel lost and betrayed. Clear the State of hangers on, elect someone who can govern and Victoria will shine again. Until then there is very little we can do because we are the working people without a voice.
That last line must hurt the Minister at the table. J. P. Stephen of Hoppers Crossing said:
The silence you hear is an anguished cry for help from tired people treading water who know that Mrs Kirner's `light at the end of the tunnel' is a train coming the other way.
Is that not a great line? That is another word picture. Margot Kingston, about this Bill, said:

Today the Government introduced legislation for a plan (to make it harder for many to get the dole). In late June, it will spend $3m on television and printed advertising to tell the unemployed the news that despite the fact that there are virtually no jobs any more, they must pretend there are and do all sorts of things to prove it.

The Government is going to spend $3m to sell this program to the unemployed people of Australia. There has been quite a bit of pollution not only since the State election started in New South Wales but also in this House today. Quite a cloud is hanging over the building because the unemployment figures are coming out tomorrow. That same pollution surrounding the western suburbs of Sydney also pollutes the western and northern sides of this House. The members on the other side of the House pollute the process of government by their failure to bring their Prime Minister to account for putting mateship in front of propriety or scarcely addressing himself to his policy speech during the 1990 election campaign.

I quote for the benefit of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Tickner), who is now at the table, a few facts about that policy speech. It should bring tears to his eyes and inspiration to his heart for what he might be able to draw to his attention. The Prime Minister said:
The fact that the tough and hard decisions we have had to make for the good of Australia are starting to work-
it was very soon after that that the Government acknowledged this recession we had to have-
the fact that we are building together a nation of opportunity, fairness and security-
where is the opportunity, the fairness and the security for people who had jobs just a while ago?-
and above all, on the strength of the Australian people.

Yes, perhaps the Prime Minister is right in that, because when the Australian people have their backs to the wall they begin to fight, and they are beginning to fight now, and they are saying that this is not good enough. They are saying to all politicians, including us, `It is time to get your act into gear'. The Prime Minister went on to say:
We will never accept the proposition that some Australians are expendable, to be dropped through a trap door and forgotten.
He also said:
We will abolish the dole.
He took on exactly what our leader at the time, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), had said: `We will abolish the dole'.
Then the Prime Minister said:
I commit my Government to provide, with the States and voluntary groups . . .

These are the words of the Prime Minister of Australia: `with the States and voluntary groups'. Was it not the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) who talked about using voluntary groups to administer some parts of our welfare system? Is this not the Prime Minister I am talking about here, who is talking about using voluntary groups to help out with our welfare system?

The Prime Minister talked about a new level of Commonwealth support. He offered us marriage counselling services. He must have known that the recession was coming because there are a few problems in families now and that is leading back to money. He then went on to say:
We will establish Family Resources Centres.
We now find out that family resource centres are not going to help with any hands-on work as well; they will just establish what is actually happening with welfare services. He said:
We will support State efforts to care for teenagers after school.
What do I get from the city of Springvale? A letter a week on the underfunding of services after school for young students and older students. He also said:
. . . we will help to provide improved transport for outer urban areas through the provision of more trains and buses.
He then talked about the total cost. That just has not happened. There is a tragedy befalling the nation at this moment. The Prime Minister went on to address himself to women and said:

In the task of national mobilisation to build a more productive and competitive economy, the women of Australia have a key role. Today-International Women's Day-I reaffirm our deep commitment to equality of opportunity for the women of Australia. It is a commitment to give women a full say, a real choice and a fair go.

What has happened? Women are the major losers of this recession. They were the ones who lost their jobs and who fell out of favour with this Government. It was their jobs that were keeping a whole lot things going.

In the February economic statement the Treasurer backed that up-I have not got the time tonight to go into it-when he talked about the Newstart allowance expenditure resulting from getting people back to work. Since that date all that has happened to us is that we have just turned people away from the workplaces of Australia.

Even having regard to the recession and the promises of more work, we have less work. The Treasurer said that in the wake of the 1982 recession we had 670,000 people unemployed; when the March figures were 824,600 or 9.6 per cent. He talked about the halving of teenage unemployment-which we would all like to see-but today, teenage unemployment stands at 189,700 or 22.9 per cent.

The coalition wants proposed changes to the unemployment benefits system stiffened and toughened. We would like to see that after nine months people are given an opportunity to begin to make a change to the situation they find themselves in. Whether they choose to find themselves in that position or not, the Opposition would like to see an earlier change. All we are saying is, `We don't want you on unemployment benefits for 12 months'. We would like to say, `After nine months we are giving you the opportunity to move on in another direction'.

The coalition is particularly concerned about the treatment of those over 55 years of age. They will not be asked to conform in the same way as other unemployed people are. I would respectfully suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if we are to see any difference in people from executive positions at all-or any people-if there were private job agencies, they could register with those agencies and, in doing so, give themselves an opportunity in perhaps another area outside the Commonwealth Employment Service to go forward and get a job.

When the Government talks of percentages, the unemployed as numbers, consumer price indexes and economic downturns, what it really means is that these are people out of work. This includes those who have always survived on temporary jobs, topping up with unemployment benefits-street smart people who have worked the system for years. They work in industries that thrive in the good times and die in the hard times. There are those who work two jobs to get ahead to pay for extras, and the loss of the second job often causes a crisis in the family budget. There are those who have always worked on a casual basis-labourers, tradesmen and those who work in the building industry-who find things really tough during a recession. Mostly, these people cope with the ups and downs.

The real losers in the current recession are genuine Australian workers who, after holding their jobs for years, are unpractised in the use of redundancy payments or services afforded by Government agencies-both urban and rural. Men and women of middle age who may even receive small superannuation payments that see them through a recession will find it hard to regain employment. The new poor find themselves spiritless. They experience shock, hurt, anger, humility and despair. They are often amongst friends whose home is secure and whose job is secure.

Rather than bag the Government any further for its failure in the social justice area for ordinary people who find themselves in this predicament, we encourage the unemployed to make a new start. I hope that this legislation will be moving in that area. If our recommendations are accepted by the Government I am sure that that will be the case.

My Party is also offering people the opportunity to take personal action. Perhaps there is an opportunity here for those people in our community who have been out of work, but who have an interest in a particular area, to retrain in that area. I give honourable members an instance. People who take an interest in those with disabilities could, with an involvement in further education in disability support training, obtain part time or full time work in the disabled area. I know from personal experience that this has happened to people around me who have been out of work. That is one instance, and there would be 100 others. People who have interests and real talents but have been in other jobs may have an opportunity to get a real new start. We are not offering a dead end, but a new opportunity for them to regain their self esteem by trying another way.

People who are over 54, going on 55, and are being treated differently by the Government from other unemployed people-their status in the community has fallen or they have lost face or their salary expectations have diminished-are the ones who are going to make the recovery in Australia more important because the recovery will begin with individuals, not governments. When we Australians change our attitudes and the way we approach our work and endeavours to gain work, then this nation will begin to revive.

The Hawke Government would do Australia's unemployed people a great service if it agreed with our policy to remove people from unemployment benefits after nine months and begin the process of re-employment or community contribution. This recession we have had to have has damaged the self-esteem of so many through loss of jobs and businesses, sackings, and the reduction of full time employment to part time. The wash out for so many people is huge disappointment, rejection, and an inability to function as they would see themselves. Probably they feel ashamed that they cannot continue in the employment that they have had for such a long time.

One fellow at 55 years of age was retrenched from a glass factory recently. It seems he has nowhere to go. I hope there is an opportunity for that man. Politicians have a few things to face up to around here at the moment. There is going to be a political wash out from this recession, and the State governments' royal commissions. I suggest to honourable members that Brian Burke might be managing Mr Lang Hancock's mines shortly. The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, may be going to Ireland to negotiate a peace with the Irish Republican Army, which is similar to the waterfront situation. Mr Paul Keating will be placing his clocks in the Lodge very shortly and Joan Kirner will get a full time job, I dare say, trying to wind those clocks back. Minister Kim Beazley will start the first private telecommunications company run by a non-union labour force. Mr John Kerin is likely to buy a sheep farm after the next election. The honourable Barry Jones will become the Ambassador to Siberia for coming too close to the truth, and Senator Peter Walsh will be shot at dawn and buried at Kakadu by the Prime Minister and Cabinet, subject to an environmental impact study. The good senator may live forever because waiting for a decision on the environment under this Government is an easy way to stay alive.

This has been a fine opportunity to stand here this evening knowing there are so many hanging on every word I say, including my mother and two others. My father may be interested too because he is still holding my first wage cheque from my first job. There was dirt involved in the job and he never thought I would get it. I do not think he thinks this is a real job either. We find ourselves in a situation where, after 15 months, the Government and the Opposition are standing together to say that we need a new start for so many people in Australia.

If I am serious about one thing it is this: all young people under this scheme will have a greater opportunity to gain employment. That is what is important to all honourable members in this House. We need to give young people and those unemployed a new start, the opportunity to have another try, to get enthusiastic and be part of this great nation. Before I finish, I believe that, with all of the problems we have in this House, we should remember tonight the homeless, not only in Australia but throughout the world. We should remember the hungry, the grieved, the desolate, the persecuted and those who are suffering the ravages of weather throughout the world on this day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the past, legislation passed in this House has not been specifically lauded for the clarity of expression in introducing programs to meet the expressed and covert needs of the Australian electorate. Given this, I am pleased to address the Bills before the House-the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1990-91, the Social Security (Job Search and Newstart) Amendment Bill and the Social Security (Rewrite) Transition Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The last mentioned of these Bills makes a promising start in providing for the transition from the Social Security Act 1947 to the clear English Social Security Act 1991 and updating that Act to take into account social security initiatives introduced in the 1990-91 Budget and providing for the implementation of initiatives in that Budget, such as New- start and disability reform.

If time allows, I will speak later of Newstart and the progressive disability reforms undertaken by the Hawke Government. But first I will detail some of the housekeeping provisions of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill.

Anomalies existing in the earlier Act include the fact that the definition of income did not exclude certain scholarship payments when gauging eligibility for pension or benefit. The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) has pointed out that, as a result of this anomaly, a person could have a pension or benefit reduced or cancelled on receiving a scholarship. I therefore welcome the Government's decision that, as from 1 September last, a scholarship awarded from outside Australia is to be excluded from the person's income if the payment does not include any component for living expenses, and if the Minister approves the scholarship payment for this purpose.

Other provisions give asset test exemption for certain prepaid funeral expenses. Clause 28, for example, ensures that certain retirement village residents receiving rent assistance immediately before 3 November 1988 who have continued at all times since that date to reside in a retirement village will continue to be qualified for rent assistance. This will be achieved by taking a person in this category not to be an eligible home owner for the purpose of the 1991 Act.

Other clauses look at payment of pensions to women whose husbands are patients in mental hospitals, and rent assistance for sickness beneficiaries. Before 1 November 1980 a woman was qualified to receive a widow's pension if her husband was a mental hospital patient. After 1 November 1980, however, a pension or benefit became payable to the husband while he resided in the mental hospital and a wife's pension, instead of a widow's pension, became payable to the wife.

A problem arose on this transfer to wife's pension in that it would have involved a reduction in the level of income support. Clause 21 in the Bill is a savings provision to provide an alternative qualification rule for women in this position, to ensure the trauma already being suffered by such a person is not exacerbated by a loss of income.

A similar saving provision is incorporated in clause 24, which provides that the rate of rent assistance payable to certain sickness beneficiaries will continue to be calculated under section 120 of the 1947 Act, as it applied before 13 September 1987. Without this savings provision sickness beneficiaries would have been adversely affected by the standardisation of rent assistance in 1987.

These clauses are indicative of the manner in which, with flexibility, legislation can respond to the needs of the general public when the lines of communication between government and those elected remain open. While some of these mechanisms may appear trivial to those not affected, they are crucial to the well-being of a significant number of Australians.

I would now like to address the legislation, which will enable major changes to be made in order to make support programs for unemployed people more effective-a most important move, particularly in the present circumstances. The Newstart program is significant in that it heralds new beginnings for people discouraged by a lengthy and fruitless search for that elusive job. Along with the Job Search program, Newstart typifies the latest rung in a ladder of reform intended to bridge the often difficult chasm between unemployment and active participation in a job.

When the Hawke Government came to power in March 1983, unemployed people were at an extremely low ebb, as the trauma occasioned by lack of work was exacerbated by the grossly insensitive Fraser label of `dole bludger'. There has been some interesting commentary this evening regarding the very real trauma which people who are out of a job, particularly for a lengthy period, are suffering. In fact, I commend the honourable member for Corinella (Mr Broadbent) for his concern for the people within his electorate.

Having been elected to this House in 1980, I had very close contact in 1981-82 with a similar situation, which lasted until the Hawke Government came to office in 1983. These problems have come up from time to time during this century. I can remember a very difficult time during the credit squeeze in the 1960s and the difficulty I had in raising a young family. So one learns after a while that these problems do repeat themselves. But before any government is able to put forward programs to meet those specific needs, it firstly has to recognise what that problem is.

My concern in that earlier 1981-82 period was that the then coalition Government did not recognise and did not say publicly that there was an economic malaise and that there was a reason why kids coming onto the job market could not get jobs. In fact, they were labelled as dole bludgers. That had the effect of lowering the esteem of young people. Anyone who has been in contact with young people who are looking for work now will understand the extra load that that unfair tag put onto the young job seeker. In effect, the general public was being told to look down on these young people and was told that in fact they were not getting jobs not because jobs were not available, but because of some deficiency within their own make-up-because they lacked a desire to go out and look for work. Because of that attitude there was no reform of, or change to, the sorts of programs that were mounted to assist people in this situation.

Because of that, I was very pleased to see the introduction of the new community employment program (CEP), which was one of the first programs brought in by the Hawke Labor Government in 1983. That CEP filled a real need in the area. Most particularly, it brought young people who were suffering long hours of despair behind closed doors or down at the local pinball parlour-which was perhaps the trendy meeting place for young people in those days-out of these inward looking areas where they were losing more and more self-esteem and put them into real work, in a day by day work environment, providing facilities for the local community.

In fact, the Boondall entertainment complex within my electorate was one of the recipients of work by young people under the CEP, as was the sea wall at Shorncliffe. Road safety was assisted by the building of a number of park and drive car parks at railway stations running along the Shorncliffe line through my electorate of Lilley.

That was indicative of the way in which the general community benefited from the CEP, but the real benefit was in getting young people out of the home, breaking that cycle of despondency and despair which prevented them from getting jobs when there was a job vacancy because they had lost all confidence.

After the CEP had run its course, there was a need for another move because it did not meet the long term needs of unemployed young people, nor was it designed to. It was designed to break that earlier cycle, and it did that very effectively. Since then, there have been a number of programs. I think most honourable members, again from both sides, will have had contact with Skillshare, which followed on from the community youth support scheme; the job centres; the NEIS, the new enterprise incentive scheme for young people who might want to start up a new business; and a lot of the training programs which have right up until now been conducted through technical and further education colleges or through private colleges, such as secretarial colleges. The Hawke Government has subsidised these colleges to enable young people to get training to get back into the work force.

It is that growth and development of programs, the shifting to meet needs, on which the programs we are discussing today in this Bill are built. Newstart is notable for the manner in which it integrates income support with labour market assistance. Without labour market programs, income and other types of supported programs for job seekers are hindered in their effectiveness. The Newstart program brings with it an additional $220m for labour market programs until the end of 1993-94, providing over 50,000 program places each year. This then will be topped by the $155m expansion of labour market programs announced in the March 1991 industry statement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

Another aspect of the Newstart program is the improved liaison between the bodies supporting job searches-the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) and the Department of Social Security. In developing arrangements for a Job Search allowance, the programs aim to help prevent long term unemployment before those problems surrounding it become entrenched in the way we have been discussing. In many cases, it just does not work to give young job seekers income support and then leave them to their own resources. Many need training and job seeking skills. To meet this need, the CES will provide early intervention assistance to Job Search allowance recipients in the first three months where it is needed. There will be a strong focus on assisting young people, and the current arrangements for 16- to 17-year-olds will be incorporated into Job Search provisions.

Before closing, I wish to comment on the activity agreement into which recipients must enter in order to receive the Job Search allowance. The agreement will set out steps which will hopefully enhance the job seeker's employment prospects. The aspect of this agreement which I will be monitoring closely is the requirement that a person must enter into and abide by the agreement if he or she is to receive the Newstart allowance. I want to make it clear that in my experience and the experience of my colleagues the large majority of job seekers are anxious above all to secure work. It is not their fault that suitable work is not available, and the Government has no intention of knocking the victims of economic downturn.

Regrettably, where any public program exists, abuse exists. By taking measures to reduce the risk of fraud and incorrect payments, the Department is acting in the interests of the majority of job seekers, who do not abuse the system. When government revenue is robbed by fraud, less money remains to meet the real needs of the majority of honest job seekers. However, this should not be taken to suggest that abuse is greater at the lower end of the earning scale than at the top. The enormous bill carried by the pay as you earn taxpayer and caused by large scale tax evasion schemes such as the bottom of the harbour scheme which the Government has addressed with the closing of loopholes, bear witness to this fact. I trust and believe that the Newstart program will address the real problems of unemployed people and will prove to be to their advantage.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak to an issue of national significance, which I note has been neglected by the media and the public. It is clear that in the few weeks since the Industrial Relations Commission had the audacity to defy the Federal Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), a number of individuals in this country have spoken out in very precise terms to denigrate the Industrial Relations Commission and cast its role in the industrial relations system in our country into doubt. I put it to you, Mr Speaker, that the Treasurer of Australia-your Treasurer-the honourable Mr Paul Keating is in contempt of section 299 (1) (d) (ii) of the Industrial Relations Act 1988. That portion of the Act states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not:
. . . by writing or speech--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for La Trobe should not try to involve the Chair in the debate in the House.
— Thank you, Mr Speaker. I repeat: section 299 (1) (d) (ii) of the Industrial Relations Act 1988 states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not:
. . . by writing or speech use words calculated:
. . . to bring a member of the Commission or the Commission into disrepute.
In the Sunday Age of 5 May 1991--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If the honourable member for La Trobe wishes to raise an allegation against another member of this House, he must do so by substantive motion. The honourable member for La Trobe should be careful about the direction of the remarks he makes to ensure that he does not transgress that rule, which says that the only way he can raise a matter relating to another member is by substantive motion.
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker.
—I do not think there is the necessity for a point of order. I am hearing the honourable member for La Trobe.

—The honourable member for La Trobe is putting a question of substance on the operation of the Industrial Relations Act and he is illustrating it by reference to circumstances. He ought to be given the liberty to do so.

—There is no point of order, as the honourable member for Higgins should know. The honourable member should resume his seat. Having brought that matter to the attention of the honourable member for La Trobe, I trust he will take notice of it.

—Thank you, Mr Speaker. I take notice of your statement in that regard. In the Sunday Age of 5 May, the Federal Treasurer warned the Industrial Relations Commission to rethink its position `or it will not have a position'. Further, he said that the Industrial Relations Commission would `be run over, bypassed and materially damaged' if it failed to adapt to the economic society of the 1990s. If that does not tend to bring the Industrial Relations Commission and the commissioners into disrepute within Australian society, I do not know what does. It is very simple for a person to say, for instance, that a Commissioner is very poor at golf, and by such a statement being made, clearly the Commissioner could be considered to be brought into disrepute in the community. The statements made in recent times by the Treasurer and by the President and the Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, as well as by many others in the community, regarding the Industrial Relations Commission may in their minds be fair statements, but in fact they violate a section of an Act which was brought into being by this Government in 1988, specifically section 299 (1) (d) (ii) of the Industrial Relations Act, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: A person shall not:
. . . by writing or speech use words calculated:
. . . to bring a member of the Commission or the Commission into disrepute.
Thank you, Mr Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two Government members are seeking the call. I do not think that we should bring matters of great controversy into the House at 10.35 p.m. It is one of the few times in my life that I think the honourable member for Kalgoorlie will probably be less controversial-a terrible bias on my part, I must admit. I think that the Opposition should accept that I am being biased against the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I must say that what I have to talk about is far more important than rugby. I want to talk tonight--
—Most things are more important than rugby, but maybe not rugby league.

—I must admit that I do not know the difference. I want to talk tonight about a man whom I consider to be one of Australia's heroes, a man who has come in for a lot of sly innuendo from members of the Liberal Party in this House over the past couple of days and a man whose political predilections are probably one million miles away from the Australian Labor Party. Given the thoroughly disgraceful treatment he received from the then Premier of Western Australia, Sir Charles Court, I am not surprised that he has decided to support the Labor Party. I refer to Lang Hancock.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it rather pitiful that we have had this denigration of this man's achievement in Romania. What Lang Hancock is about in Romania is opening up to Australia potential trade with eastern Europe, a potential that far exceeds the voluminous trade with Japan. The market for iron ore, coal and the other minerals produced in Australia is far greater in eastern Europe, and Lang Hancock has led the way. The market hinges on the canal which runs from the port of Constanta on the Black Sea to Cernavoda on the Danube.

This canal, which is 64.2 kilometres long and 120 metres wide, required the removal of 300 million cubic metres of earth and 3.5 million cubic metres of concrete. To put that into perspective, the Suez Canal, which is 164 kilometres long, required the removal of only 275 million cubic metres of dirt and the Panama Canal, which is 81 kilometres long, required the removal of 160 million cubic metres of dirt and 3.9 million cubic metres of concrete.

This canal is not a new idea; it was an idea of the last century and, indeed, Hitler started it during the early part of 1944. However, it was Lang Hancock who seized on the opportunity to present it. The canal enables us to send large ships in excess of 150,000 tonnes into the Mediterranean. Prior to the construction of this canal, the Danube offered passage only to ships of about 30,000 tonnes.

The canal enables us to be competitive with South America. I refer not only to iron ore but bauxite, alumina, coal and many other products. Hungary, which has a history of being a very large aluminium producing country, is running out of its own raw material. Hungary has the potential to be a very big customer for Australian alumina or bauxite. Coal has already entered eastern Europe through this canal.

This canal is working because Lang Hancock had the vision to see its potential. Out of his own pocket, he spent $30m to install the unloaders at the port of Constanta. Without these unloaders, no traffic in the commodities that we sell would be possible.

I believe it is a tribute to this man, and it is a pity to see him so denigrated. Sly innuendos are made and questions asked about why Brian Burke should be involved. Brian Burke is involved because the Western Australian Government was the government that gave support to Hancock in these ventures, and it was Brian Burke who had the political contacts in Romania. He was known there and had done far more to develop trade than Austrade had ever done, and far more effectively. We need to realise the debt that Australia owes to some of these people. History will write them in much bolder letters than we, in our parsimonious and sanctimonious way, tend to do at the moment.

To date, the unloading facility at the port of Constanta has cost Hancock dearly. He certainly has not made a profit from it, but Australia certainly has through the passage of its cargoes through that port. In the long haul it is to be hoped that Hancock will benefit from this. It is a tribute to Lang Hancock and to his able offsider, Kevin Dalby.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Broadbent Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw to the House's attention the untimely death of Councillor William Thwaites, OBE. He was born at Yannathan on 6 August 1918 and died on 13 April 1991 aged 73-a rather remarkable gentleman. He was a councillor of the Shire of Cranbourne for 36 years from 1955-91. He replaced his father, John, who was on the council from 1936-55-a period of 19 years. The combined services of father and son was 55 years.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill Thwaites was Shire President five times, a returned soldier with five years service from 1939-45 and a justice of the peace. He was awarded the OBE in 1972 for services to local government and distinguished himself in service to local government at both State and Federal levels. At a State level he was President of the Municipal Association of Victoria for three successive terms, from 1969-72. He was Treasurer of the Municipal Association of Victoria for 15 years from 1973-88. Bill Thwaites was Chairman of the Local Authority Superannuation Board for 10 years from 1975-85 and Foundation Chairman of the Western Port Regional Planning Authority in 1969.

In a federal sphere, he was President of the Australian Local Government Association from 1975-76, and the Victorian local government representative at three constitutional conventions, in 1973, 1975 and 1976. He was the Victorian local government representative on the Federal Government Inter-Government Relations Committee in 1976, the Victorian local government representative on the Federal Government Housing Standards Committee in 1971 and an Australian local government representative at the United Nations Habitat Conference in 1976.

Bill Thwaites's loving wife, Marg, died earlier and I do not think that Councillor Bill was ever the same from that time on. Bill Thwaites, Marg and his three children were friends of our family for many years. In fact, Bill grew up in the early years with my mother. He made a great contribution to his local community and was much loved by many throughout the Cranbourne shire. Although I never served on the same council that he did, I served on many regional bodies with him. He was a great source of information and wisdom for me. He was somebody to whom I could turn when I needed help in my local government years.

His contribution to his general community is not listed here because he served in a local area in his beloved Yannathan and Lang Lang on all sorts of community committees, as many honourable members in this House have served. As I said, he was greatly loved by his community, and especially his family-the three children and the grandchildren he leaves. We offer the best to them and recognise the great contribution that this man made over his 36 years on the council of the Shire of Cranbourne.

The Shire of Cranbourne will be better off that this man lived, just as it was better off that his father lived. Their joint service of 55 years is remarkable at this time when politicians serve such limited time in their chosen field. A remarkable man, through remarkable years, he saw remarkable change.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two challenges I would like to speak about tonight. Firstly, and very briefly I remind the Chair that Wally Lewis and the great Queensland team won tonight, and it was fantastic. I think the honourable member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) will cover that later on tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: But I would like to speak about another challenge. There has been much discussion lately about a leadership challenge in Federal Parliament. I confess that I believe there is a leadership challenge in the wings. I have done some research lately--

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I am pleased that the honourable member for Maranoa is interested in this, because it would concern him greatly. In the Budget session, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) spoke, on average, only once a week. Parliamentary figures show that in the Budget session of eight weeks and two days the right honourable member for New England made eight speeches and took eight points of order.

SPEECH.PARA: But in the current session he has spoken twice as many times and has risen to his feet on three occasions in a packed House on points of order. In the six weeks and two days of this autumn session the right honourable member for New England has made 13 speeches and risen on three points of order. It is of interest to note that the three points of order have occurred within the last three sitting days-that is, two on 18 April and one on 7 May. That was, of course, when it was obvious that the Opposition had lost the initiative in the debate in the House. I believe it could well be the beginning of the end for the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer).

Let us look back at some of the comments that the right honourable member for New England made when he accused his National Party colleagues of disloyalty. On 11 May 1989 he said in the Hobart Mercury--

TALK.START.PARA: —Great paper.
—It is a great paper, as the honourable member for Denison said. The article was headed `Sinclair keeps his challenge options open'. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Ousted Federal National Party leader Mr Ian Sinclair yesterday would not rule out a challenge to regain the leadership before the next election.

Knowing Sinkers, that means he will not ever rule out a challenge, because one thing about him people have to admire is that he is tough and he likes to have a go. Let us look at what is happening in the National Party today. On 16 April the Australian said:
Nationals split on backing tariff cut.
It continued:
It is believed the former leader of the National Party Mr Ian Sinclair was last night considering tabling an amendment in Parliament against the legislation.
Of course we all know that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) is agonising and sitting on a barbed wire fence wondering what to do about tariff cuts in the sugar industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very painful position.

—It is certainly a painful position, as the honourable member for Oxley says, and obviously he is still not aware of the benefits to the sugar industry of cutting tariffs and trying to get better access to markets for the 80 per cent of sugar we try to sell overseas. It is interesting to note that on 14 December 1990 the QTV afternoon news said:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal National Party Leader, Tim Fischer, says he can't support a ban on imported produce into Australia. In particular, the Nationals' leader says he doesn't go along with news to ban imported bananas from South America, claiming Australia must rely on free trade to survive.
That is an interesting point and I am pleased that he said that. On 28 April the Sunday Sun in Queensland said:
State National Party frontbencher Neville Harper said that the party in Queensland did not support a free trade policy.
Mr Baldwin-
another person who was at the function-
replied: The National Party federally has the same free trade policy-
as the Liberal and Labor parties. The article then quoted him as saying:
You should use your numbers to make them think about what they're doing to their constituency.

We have seen what has happened in the Senate, where three Queensland National Party senators have crossed the floor and voted against their coalition partners on everything of importance, whether it be wheat, wool, sugar, et cetera. There is a whiff of challenge on the other side of the House in regard to the National Party.

I was just looking at what I think would make a great Woody Allen script-the National Party Federal policy on economics. It says that the priority for the coalition in government, according to the National Party, is emphasis on cutting inflation-something we in the Australian Labor Party have been doing for the last seven years. Obviously those in the National Party are not aware of it.

Even better, the policy goes on to say that we should move from monetary to fiscal policy. Yet every time we want to make some tough decisions in here, those in the National Party wimp out. I refer, for example, to selling the pipeline or to the assets test. They have promised more money for roads, more money for everything. In other words, they want a softer fiscal policy at the same time as their policy itself, formed last year down here in Canberra, said they wanted a tighter fiscal policy. But, better still, they go on to say:
That it be National Party policy to reduce all tariffs to negligible levels . . .

That is to be over the next eight years. But we have the Queensland National Party. That is the Klu Klux Klan. The League of Rights runs the Queensland National Party; it is the Klu Klux Klan without the bed sheets. Its members are saying, of course, that they do not believe in a free trade policy. Is it any wonder, with the right honourable member for New England lifting the agenda, that there is not a challenge in the wings?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think that anyone in this House would take very seriously the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice). What he has said is so wide of the mark that he really should be looking at his side of the House and the little Caucus meetings around the corridors as to who is getting the numbers to take on the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That is the issue that he should be talking about and looking at.

SPEECH.PARA: He does not need to worry about this side because, after the next election, those on this side of the House will be on the other side, and the honourable member for Hinkler will not be here anyway. I think that he is just trying to shore up a few of his constituents. He needs to look at the issues that are running in the electorate and not trivia, and he should not talk rubbish in this House.

Last night I travelled to Dubbo to speak with some of the people in the Wool Council of Australia and the Australian Wool Corporation at an open meeting today of the Corporation which was addressed by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) and which had a record attendance. The auditorium was packed to overflowing. One of the issues that was canvassed around the room during morning tea was the real fear amongst many people on the land and many small businesses in rural Australia that they will not survive the current crisis and recession.

It would do well for the honourable member for Hinkler to listen to what I have to say because only last year he said that there was no rural crisis in Australia. I suggest that he go to some of these rural crisis meetings, such as the one at Dubbo, which I attended today. He would learn a little more and understand some of the real issues that are out there.

I want to talk about the rural adjustment package that has been announced by the Minister. That matter was put to him in Dubbo today. The Minister was accusing the New South Wales farmers-they can defend themselves-of saying that his latest package was a con job. I looked at the package that has been released by the Minister and I acknowledge that he has made more money available. In the most important part of the package, part A, there is only $12.2m being made available for 1991-92. This amount in part A of the package is for the whole of Australia. Part B and part C address different areas of reconstruction for people who are moving off the land or reconstructing debts.

The honourable member for Hinkler may be very interested to know that part A of the package is directed to interest subsidies for those farmers who, through no fault of their own, have hit an economic crisis and it is beyond their economic capacity to meet their interest rate payments. If he can agree that $12.2m of additional funding, of new lending, for 1991-92 will meet the crisis confronting rural Australia in the next 12 months, he is a bigger joke than I have imagined. I would like the Minister to take another look at part A of this adjustment package because it is vitally important. I believe that the Minister does have an empathy with people in rural Australia and that he should be looking at making more money available in part A of the package.

The people who have had a go in the past three or four years will be most affected. They have had a go and have taken on extra debt and they will be affected. Unless we are very careful, we will be left with those people who have not had a go rather than those who have. I believe that we should be supporting those people who are the achievers. The part A side of this adjustment package is critical and needs additional funding allocated to it.

Another problem with the whole rural adjustment package and the emphasis that the Minister is placing on saving rural Australia with rural adjustment is that rural adjustment committees across Australia, which in each State are administered by the State authorities, have to sit and to act as God as to who gets this adjustment.

I have been talking to the banks in Queensland and to the constituents in my electorate and have been advised that up to 50 per cent of applicants have not received any assistance at this stage. The worst is yet to come. In other words, 50 per cent of the applicants are getting assistance but there is still another 50 per cent who are real achievers, who have had a go in the past four or five years, who are getting no assistance at all. They could well be forced into a situation within the next 12 months or two years where not only will they will be penniless but they will also be homeless. They will be forced off the land. The flippant comments of the honourable member for Hinkler obviously demonstrate that he and the Government have no understanding of the crisis confronting rural Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis Mr A.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to enter the adjournment debate this evening. You might recall, Mr Speaker, that last night I informed the House of the very important event in the sporting calendar of the nation which was to occur this evening-the first State of Origin match of the 1991 rugby league season.

SPEECH.PARA: Government members-Who won?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I think those members on my right who interject might not be here if they continue.

—The match having been decided only recently, I am very pleased to be able to inform the House that it was indeed the great sporting spectacle that I suggested last night that it would be. The Queensland State of Origin side has triumphed 6-4 over the New South Wales team and has once again asserted its authority in national rugby league and demonstrated yet again its superior ability in this great sport.

SPEECH.PARA: In the early discussions after the end of the match there were various theories put forward to explain what was, in some quarters, an unexpected victory. It is fair to say that Queensland went into the match as the underdogs. New South Wales had a more much more seasoned team, with nearly half of the Queensland side never having played in a State of Origin match before. As I said last night, put a maroon jersey on a Queensland player in the middle of Lang Park in a State of Origin match and wonderful things can happen. That was certainly the way in which the match unfolded this evening.

I would like to give some special recognition to the efforts of the new players in that side this evening, players who for the first time were in the maroon jerseys in a State of Origin match. Full-back Hauff was outstanding and made no fault throughout the game. It was a sad sight to see him removed from the field injured. One hopes that it is only a minor injury and will not interfere with his commitments later this season.

The other person who deserves special mention was forward Larson, whom, I suspect, most people had not heard anything of and who at half-time had topped the tackle count and, I believe, also topped the count of the number of occasions the ball had been taken up in offence. That is an outstanding contribution from a player in his first match.

There are some other theories. I was interested to see interviewed on the television tonight the New South Wales captain, who claimed that it was the three Ls-Lewis, Langer and Lang Park-that decided it. I suppose that in many respects he is nearly right. I would have put four Ls in there. I think the coach, Graham Lowe, contributed an enormous amount to the win.

Nothing should be taken away from the captain of the side, Wally Lewis, who, as I said last night, is one of the greatest players ever to play in the code of rugby league. He demonstrated this evening in the State of Origin match-taking out the man of the match award-that as a veteran of the game, as he is, he is still on the field one of the best players in the world. His performance this evening was nothing short of outstanding.

My friend and colleague the honourable member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott) has a further analysis of the game and attributes a great portion of our victory to the Ipswich factor. The Ipswich factor was an important one-the Ipswich factor being Kevin Langer, Kevin Walters and Steve Walters, outstanding rugby league players who all contributed magnificently to the performance this evening and certainly played their part in ensuring that Queensland was victorious.

It was one of the great games of rugby league, although it was one of the lowest scoring games. At one point-and I imagine that the statisticians will now be checking through the records-it was speculated that it was the match with the lowest points scored since State of Origin matches were first played. But that does not detract from the quality of the game because the quality of the game was outstanding. The first half, in particular, was played at such a hectic pace that I think all who watched it wondered just how long it could go on that rate. It was a testimony to the fitness of all concerned on both sides that they were able to play the game at such a frantic pace at such a high quality for so long.

Of course, that was the first match of the series. I am sure that you, Mr Speaker, and a number of other members of the House would be keenly looking forward to the second match, which will be in Sydney. I have no doubt whatsoever that the Sydney crowd will provide encouragement for the Blues. I equally have no doubt that the Queensland side will again be victorious.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your time is up! I thought the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs might have got up and done his bit for New South Wales. Nevertheless, it being 11 p.m., the House stands adjourned until 9.30 a.m. tomorrow.
